GAME: Citadels

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The more players, the deeper the game. Fun and easy to explain (also with &quot;non gamers&quot;), it works well with 6-7 players. One of the best strategy games I own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great concept, very tense and entertaining, can be played with anyone.
However, the game has some issues which made me drop out over time. 

Issues I have with this game:
- three player flaw (needs 9th character),
- the game thrives on interaction (so the more players the better) but it drags too long with 6+ players,
- the Thief could benefit from more gold in play,
- the Architect is a bit overpowered,
- the Warlord is severely underpowered especially with 4+ players,
- the districts could be more useful and should interact better with the chosen Characters.

All these points should be addressed in the 2016 Edition, which would raise my score from 7 to 9.

Best with 4-6 players. 
Ordinary with 2-3 and too long with 7-8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
It's a simple game that brings new fun to card drafting with extremely high player interaction. The length is just about right, meaning just a bit longer than it probably needs to be (which is how I like most games.) Predictably unpredictable. A perfect family game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Stupid, random game. You are being punished for picking optimal moves.

RATING: 8
One of the first games in our collection, this has seen lots of play time during the years. While we don't play it nearly as often now, I still appreciate the fun of the role-taking aspect and the "I know that he thinks that I think that he thinks..." twists. A lovely game that can work wonders in creating a fun atmosphere in any gaming group.

Update: played again with 7 players.  Which seemed far too many, loads of downtime and lack of control. I started off enjoying it but about halfway through decided I didn't much like it at all.
I've been told it is great for 2 players and can believe that I might like it for 2 - negligble downtime and complete control of your own destiny.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun game for between 2 and 8 people. I was impressed by the way the rule is written to slightly change the game for every number of players. This makes it work really well with any number.

The game is like a mixture of Mafia with San Juan. You have role selection similar to San Juan but need to guess who picked what role similar to Mafia-type games.

The game includes some variant cards which I think is a great effort by the publisher to make the game stay enjoyable for a long time. We have not tried any of the alternate roles or buildings yet, but do they seem fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Okay game with an interesting "you don't know anyone's character" kind of element, but I'd rather play coup.

RATING: 8.5
Fun fantasy-themed, city-building card game with nice art. Lots of opportunities to be mean to each other. When you get to know the characters, there is a good amount of bluffing and guessing going on. A nice, easy to learn, cut-throat card game.  One of my wife's favorites.

I think the two player game is great; there's definitely less chaos and more mind games. That said, I also like the amount of chaos in a 6-7 player game.

RATING: 9
An excellent game that plays well with the kids and with adults. That's a big plus for us, and the fact that Citadels works so well with two players makes it a go-to game when there's a need for some filler time. It's great.

We don't use the expansion characters, but once in a while we mix things up with some of the buildings from the expansion.

This single game probably wins the "Most Fun Per Cubic Centimeter of Box Space" award.

RATING: N/A
The larger the group, the better for this one.  Everyone is someone, and no one knows who anyone else is.  The assassin chooses to assassinate the king, but is the King the guy next to him, or the quiet one across the table?  And a new round starts, and it all changes.  My only complaint about this game is that it can go on a bit too long.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A fun guessing game.  The Assassin and Thief (and to a lesser extent the Magician) roles spice the game with screwage.

A 7 player game lasts too long, so you may want to reduce the number of districts required in that case.  It plays well even with 2.

It will often take people too long to decide which role to take.  

Sometimes a player will just get stolen from and killed and screwed through the entire game, and that's not fun.  It's one of those games where sometimes, for the sake of civility, I've laid off on someone simply because they'd been a target all game long (even though it would be in my interest to continue to make them a target).

2008-01-31: Downgraded from 7 to 6.2.  Too much downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2010-05-13 (rating 6):

I didn't really appreciate that game. It is fine but slightly boring.

We played 8 players game and obviously the game does not scale well. With numerous players the ending players have little choice of useful roles. And in particular it might be hard to become a king (or seat near to the king) for such player.


I much more prefer to play [gameid=3076] for example.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Terrific Game.  Straightforward rules that make it easy to jump right in (even for a 1st-timer), something that is nice in my gaming group.  Yet, it is complex enough to have staying power.

The game itself is good enough to be rated 8 or above; I gave it a 9 because it comes with "bonus cards" that can be swapped in & out from game to game, making Citadels extremely replayable.  

This bonus card idea is brilliant -- every game should have such a set of extra cards with rules about what to swap for what (in order to maintain game balance) like Citadels does.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
2008-08-04
Somehow i expected a little more from this game. It should have all the elements I usually enjoy - psychology, bluffing, speaking, direct and indirect player interaction. But still there's something missing.

2016-02-23
Citadels involves a lot of outguessing your opponents, and this is basically all the meat. Otherwise it is a rather straightforward climbing game. Or maybe straightforward is not the best word here. The goal is simple but the way there may be quite twisted.

I like how the characters interact with each other and this gives you a lot to ponder on your turn. However, the negative characters (i.e. refraining certain players from taking an action), can create very unsettling moments which could be seen as king making, or simply bullying. In other words, Citadels can certainly destroy the fun for some players if they start taking things personally. 

For me Citadels works as entertainment in the realm of bluffing and table talk and I like it. Usually it is easy to see the best solution for you but this is in plain view for the others as well. Every turn, you have to work out your position relative to other players and act correspondingly but not predictably. Thus I would only play Citadels with friends I know. Playing with complete strangers kills half of the game since you have absolutely no way of knowing what might they be thinking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Classic Bruno Faidutti. Citadels isn't my favorite of Bruno's games, but it is still good. The premise is simple. Each round you secretly select a role to play in order to use its specific power to help yourself win the game. The ultimate goal is to build buildings with enough value to win. Of course sometimes this means murdering other players, making money, etc. artistically the game is quite easy on the eyes but it has a pretty absent theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very entertaining game.
A sure bet for gaming parties.

RATING: 6.5

RATING: 9
The number of games I've played for more than a decade and am still interested in playing is very small. The fact that Citadels is so simple but still makes that list makes it incredible. I love how Faidutti makes you play each other as much as the game rules. I prefer playing with the "fast game" option most of the time, though, as the game can drag a tad at the full length.

RATING: 7
A good game that has elements of San Juan (roles) and other city building games with a deceptively deep strategic element. This game provides the player with many options which can lead to a lot of analysis. We played with six people and the game gets very long with that many people (it took us at least 2  hours). Overall, the artwork on the cards was excellent with the exception of the odd fairylike art for one of the castles (the rest of it all felt very dark and gothic, which I like). My only other complaint would be that the currency looks more like strepsils than any kind of currency, which takes away from the feel a tiny bit. As always, I was also hoping for oversize cards too!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I played this game just twice, so these are mostly impressions that may change after multiple play.

This is a very interesting card game, that is able to offer a lot of depth in a small package. Although I'm not particularly fond of its artwork and components, even if there's not really anything wrong with them, I've to say that I enjoyed it. I especially liked the challenge that comes with its game-play. I like games where you have to outguess your opponents and this one has that in spades!

There's a good level of interaction, but also some take-that elements that bother me a little, because they can really screw you over badly. It's not really fun when you lose your entire turn and it's especially annoying when that happens for a bunch of turns in a row. Furthermore it can really drag the game out to a ridiculous length for a filler like this.

Besides these couple of issues I find Citadel to be an enjoyable game. It's easy to teach, but it's deep and it's very interactive. It's not a game I want to own, but I would like to explore it some more, if I'll have the chance.

RATING: 7
2-8. This is a card game where you build buildings and manage money, which sounds boring, but what makes it awesome is the role selection. Each turn you draft character cards with special abilities, that let you make other players skip their turns, or take their money or their cards and so forth. Very fun though I never win. In my opinion it lasts just a hair too long, especially when playing with 7 or 8. Rules: http://fantasyflightgames.com/ffg_content/Citadels/support/citadels-rules-english.pdf

RATING: 7
An excellent game.  Faidutti's games often look more fun to me than they play.  Perhaps most of them are good if you get the right crowd, but this one is good played against kids, eurogamers, ameritrash gamers, ..., and it scales very nicely from 2 players on up.  Just a fantastic design.  My only criticism would be that it can drag on a little for what it is.

Update: I think my comment above is far too harsh on Bruno Faidutti.  When his games haven't worked for me, it's almost always been referable to players not getting into the spirit.  I am probably unduly influenced by some extremely depressing rounds of Mystery of the Abbey with people prone to erroneous answers.

RATING: 7
FAMILY, STRATEGY

In this card game, players assume roles each turn like the king, alchemist, warlord, etc. while trying to build a diverse "district" (city or kingdom). 

A game that improves with more players--probably not so good for two. I think my rating of this game will increase with more plays.

Recommended with 2-7 players (best 5). 20-60 mins.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
a card game where you choose a character (king, assassin etc) for the round and use them to help you build the best city. Really quite good fun except for the steep learning curve. It is more or less essential to know all the characters up front to get the best out of it.

Crucial to this game is that your actions with, for example the Assassin, are aimed at the character card and NOT the player. So it becomes a game of bluff as each player tries to disguise their choice to protect their turn and achieve the most glorious result

RATING: 4
Definitely one of the better card games around for multiple players, especially when comparing it to Munchkins and Killer Bunnies. 

We played one game with 7 players. My husband got assassinated the first two rounds, so he hated the game because by the time he got to play, he was so far out of the game in terms of build-up, card collection, and money. His comment is that there is a definite runaway factor where 2 player got left in the dust with 2 players took a commanding lead. Also, everyone seemed to think my graveyard card was OP, even though I was only able to use it once during the game. So, my husband gives this a big Nay and it is banned from our house. 

I kind of like the game, except that it is way too chaotic and there is no real way to plan moves. You're not even sure who you are targeting for the character abilities since you call out the characters instead of target the players, so the game doesn't even let you plan that. Also, our game took forever to play, it felt like a 3 hour game - for a simple card game, it far exhausted the 1 hour that we wanted to sink into it. 

UPDATE: After playing Shadow Hunters, I've decided that this game just doesn't cut it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
FAMILY GAME
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
First impression: 10/10
Current impression: 10/10

The first time I played it with my friends almost 2 years ago. Then in another year I played it in another company. Recently I've recalled playing it and actually enjoying it, so I decided to get it. It's not that expensive and it's portable, which is great.

I've had it for a week now approximately, and I'm totally enjoying it and I'm kind of addicted. 

- Short review of the game:

In my opinion, it's a game for 2 players. Maybe 3... 4 in the outermost case. 
Because: the more players there are, the more luck-based the game becomes. And the longer it lasts. 

I highly recommend playing with people who know the rules already and played the game before. And it's also better to make time limits for each turn, playing online we have a 55 sec limit to do all actions (picking roles first, and then in the next phase using the role, collecting money, drawing cards, building, also has to be done in 55 seconds). That can be a bit problematic online if there is lag, but if you play the game normally at a table - it shouldn't be a problem.

In a game with more than 4 people it becomes chaotic and luck-based, as I've already stated. It will just depend on the person's hand and on the randomness of assassins and thieves. There are only 3 destructive roles out of the 8: Assassin, Thief, Warlord. 
Warlord can only destroy a building of one person/turn. It might be alright for trolling, but in a game with many players - that doesn't give anything. And Assassins and Thieves mainly just hit random players. These roles are chosen by the advanced players to not be assassinated or picked themselves with a 100% chance, and to start first.
In my second game, when we were 5 I think... One person just was getting assassinated and picked over and over. Every turn. "F* this game...", "I hate this game" he said. And that was not logical. It was random. He even chose the least advantageous roles to avoid being killed.   
Didn't work. Of course that way some people will hate this game. :)


For 2 players it's totally strategical thinking, psychology too I would say. 2 players is really a challenge. Assassins and Warlords can really do damage here. In the beginning if you have bad building cards, you can choose the Magician, use the best of them, and give the other trash to the player. That might ruin his game. King is a bold role, because next turn you're choosing first. Merchant is overpowered, but for this very reason he is targeted the most. The bishop isn't too strong as far as I can judge by my few games, but still has his pros. 
2 Roles per turn mechanics is great in my opinion. That's best for 2-3 Players. Enjoy!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
A very fun card game with hidden roles, and the roles having special powers.  8 different role cards are shuffled, and one is layed face down.  (some layed face up depending on # players).  The king gets [#players+1] cards to choose from, and passes the rest to the player on his left, who chooses one, and passes it to the player on his left, etc. The last player (with 2 cards to choose from) takes one, and places the final one face down.  This means that the first player will know the first face down card (since he saw all the rest) and the last player will know the last face down card.  This gives each player a semi-advantage on knowing which role each person chose, which is a huge deal, since some of the cards require you to steal or murder a certain role.  If you want to target a certain player, you have to guess which card they chose.  This makes the game very fun and tense.  I can't wait to play another game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I enjoy this game with 2-3 players.  Anymore then that and the game drags on and has too much downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

- A little too dry

RATING: 6.2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
7 players. Won by 1 point. You better build cards that are worth 3 or more to ensure other's can't destroy them too easily. The leader is the most targeted person and easily recognizable. 

thief and murderer are good for payback/fun or balancing the game. thief is ideal if players have lots of gold.
mage if youve got bad cards. 
mercenary is useful at the beginning (low gold count means 1 point buildings) and at the end to destroy other competitor's buildings. 
architect if you dont have cards but not good if you already have several cards because then you most likely have to swap with the mage. can be great in the last round.
priest is only good if you have blue cards.(the game rewards being aggressive, so no use for a defensive card) 
merchant was target #1 in our group for murderer and thief, i wouldnt choose this card
one person chose the king at the beginning 3 times but he knew he will get murdered eventually. i'd say if youre always one of the last players during the turn this card is favorable. and for yellow cards of course.

king's cards are usually worth a lot so they dont get destroyed easily. merchant's cards on the other hand are usually low cost. Makes merchant even more unattractive.

a lot of fun, but i recommend playing with up to 5/ max. 6 players. it takes too much time otherwise.

downtime is no problem because you ought to think about choosing the next card yourself. also need to look at how many cards/gold and how many points the others have.

extra points for 5 different colours seems hard to achieve.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great fun. Easy to play, very replayable. Highly recommended.

RATING: 10
This game is a milestone in game development. I've played it many, many times. It plays great as a 2 player all the way up to 5 player (beyond that it's fun but a bit too luck based). A great game to teach to non-gamers too!

RATING: 7.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Played 6 players once - disappointed by all the downtime. Played with 6 again - we understood the strategy better, had less downtime and all enjoyed it much more. Played 2 player version with my wife - we loved it!!!

UPDATE: Played many more times now. It can be very frustrating when one gets targeted by an assassin, thief or magician (often unwittingly). 

For this reason I'm not happy giving this game a 10, as I like everyone to have fun playing my games, and invariably there is someone who won't!

What's really clever is that it's a combination of an investment game (earning income, buying districts managing cards) and a screwage game (caused by the chaos of secretly choosing roles).

The secret may be balancing these 2 perspectives.

In the past I always treated it as an investment game, and often got whipped. Last time I played I followed a risk management strategy instead - and annihilated the other 5 players!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Zmienione z 10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I personally love this game and most people I've played with have really enjoyed it as well. The two player and the three player games are slight variants where you take multiple characters. I really enjoy the three player game and the two player game is ok. This game works best for me with four or five players. I played with 7 and that was way too much. Perhaps it would work with all experienced players as it would stop the amount of analysis paralysis.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
2-8(5)

2p: It's interesting, and there is plenty of gamesmanship in the role selection (my partner seemingly being better at this than I). Sometimes, I find that being the King, with the first role randomly set aside, leaves you open such that you nearly *have* to choose the Assassin (in some cases it would be blindingly obvious who you've chosen), which seems to remove some tension. Also lacking in that most of the districts are just placeholders (varying only in color and in initial cost/final score), which seems like a pretty big MacGuffin. If it's too aggressive, could go long, I'd say.

Multiplayer: I can certainly see where the Analysis Paralysis comes in. There are several role cards to choose from and sometimes players just keep psyching themselves out out their choices. Also, the games can run really ... really ... long to reach eight districts, especially with the warlord in play. Maybe we didn't play optimally (as far as building aggressively). I'd like to get this out more to see how it can be played more efficiently, but this first play was loooooong.

RATING: 6
At the heart of Citadels is role selection and it is amusingly implemented here, with opportunities for bluff and take-thatery plentiful.  The rest of the game is a rather less interesting matter of developing your city as quickly and to as high a value as possible.  The problem is its ninety minute playing time; this game is really too insubstantial and repetitive to justify that sort of time investment.  

My Hans im Gluck edition is nicely produced and the card artwork is rather lovely.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
In my opinion Citadels is pretty decent (yet flawed) game for its price. It brings some of that 'big' board game experience and decision making to a very newcomer friendly format, but which cards you happen to have in your hands or draw make too much of a difference. It's entirely possible to waste a couple of valuable turns looking for an affordable building while another player has no trouble at all getting one building after another played. That said, with four or more players the drafting mechanic starts to shine which greatly improves the playing experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lots of fun, as long as you don't let "random" screwage get to you.  It's not exactly a "take that" game because it's tough to target another player directly, but can be frustrating if someone guesses correctly (or guesses wrong and takes you out on accident) several turns in a row.  Still, the role selection mechanic is very interesting, and the rest of the gameplay is simple enough to not get in the way.  The only issue is if someone really suffers from AP and takes more than 30 seconds to pick their character - I saw one person take 5 minutes once... what could he possibly have been thinking about?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
Can be ok with 2 or 3 players.  With more than 3, there is WAY too much downtime.  If you get assassinated, you're forced to sit out an entire round and watch everyone else think about their plays. RATING: 7
Revisited this and didn't like it nearly as much.  I actually wasn't too excited to play it.  Maybe this is because I've been exposed to a lot more than when I first played this.  Or maybe the novelty has worn off.  We also played with 4, and I think being limited to just one role might make this a little less interesting.

But yeah, I just felt too controlled by the luck of drawing the right cards or not getting hit by the assassin/thief.

So I pulled the rating down from it's previous heights.

------------------

This is a fun double-guessing, card drafting game.  You have to figure out a way to reach goals without being too predictable.  When one player guesses what the other is going to do then they can really screw them over.

We've mostly played this with just 2 or 3 players and enjoyed it a lot.  You get to pick two roles and it's much easier to predict what everyone else is doing.

Another game that didn't terribly excite me, but was pretty fun.  In our game, the Assassin kept killing the thief, which was pretty funny, but when they didn't things were pretty cutthroat.

I'd definitely play it again, but it just seemed like winning had less to do with how you played then with what you drew and when.

RATING: 5
An interesting card drafting game that has the elements to be a great game. High player interaction and interesting decision making, including anticipation of what your opponents are going to do, are great features of the game. However, the main problem with this game is that is drags on way too long. There's many too much downtime when players are picking their role cards and whenever someone gets close to ending the game, another player uses the Warlord role to destroy one of their districts. These reasons alone make it a snooze to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Traded. It didn't hit the table often after all. The game's popularity also questioned me the reason to hold on to my own copy. I don't mind playing it but not enough to own my copy I guess.

Hated the first time I played this. Thought it was way too long for what it is. Later learned that my friend taught me wrong, we've played 3p game but only chose one role per round. I then also learned that this game works quite nicely with 2 player. So I obtained my copy to try out with my wife. I love this game as a 2p game. It's snappier, more choices per turn, less chaotic and most importantly more head to head mind reading. I thought the the city building element was slapped on during my first play, I still think it is but in 2p play it didn't bother me as much as the game only last for 20 minutes or so.  Willing to explore more on expansions.

RATING: 6
The role drafting and the various abilities of the roles is a key design aspect of this game that makes an otherwise middle of the road game interesting.  Game play can be a bit long and the blind bidding feel can frustrate players if the game is extended to far.  This is likely to be a game that either works for you or doesn't.  It can be highly interactive, so the players involved in the game will determine any interpretation of the game.  Worthy of playing on occasion. [GTI: TGCL]

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The player interaction in this game is awesome.  Players can effectively ally against someone in the lead by choosing specific roles to corner him and wreck his stuff (or at least waste his turn).  Great game.

After playing with 3 players, my esteem for this game has risen even further.  The two roles per game round guarantees that you will get a turn even if you are assassinated.  Plus, the one random unavailable role keeps everyone but the pineapple king guessing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Classic role-selection and tableau-building game. Somewhat old, but still maintains uniqueness and hasn't expired due to new releases.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the games that got me into the Board Game Renaissance.  Picked it up on a whim, since the art was stellar.  Easy to learn, and loved the 'second guessing' of role choice, and choosing the right one vs what other people chose.  It can get tedious, however, if someone is good at assassinating you (you get no turns!), and the non 'role chosing' part of the game, of building up your city, is kind of dull.

RATING: 10

Large player count and quick play time without sacrificing strategy and depth.

Seasoned gamers and beginner approved while it is easy to play the game offers a depth of strategy in role drafting, building choices and also the social element of playing off other players.

Very different play experience depending on the group.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
despite only 2 plays, I think this might be my favorite of the "hidden role" games.  In most of these games there's either not quite enough "game" (werewolf) or the hidden role aspect isn't very satisfying to me (shadow hunters).

Citadels presents the players with tough choices that directly relate to the hidden role mechanic.

It works great.

*Update*
More plays now and this still is a wonderful game.  Every now and then you will get a dud game where either you are the unfortunate target of multiple assasinations, or the game as a whole just drags on a bit.

Still its great bang for your buck and a must play if you like the psychological dance that comes with hidden roles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun filler game that takes a little too long for what it is.  Still worth pulling out every once in a while.

RATING: 9.5
Got interested in Citadelles after so many games of Groo (with which it distantly shares the town building theme and 'take-that' aspect). Played my first games in a tavern with friends over some beers from 4 p.m. until 3 a.m. Excellent variable player power game which made me discover Bruno Faidutti. There are variants available and more than one edition was published.  I never get tired of this game!

RATING: 9
Me and my boyfriend play a lot this game, is one of our favorites. When it;s about choosing personalities we try to guess what the other chooses. With more people I find a bit more chaotic, you can't really guess who chooses what. But it's also interesting. You have to pay attention on you chosen one, because there's a high risk that somebody will choose the thief or the assassin.
The interesting thing for me is when playing with expansion, and we choose the bonus characters: each game is pretty different, you have to find new strategies all the time, because the deck of characters which you use in a game changes all the time, and the characters influences each other.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2007 edition with Dark Cities Expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My biggest problem with the game is with how slow it is with 4+ people. A round generally lasts at least 9-10 minutes because of the long time people take to choose characters. Then it takes 1-2 minute to resolve the choices. I prefer games where I get to "play" for more than 20% of the time. For this reason, in 4+ player games I think Citadels is too light/deep/slow/random for the final payoff. However, I have played several 2 player games and I like it a lot more this way. In my experience, this game is much better with fewer people (2-4). So overall I'd say Citadels is an good game for 2-4 players with the added versatility of enabling up to 8 players to play. If you are playing with 4+, insist on fast role selection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The dynamic of this game changes depending on the group size. Great potential for back-stabing in this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nagyon tetszett!! Könnyed és változatos, 4-en próbáltuk. Nálam kenterbe veri a Dominiont.
---
Nem tudom már, 2010-ben, amikor először próbáltam, miért pont a Dominionhoz hasonlítottam:) Így 5 év elteltével újra játszva vele ami elsőként eszembe jut, hogy szerintem megelőzi a korát. Konfrontatív játékot nem kedvelőknek nem ajánlom. Olvastam hogy csak többen jó, de mi hárman is élvezzük, szerintem változatos, a sok karakter sok újrajátszhatóságot ad. Ráadásul mivel kevés játékos esetén 2 karaktert visz mindenki, kisebb a holtidő, és nehezebb teljesen kilőni valakit egy körből. Egy 6 fős játékban elég uncsi lehet ha kinyírják a karakterét valakinek és passzívan végigüli a teljes kört. Ráadásul a gyilkolással nem lehet tutira menni, lehet hogy véletlen mindig ugyanazt ölik meg, aki így végigüli a játékot tétlenül, a halott karaktereit siratva. Ez mondjuk nem túl pozitív, de szerintem még mindig jobb, mintha konkrét játékost lehetne megölni.
Sajnos a szabály nem elég egzakt, bizonyos szituációk nincsenek leszabályozva (pl. a Diplomata adhat cserébe olyan épületet, amiből már van a városomban? A logikus az hogy nem, de ez csak faq-ban van meg, ahogy sok más is. Elég sok egymásrahatásuk van a karaktereknek és épületeknek, ezen alaposan illett volna végigmenni a szabályban...)
De a hibái ellenére is jó kis játék!!
---
Húha, eddig max 4 fővel játszottam, most 9-en próbáltuk, ami azt hiszem hivatalosan nem is lehetséges, a szabályban max 7 fő van, a dobozon 8 az extrák miatt... Azt hiszem, igazságtalanság lenne ez alapján a parti alapján pontozni, mert nagyon sok holtidő volt így, 2 és fél - 3 óra volt a játékidő. Egyszer ki kéne már próbálni 5-6 fővel, ahogy ajánlják:))) Egyébként nem volt rossz élmény annyira, csak nem tudom eldönteni, mi akar ez lenni, partijátéknak hosszú, de amúgy meg laza káosz az egész... Néha bele lehet azért trafálni dolgokba, de sok esetben nem látom a tervezhetőséget.

RATING: 6
Highly recommended 6  player game.

First game: 4-21-07
I find it to be ok.  Not especially excited about.  There is enough mind games and you can plan somewhat since you can try and predict what roles people are going to choose.  However, the Thief and the Assassin employs direct conflict, which would turn a lot of people as they can get pretty personal.  At the same time, I don't know how the game would work without them without applying athematic, rigid rules to prevent broken "combos".  Just not my cup of tea.

RATING: 8.5
Possibly the biggest gaming hit yet with my boys (7 and 5) - despite the "take that" elements (and occassional break-downs!) they keep coming back for more. Very impressed by the 5 year-olds ability to think through his options. We play with the Witch and the Wizard to reduce the impact of the "take that" aspects to a degree. Especially good with 2 as you can never be certain which roles have been selected. Good with three too. My wife has joined in a couple of times, but her boastful approach went down very badly with the boys....!

RATING: 6.5
One of those classic games who made on role selection a widespread knwledge. It has light rules but need quite a lot of deduction and bluffing, so it is a great choice as a gateway-game. There's lots of chaos and chance, however, so it should not be taken too seriously, but seen as a fun ride (quasi a party game) and played very quickly (ideal play time: 30 minutes! Above this, it overstays its welcome...).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
The first card game I've owned - city building with hidden roles and a bit of bluffing among players. Game takes a bit too long that usually I'll make the end game triggering condition to be 7 instead of 8 cities. The character drafting at the start of every turn will really slow the game down if anyone is unfamiliarize with the characters or over-analyzing the possible characters that other players have already drafted. Still a good game but I'm pretty burn out from overplaying it when I initially own it, will still pull it out from time to time if requested.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think I like this game more then my friends and it's really not very good with less then 3 players. It's another city building game and I prefer San Juan over this. the major difference is the characters and they way you purchase your properties. It also have the added element that one character will be able to destroy a property of your opponent if you can pay the price. 

A majoy thing about this game is to always try and figure out which character each of your opponents are holding and since they are selected in a intricate way. The flaw in this is that you will almost always be able to figure it out or atleast very rarely be wrong if you just follow what is going on and that is really the greatest downside in this game since the characters you choose may counter effects of your opponents character or set him at a disadvantage. 

Since the characters are numbered from 1-8  and whoever picked #1 will play first during that round, plus with the added twist that that character happens to be the assassin who can chose to kill on of your opponents characters if you guess right of what they are holding (long sentence) it is a major advantage to be able to chose the assassin as you can take away your opponents advantage of his card for an entire turn. The more people you are the less power will the assassin have but the game is still not hard enough tactically to make it anywhere near the top of my list.

Fun on occation
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
First Play: Easy enoughy to learn but a cheat sheet with the character details on is essential, one per player. 

There is a danger of down time as people pick character cards so a timer might be necessary for those with AP.

I liked the deduction necessary to establish who was doing what for any particular reason. The randomness of the cards might be an issue with further plays but the expansion would seem to add legs to the life span of the game.

Looks like it could be a good one for the pub.

After further plays this one has legs and some. Rating up'ed (7.5)

Indeed the randomness is starting to jade the experience. Its an OK filler but having returned to play after a long break, it really did seem that a large slice of the game is out of a players control. Rating back to 7.

RATING: 7
Solid game for the simplicity. I like the mechanics that allow for a lot of player interaction (killing, stealing and destruction of property). Enough luck to make it interesting but usually not enough to kill a superior strategy. Easy to learn, decently quick game play and high number of players make it a good choice for large groups. If someone is having a good night and winning a lot of games; throw this game in, gang up on them and take them off the winners seat ;)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
RoleSelection, Solo

I've mostly played this game two-player, and it's been an excellent role-choosing game (one of the mechanics that Puerto Rico and Meuterer are famous for).  I have been playing this game multiplayer online, and I enjoy it there too, about as much.  In my personal copy, the character cards are safely sleeved for handling.
  
I keep this game around because it's a great bluffing/role-choosing game, and I am fond of bluffing games.  The game around the mechanic is simple, and the roles interact with that game in interesting (and sometimes brutal) ways.  The alternate characters in the American version are a must.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The interaction of the different roles is wonderful, and the twist of attacking other players by guessing which role they selected is awesome.  It's a really great game as long as it doesn't last too long.  We usually play to 7 districts instead of 8 to keep things moving.  I don't recommend playing with large groups, though, unless none of the players suffer from analysis-paralysis.

For some reason people can really freeze up when making their role selection, so be prepared for that.  Also, this game is about beating others down as much as it is about building yourself up, so don't play with players that have easily bruised feelings.  The fun in this game comes primarily from the assassin and the thief roles.  Players who select those roles are challenged to select the role that a particular person chose, and players who might be targeted are challenged to select roles that the assassin and thief won't expect.  It makes the game tons of fun, and I love seeing the look on someone's face when I select the right role and steal their pot of gold.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Played this once when I was in no condition for gaming. I was extremely tired and had huge problems focusing. Add to that that 3 of the 5 people had never played before so we had massive amounts of downtime while people selected roles. The game lasted more than 2½ hours which is just way too long for a game like this.

I did see the potential in the game though. A game that is easy to grasp but hard to master. Indeed I came in second to last after struggling immensely the first few rounds. Don't feel like I can rate it properly at this time though - would need more plays. Which I'd happily do - I just wish there was less downtime. We played this right after 7 Wonders where downtime is close to zero.

RATING: 6
Incredibly fun.  Everybody knows the strategy, so it turns into a game of can-I-out-think-you with the character cards.  Play mechanics work seamlessly, and for the seeming complexity of the character cards, I could explain the entire game in 3-5 minutes.  The two-player game, which is where all of my plays have been so far, has been thrilling, intense, and most of all, fun.  Anxious to try it with more players.

Alright, tried with more players and I'm convinced.  Tremendous fun and staying power.

RATING: 3
I've played this twice, each time with 7 players. Each time I was told it would be a fast game, and each time it ran over two hours. Assassination, stealing, and destroying buildings all make a long, slow, boring game longer. And it's not as if you have anything to do on your turn if any of them happen to you. It's a slow, boring, slog and I never want to play it again.

The only reason it's a 3 and not lower is because I hear it might be better with fewer people. If so, why even go up to that many players?

RATING: 8.8
Great game, really enjoyed with 2 but it shines with 4 or more. Easy to teach with lots of interaction and second guessing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Citadels is the perfect (card) game for it keeps the rules to a minimum while making for a deep interaction among players and creating a very warm and friendly ambience: actually I would number it among the all-time best games as well, for it requires strategy, skills, vision and even a bit of luck, which helps prevent the game from being too cold and impersonal.

Citadels is easy both to understand and play and as such it’s a good game to be played with casual or non gamers: quickly indeed they’ll feel like they’re pulled into the middle of the action and within just a couple of turns they’ll start thinking they could even make it, thus pondering more cautiously their next actions.

Edit: after further plays I raised my rating from 8 to 9 in November 2011.

RATING: 6
I owned this game a long time ago, played it a bunch 2-player and was unimpressed, so I traded it away. Recent games with three players made me more impressed with the central role-selection/imperfect information mechanic, but ultimately until I play with more (ie enough that we're not selecting two roles per player) I think this will remain a 6. I'm convinced the game scales VERY poorly.

EDIT: after a 5-player game where I came second, I think the problem is that I just don't really deal all that well with the sort of role selection game that privileges the reading of multiple tableaus at once. Might be why I find the higher levels of RftG strategy so difficult, too.

RATING: 3
Completely loathsome.  I have had the unfortunate pleasure of playing this again recently and it confirmed that this is maybe the most overrated game on the Geek even at a paltry 100+ ranking.  At least other highly rated games have something I can point to as appealing, here we just have a pile of randomness rolled in with some hosage and then overbaked with a 45 minute playing time.  Virtually no important decisions yet one player always spends far too much time thinking about what role to pick.  Then I get assassinated even though I have no chance of winning as it is.  At really short filler length it might be tolerable, but it's not and for that I give it my second lowest rating.

RATING: 8
I've only played this in 2-player, against an experienced player.  It was a fascinating exercise in logic, deduction and indecision!

Played this a few more times now, in some larger groups. I like it - it's not amazing, but it doesn't take too long, and I like the feeling of always being able to do something. On the other hand, it's a pain if everyone decides you're winning and spends their time trying to stop you, and the assassin effectively wiping out someone's turn isn't a great feeling. I'm not a fan of mechanics that see people losing turns.

RATING: 6

RATING: 8
I have only played this with two players so I cannot speak to the "wildness" of the game with many players or speak to the claim I've heard that it can overstay its welcome. The two player game was a very fun conjunction of choosing of roles, bluffing and strategy. It's a short game (again, with two players) and it surprised to me to find that there still was a little feeling of theme in the gameplay that made the experience enjoyable. It was satisfying to look over my city at the end of the game. It's not a brainburner and could be played with the same intensity as Carcassonne, for example, and therefore could allow conversation and music, for example. It's a great weeknight game and I'm glad to have it in the collection.

Update: I finally played it with six players and it moved up to an 7 to an 8. I get it now. We played with the Diplomat and only to six cards and this kept the time down significantly. With a watchful eye towards keeping the play time at a healthy pace I think this is a winner.

RATING: 6
I don't really know what Citadels is. 

It claims to be a bluffing, cutthroat, city-building game that operates within variable powers and turn-order, (overall some really nice mechanics) but nothing truly stands out in terms of purpose. In fact, everything is kinda pithy with elements of luck and low decision making. Most of the time, it comes down to how good your starting hand is and who can build their citadel first.

RATING: 2
Another game others love and I loathe. It's all about punishing success - unless you luck out and get missed. Collect gold, it'll be stolen, get a big hand and the magician swaps with you, take a good role and be killed by the assassin. You can't plan ahead, the 'take that' is rather random, game is just too chaotic for me.

Add the downtime and it's killed stone dead - had no fun at all, just wanted the game to end ... could stand it if it ran 20 minutes, but three times that (+) no thanks.

RATING: 7
A nice game that can be completed fairly quickly. After a little stumbling with the rules (which, to be fair, may have been due to my attempt at describing them - something I'm not too brilliant at) it went along fairly smoothly. 
It wouldn't take too long to complete, and with the extra 'special' characters after the first few games, it could become quite good! 

A great little game if you've not got too long to play something, or if you've got a few hours to kill (waiting for meals, or at an airport waiting for your flight).

The cards have really nice artwork on them too, which is always a plus - even if a subjective plus.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fast-paced, fun, nerve-racking, and makes for some hilariously paranoid situations. Every round you secretly draft role cards that give you specific upgrades as you try to build up a city, but some role cards are specifically designed to screw other players over. However, as much as the game is very much about screwing over other players, the fact that you can easily recover means that Citadels never feels particularly mean. A great, portable card game that I carry around just in case, and it usually does a great job of filling in awkward gaps of time.

RATING: 6
An old favorite of my gaming group. I must confess that Citadels is a rather flawed game, but I still have a soft spot for it.

It provides a greatly different player experience with different player counts. 2-player Citadels is surprisingly good; it is a very tense guessing and bluffing game.

3-player Citadels does not balance perfectly, since the first player typically has too great of an advantage. 4-player and 5-player are better, but then down time starts to become a serious issue.

RATING: 8
The role selection is great fun. Some roles are obviously better than others. It becomes interesting because the good roles have a higher chance of being murdered by the assassin and making too obvious choices makes you a target for the thief.

Sometimes it happens that one player gets murdered and mugged several times in a row (without intension from the other players) which leaves them with no chance to win. Luckily this doesn't happen too often.

The extra roles from the included expansion are good to mix in with the original roles, but overall I prefer the ones from base game.

RATING: 6
I liked this game a lot when I first played it, but then it started to wear on me. A group of friends really likes to play this game and so I have probably overplayed it. We've played with six or more which makes it too long and too long inbetween decisions. It is probably best with 4. I find the assassin a flaw in the game. It isn't very fun to get killed and miss your entire turn and can completely ruin the game for you if it happens to often. The game also has a king-maker problem; I've had several games were two or more were in contention to win and then one of the other players destroyed one of their buildings (sometimes for spite because that player took their cards earlier in the game) and completely handed the game to the other player. I like games where I win based on how well I play, not by how long I can fly under the radar. It can be quite fun though and if you play it in light-spirits it makes for an enjoyable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played this again recently with three and had a blast. So my rating climbed, but ONLY FOR 2 or 3 Players. Any more and a horrible waste of time.

RATING: 6
Played with three players. Very fun, although (at least in the one time I've played) the Assassin is hugely overpowered, and some of the other role cards were almost entirely ignored (in particular, the Magician and the Bishop -- although my brother invoked the Bishop at just the right time to nearly eke out a victory).

UPDATE: Played again with five, incl. three new players. The game dragged a little, and it was much harder to teach than I had expected -- it took a couple of turns before everybody understood the roles well enough. But then everybody got into it! The most surprising aspect, with so many people: heated negotiations to avoid (or redirect) the Warlord's power.

UPDATE: With two players, the thief is too weak, and the bishop too powerful. Might have to swap out.

UPDATE: I have yet to have a truly outstanding session of this game. That makes me sad. Downgraded.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
avg game (old one)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best known pre-PR role-choice game, and deservedly so (though inspired by 'Veratter').  Being a Faidutti, there's touches of chaos here, and the Assassin, Thief, Magician and Warlord can make things very tough if you seem to be a random target, but you should only be a target if you're doing well.  Played properly, those characters help make sure there are no runaway winners and the whole is nicely balanced as a result, with finishes usually pretty tight.  Just don't overthink it or it will drag on a bit too long - the key is for the King to keep a close eye on things and move on at a good pace rather than letting things meander.  Still Bruno's best I think.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good introduction for newcomers to card/board games!

RATING: 9.5
I was going to give Citadels a 9, but then I had to raise it to a 9.5 because it's just that good.  There are a few minor flaws that hold this game back from a perfect 10 (why does the Library cost more than the Smithy?), but few games offer more excitement and intrigue.  This game has rivaled Settlers in terms of play time for all of the gaming groups that I've introduced it to.  It's great as a 3-player and a 4-player game, and that's something Settlers can't say.  Like Dante's Commedia, Bruno Faidutti's Citadels is a work of art for the ages.

RATING: 4
Although a little simplistic, I quite enjoy this little game and would love to break it out when time is limited or when I'm too tired to devote the required energy to one of my larger games.  

Unfortunately, my typical gaming partners don't seem to enjoy this game: one doesn't care for the bluffing/deduction mechanic; one doesn't care for the conflict demanded by half the roles.  Consequently, I can't accurately comment on the depth of strategy or quality of the experience. 

I am quite disappointed by the blandness of the buildings.  It'd be nice to feel like I was really building up some sort of city, rather than just "banking" gold (which is largely what building amounts to).

I feel like there's more waiting to be explored. 

Edit: I'm making an effort to rate games where possible, even if a bit premature.  After purchasing and playing Battle Line, I just can't imagine this hitting the right spot with any group short of 5+ (Battle Line is far Superior with 2 players; Dominion or Race for the Galaxy are more interesting with 3-4) and that seems like it might just be chaos.

RATING: 7

Got this feeling that the step up in complexity is still digestible for such a gaming group - at least if they're not hardcore non-gamers. After all, it's more psychology and bluff than calculating strategy (which doesn't tend to mix well with a less than sober state. :p ). 

So, given the low price, I may pick up this one for the above purpose.

RATING: 7
Small Game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Citadels was never something I played a lot of (my group had already more or less exhausted it by the time I'd entered the hobby - a mere two years after its release), but I enjoyed it with a few caveats (use of expansion roles to replace Assassin & Thief, always playing to 7 buildings, never playing with more than 5 players). These days, I find it incredibly hard to go back to.

Let's start with the positive, though: the role selection mechanic here is great. By now, there have been a million copycats or variations on it but Citadels' implementation is uniquely tense and exciting (okay, besides Meuterer which is identical, but has a better game wrapped around) - it just plain feels good to pull off what can feel like elaborate double bluffs, and correctly deduce which roles the other players are going to select in order to maximize your personal gains. There's better bluffing games, to be sure, but Citadels' mind games (and the rewards they reap) carves itself a nice identity all its own (again, excepting Meuterer but nobody wants to play that with me for some reason).

And yet... I feel like the game occupies this weird space between "light game" and "filler". It's somehow not enough to say "the game drags on for too long", though that is the core issue. It's just not punchy enough to hold up to an hour (more frequently 1.5 minimum), and even at 30-45 minutes (rare) it feels bloated. I just think I would like this game better if it had been pared down to its absolute barest essence, dissolving all of the fat (I apologize for the yucky imagery) and leaving behind only the PURE FUN that is the shining core - the kind of bare-bones-but-maximized-fun systems that are the hallmark of a good filler. Everything surrounding the bluffing and double bluffing just feels non-essential.

And it doesn't help that all of the truly confrontational interaction in Citadels serves to extend the game time. Assassin, Warlock, Thief... these roles all just artificially draw things out, while encouraging you to attack the leader without really feeling like you're making tactically satisfying or clever plays.

Blame it on the advancement of designs, but these days whenever I think of Citadels I increasingly find myself wishing it was either just... more than it is or less. And for me, there's just no turning back.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Un juego ligero entretenido y divertido. El factor suerte aparece, si bien casi nunca no es determinante en las partidas, añadiendo variedad al juego. Aunque Ciudadelas es un juego ligero, yo no lo recomendaría como iniciación. Normalmente surgen problemas a la hora de conjugar los diferentes roles con sus posibilidades estratégicas, y al mismo tiempo, confunden habitualmetne la regla de principio de turno de o coger dos cartas y elegir una o coger dos monedas. 

An entertained and amused light game. The luck appears, although it isn t determinant, adding variety to the game. Although Ciudadelas is a light game, I would not recommend it like introduction to the boardgames. Often  there are problems with the understanding rol s strategy, and at the same time, often the rule of taking two cards and choosing one or to take two currencies confuse.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There are many things I like about this game.  The components are nice and the artwork on the cards are very well done.  The premise of the game is simple, but there is a lot of strategy.  The main gripe that I have with the game is that the perfect setup is required to have a blast with the game.  Although it plays with 2-6 players, I've only had a really fun time with 5 players. With less than 5, it becomes a lot more predictable what roles players pick with the amount of information on the table.  With more than 5, the game tends to drag and become too chaotic.  Even with 5 players, the right crowd needs to be involved for everyone to have a good time.  The game can be very cutthroat, even if the actions are based on educated guesses.  A person who is constantly killed, stolen from, and districts destroyed will have a miserable time.  People who don't take setbacks well will darken the mood of the game.  The game can move really slowly due to the analysis paralysis that may occur.  If you have a group of heavy gamers, the rounds will tend to drag.  I would rate the game higher, but lowered the score due to the difficulty to have the ideal setup of players and personalities required to make the game enjoyable.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Bizarre mashup of chaotic take-that fest and deep decision making deduction game. I usually like that kind of managed chaos hybrid, but here the assassin and thief choices often seem arbitrary. The card that ends the game one building early is absurd, as you can't plan anything. If the game played in 45 minutes, it could be OK, but it drags on and on and on

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
If I remember correctly, my first rating of Citadels was 7.5 or so. It was quite intriguing because of the role selection mechanism. Since that first play my enthusiasm for the game has declined, and it's mainly because of the fact that it's actually a quite light game without many meaningful decisions and because it's basically just too long for what it offers.

I still think the role selection is okay, and it's always funny to pick the Assassin or Thief and think about who picked which role! Those two, along the warlock, means that the game has a fair amount of interaction which is almost always a plus.

I wouldn't play it with more than 5 players I think, simply because of the massive downtime and long playing time, and if I'm playing it again I think I'm going to suggest to play with the variant that the game ends after the 7th building has been built as I think that's much better for a game like this.

One thing I appreciate about a game, but which has nothing to do with the gameplay, is the size of the box... I don't have much space for games, so this tiny box is warmly welcomed (and the new edition even includes the expansion which is great)! Still, the gameplay isn't great so it's a game I don't need to own and will probably only play on rare occasions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Secret role game that works okay with larger groups (provided things don't slow down too much).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Playful, frustrating, enjoyable chaos that is surprisingly quick for newbies to pick up. I consider it a must have for any gaming library, and partly because it it scales well from 3 to 7. It's a must to put the character cards in protectors. // Kudos to Fantasy Flight on upgrading the 05 edition---smaller box, better card quality, expansion included = ALL GOOD 

UPDATE: 01/09
Hitting the table more as I have been teaching it to new people just coming into designer games. For those first four or five times you play it with a new crowd---this is good stuff! Maybe you can play it into the ground if played too often, but it is a favorite of mine to teach and introduce to new gamers. 

NOTE: In an effort to speed the game up I teach the game with 7 buildings as the goal (6 for the very first game teaching) and also allow players to keep both cards on a draw. Speeding the game up is important to keep the game fresh. Usual good for a copy plays with a group and then we move on before it starts bugging people.

My criterion for rating games


http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/147053/item/2300390#item2300390


1) Sense of wonder: For the most part this game is the same everytime, but there is some mystery in what roles you will be passes and what role each player has taken.

2) Meaningful/fun decisions.  Some choices throughout the game mostly about what role to pick. Too many times it is obvious which role you need to take.

3) Player interaction:  This is the strength of this game.  Trying to figure out which role each player is taking and who the assassin/thief is attacking as well as whose building the warlord is going to destroy is fun.

4) Components/artwork:  Nice cards and money tokens that look like candy! The artwork is kind of strange and not really my thing.

5) Game length/complexity:  The game has a nice about of complexity for a game night crowd, but the game can really drag on with the assassin killing the merchant/navigator and the thief stealing and the warlord blowing up the buildings. It can really drag with more than 4 players. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice game plays quickly and also a matter of think and double think
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a classic role-selection card/building game.  Very few people dislike it.

It's simple and fun, and some thinking is involved when choosing roles.

The only downside is that some thinking is involved when choosing roles :)  A bad thing when you have slow thinkers playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This game is a winner for me.  A tremendous amount of potential for strategy building on each turn, and the game plays very fast with 2 or 3 players (because you can build up to 2 buildings per round).  Overall, a fun game, with easy rules and fast play.

This game is the most fun with 5 or 6 players, and a few purple building cards from the expansion (that comes with the new reprints from FFG).  Each player only gets one role, so the game plays out longer, but the element of intrique, suspicion, and guessing really make this a gamers game.  A lot of fun with a group of people - Well done!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I rate this lower because it has a bit of a Puerto Rico feel, though can be fun to play when in the right mood and with the right people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
A nice little card game that takes @30 minutes to play.  The cards are of excellent quality with moderate to good art.  The gold coins that come with the game feel substantial enough that you feel good getting them and are not so big that they're cumbersome to deal with.  
Strategy can vary depending on the number of players, with the mechanic of picking your role(s) being the most notable change.  I am particularly fond of this part of the game; the challenge of figuring out the best role to chose based on the mindset of the other players.
Biggest complaint is that the city districts being played don't feel to have any real relationship to each other (why would my city have a battlefield?).  
All things said, a great game either for a quick one-off between other games or for an entire evening with friends.

RATING: 8
Played this a lot ages ago, and still enjoy it when it comes out.  I like the art and the flavor of the game, and think the selection of character/powers is well balanced.  Games tend to result in pile on the leader activity, so often the first person to approach a win is definitely not going to win.  It can have some real player conflict, which some people may be averse to.  The expansion characters can alleviate this some, such as the diplomat which is a less screw-you version of the warlord.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Initial rating is a 6 after a 2 player game, but I suspect this will go up. The true test will be to see how this game works with a range of player numbers, as I'd like this to be flexible enough for 2, 3, 6, and even 7 players.

Update: I'm still only playing this with two players, but I'm liking it more. Bump it up to a "7". It took a while but it's growing on me. The rules read OK, but nothing special. The first game felt "eh." But once you learn the character cards and how to play off your opponents, it becomes much more enjoyable. Curious to see how this plays with 5, 6, or 7 people. I expect this rating will continue to increase as people learn the game.

Update: Finally played this with 4 players. It's not shockingly better than 2 players... just different. I predict though that with 6 or 7 players this game would drag too much. 4 or 5 is definitely the "sweet spot."

Update: Dropped this to a 6, and it probably stays there. I don't mind owning it... it's cheap, and it serves as a decent gateway game for new players. However, it's also a little long (I can see how I'd always cut it down to 7 districts), and there's many more interesting games I want to play at this complexity and time frame.

Update: traded this away in a math trade for the Treasure Chest expansion for In the Year of the Dragon. This just wasn't getting any play, and there's far more interesting games in my collection.

RATING: 5
A secret role selection game that is fun for the first few rounds, but there is too much attacking in this game for it to be a lot of fun for me. The game can simply stall out once people get to 6 buildings because so many roles damage other players and take a few more turns so it outstays its welcome. I will admit the purple building card special abilities are pretty good and really do give the game some extra life, but if I am looking for a game of this type I would reach for Libertalia because in that game you know it will end after a set number of turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The most amusing part of this game for me is looking at what roles have already been taken and trying to figure out who has done what.  Some of the game is luck and some of the game is skill in figuring out what moves to make, but in a large game, most of the players--especially those further in the middle, further away from the king--have to make lucky guesses or clever deductions to figure out who's playing which role.  An egg timer might be useful for the role selection phase of the game, especially in larger games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Update on 9/11/15: Okay. It is not terrible with three. Moderately fun. The take that aspect is a little annoying but, with less downtime, I can see more of the charm of the game. But there isn't much.

(3/29/10 - still 10 plays): I've got to steal enzo622's comment. It is just too right on:

"Ugh, this game annoys the hell out of me! Seriously, I can't believe people enjoy sitting around a table and playing a game of "random take-that" that goes on and on and on... and on and on. Twenty minutes for a group of 8 per turn and if you get assed out of a turn by the Assassin or Thief or whatever, you're looking at literally 40 minutes without doing much at all. And the thing is, you got assed out of a turn completely randomly; the other player was probably not even gunning for you.

I played Mission: Red Planet and it was the same thing. I could not figure out why I was at the table when a monkey would have the same results as a human playing that game. I guess if you want to be absolved of any responsibility for winning or losing, these types of games may appeal to you.

I can't stand Bruno Faidutti games and their chaotic, random style of "take that". Mr. Faidutti, you know what? Chicken butt."

(2/2/10 - 10 Plays) I'm doing a ratings revision, and maybe this isn't fair, but I can't imagine asking to play this game, and I can only imagine it being fun with certain people. The action selection mechanism just bugs the crap out of me.

Originally rated a 6. Since updated to a 7 after 7 plays. So far played with 7, 6, 4, 3, and 2. What is actually neat about this is how totally differently it plays with different numbers. So far, I think I like four the best. With 6 & 7, the game went far longer than its worth.

RATING: 8
Players: 2 − 7*
*Dark City expansion adds an 8th player with adjusted rules.

[Played with 2 Player Rules]
A lot of game in a little box. Almost 2 games in one with 2 solid core mechanics. Choosing a character (and hindering your opponents in the process) and building a city, enhanced by your character's abilities. The fact that you're changing characters each round makes it all the more interesting.

Starts out as a luck based game, but over the rounds you can influence how the game plays out for both yourself and your opponents. The hand that you are dealt in the beginning really shapes your strategy from the onset. 

Full of options. One of Bruno Fiadutti's best! Also comes with the Dark City expansion which adds more variety.

RATING: 4
Too long to be a filler, even to be a deluxxx-super-filler like Race For The Galaxy or Fleet, more interesting games with similar footprints and half the playtime. Too insubstantial to be a really good main-event game. But, at the same time, not an actually [i]bad[/i] game, if you feel me. Just an unmemorable one. But at the very least it certainly conveys the atmosphere of intriguing power brokers in a fantasy city better than Lords of Waterdeep can manage...

RATING: 6

RATING: 6.5
Rare to find a strategy game that supports 7 players, but I've only played twice so I'm not sure how much I like it (rating may go up/down one).  It's really important for players to choose roles quickly or the game drags.  Might be worth using a timer for that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
The rules are quite straight-forward, so you can start a game quite quickly.

There could have been more variation in the available buildings (filling a city with three castles, two palaces and a few churches just seems silly) and I do not particularly like the artwork (inconsistent style: realistic mixed with fantasy-like, and humans look pretty awkward). Also, scoring is not easily memorised, meaning it is not that simple to determine the winner at a glance when building the last building for your city.

Overal, the game is a success despite the above, because it really leads to excellent player interaction: the insecurity when you notice the murderer is gone after the first player took their card means you do not dare to take the merchant card as it would be the obvious move and you may get killed because of it - only to find out later that the murderer was not in play in that round... It is a game of phatoming and anticipating your opponents' thoughts and decisions, but also a game of luck/guessing to some extent. These elements are mixed brilliantly through a simple system.

RATING: 5
No sleeves
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
My enjoyment of this game is probably a 7 or 8 but because it comes with so many caveats, I have only rated it a 6.

Firstly do your research before playing this game! I heard beforehand that it can play too long (so we only play to 7 structures and never play with too many players). 

Secondly, play this when you're all feeling fresh, and not late into the night after 3 games of Pandemic and everyone's a bit sleepy or it will SLOW RIGHT DOWN. It sounds silly, but because you have to think about your role selection and what you think other people will choose, if everyone is tired the game will drag on.

I have played the 2 player and the multi-player versions of this game. Both are good. The 2-player is very psychological and sometimes for me, a little too intense/stressful. This is because you are picking two roles to play and you and your opponent are gunning for each other from the start. I really do enjoy the stimulation from the game but sometimes I just won't play it (as 2 players) because I get stressed out!

The multiplayer is much less stressful because you aren't constantly a target or having to target someone else - it gets spread between you, so you can actually focus on building something. That being said, it can drag if you let it (so take heed of my first two points and you'll have fun).

I own the Fantasy Flight (smaller box) version of this game which comes with the Dark City expansion included. It is very portable and we originally bought it because we can take it hiking easily and it plays such a variety of numbers of players which is a win in my books.

In the end though, if my entire collection was destroyed, I probably wouldn't try to replace this.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorite card game.  The game is easy to teach and most people grasp it after the first round or two.  While some feel there is too much downtime, I stay engaged with everyone's action and trying to figure out the players' strategies.  The game can drag with the wrong people - especially the closer they sit to the king and have more character options.  For that slight inconvenience, I knock it down to an 8.

Citadels is a game I'd rather not play, but if someone was enthusiastic about it...I'd be willing.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
What is with the hype on this one? The overall mechanisms of the game have promise, gold or cards, build buildings to make different roles better for you, usw; what it boils down to though, is a whole lot of punishment. You can't have a big hand or the magician will swap with you. You can't have a lot of gold, or the thief will hit you. You're in danger taking either of the better roles (Merchant and Architect) because the Assassin will be likely to hit you. And on, and on. 

My A number one complaint with this game is that planning ahead is nigh impossible because of all the constant chaos that unfolds as the game progresses. I like a lot of the ideas that it has, but the reality of its implementation is just not to my tastes at all. The game presents the illusion of interesting choices (i.e.: I think I'll create card advantage by doing this) and then randomly punishes you and renders your planning useless. Funnily, games like Fluxx, which I consider about as random as this, are less offensive to me in the grand sense because at least Fluxx doesn't have the pretension of being a game where the decisions you make are all that important. Citadels does, and what it delivers is that much more annoying to me as a result. Quite easily my least favourite game put out by both HiG and European design firms in general.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Finally, after playing this off and on for a few years I've come to really love Citadels.  For whatever reason, the game never really clicked with me (probably because I wasn't playing it with the right people) but it's become a regular fixture with my group.  The game has a very, very high degree of replayability because it allows for direct interaction, deduction, and competition unlike many Euros and there is always an interesting choice or two to be made every turn.  The art is terrific, the expansion is great...definitely a seminal classic that will be played for many years to come.

RATING: 8
Egyszerű játék, amiben az a legjobb, hogy minden játékos minden körben más-más karakter lehet. De nehéz a választás:
ha olyan karakter vagyok, aki inkább a saját kis kerületeit építené vagy pénzt, lapot gyűjtene, megszerezné a koronát, akkor a többi karakter könnyen meglophatja, rombolhatja. Ha viszont olyan karakter amivel mások kártyáit, pénzét elszedem, aki megöl másokat, vagy aki lerombolja mások épületeit, akkor bár másokat hátráltat, önmaga sokkal lassabban fejlődik.
Az is lényeges, hogy jól blöfföljünk, ne tudják a többiek én melyik karakter vagyok éppen, és közben a magam javára tudjam fordítani az eseményeket.

Szóval közelíti szememben a tökéletes játékokat. Hogy mégis mi a negatívum? Amikor a karaktereket ki kell választani, illetve amíg adott játékos azon gondolkozik, hogy kit öljön meg, vagy mit építsen, stb., addig nagyon lehet unatkozni a többi játékosnak...

Egyébként ajánlott beszerezni a magyar kiadást, amikor én vettem a kiegészítő is benne volt a játékban új karakterekkel és új (lila) épületekkel!

Sértődős játékosokkal nem ajánlatos játszani, nagyon rosszul érint minket is, amikor már 5 kör óta mindig rosszat tesznek velem. :D

Játszási szám: több, mint 15
Amióta megvan: 2009.tavasz

RATING: 6.5
This is a  good game. The art is very nice, and the game play is strategic enough to make it interesting. The guessing or "deductive reasoning" portion of the game is pretty fun too. The major drawbacks to this game is that the "choosing a character" phase really takes up about 2/3 of the game, and the actually playing and building up cities only takes about 1/3(obviously!!) It is very prone to analysis paralysis making this even worse. Still overall a fairly enjoyable experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
