=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
As card games go, Citadels is an excellent game of sly maneuvring, reverse psychology, opportunism and deceit. Things can get surprisingly complex for a cardgame this size: it is a good 'filler', if a little heavy at times. However, the game has a tendency to drag on, especially as the number of players rises above 4: speedy builders are delayed, character powers become repetitive. Seasoned players also begin to target 'well known' characters and follow 'well known' tactics: the merchant is surprisingly often robbed; the architect is surprisingly often stabbed. (Or vice versa.) Should the architect survive a round, his owner becomes a sitting duck for the magician, and so forth. I hadn't played the game sufficiently often to notice this at first, but of late I have. Presumably this is why the expansion was released. Machiavelli also has a sweet spot at 4 and 5 players; all other numbers don't really work or aren't as much fun.

[b]Update[/b] Sold off.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I recently purchased the English version (Citadels).  The game aside, I have a few negative comments for Fantasy Flight Games:  The box is way too big (could have been contained in one of those Kosmos 2-player style boxes) and the worst offender being there's no tray of any kind inside the box.  Despite the presence of a heap of little cardboard counters and about 80 loose cards, there's no way to organize it.  Another gripe: the card quality is really poor.  They're very thin, flat finish cards; the kind that come out of their wrapping bent and typically get worse with play. (at Bruno Faidutti's suggestion, I've already put deck protectors on the character cards)  Maybe I'm spoiled by most game companies (Rio Grande comes to mind), but this is disappointing presentation for a $20 game.  All that aside, I love the actual game.  I like the fact that there's definitely tactics and strategies, but nothing that requires eons of thinking or forward planning, especially since you never really know what character you'll be next round of play.  I took some complaints from other players to heart and earnestly looked for these flaws in practical gameplay.  Maybe I'm missing something, but many of the complaints seem unfounded to me (but then, I'm assuming there's been some rule changes between the German and English versions).  This is a superb, relatively quick card game, that actually has a certain "beer and pretzels" type feel to it.  Big thumbs up from me; I also think it's a good introduction-to-European-games game, especially with the semi-CCG looking aspect.  I LOVE the art, love the design; it's a fun game...definitely will hit the table as a light entry.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This game has gone through something of a lifecycle with our gaming.  In our initial exploration of Euro games this game got played all of the time.  It was fun and easily accessible so everyone liked it.  My then nine-year-old went from little success to absolutely kicking our butts!  The dynamic how every turn you choose (a potentially different) character was something that kept the game feeling fresh and new every hand. 

2005-09: Had to downgrade this from a nine to an eight after playing with six people (including some newby's).  Yikers!  Just poke me in the eye next time.  At least the pain would be over a lot faster.  Brutally ugly game with six.  Too much down time.

2006-05:  We haven't played Citadels in forever.  It just isn't a game that makes it to the table.  This is probably due to something of a change in the game playing dynamics at home.  Either that or this game has lost some of it's appeal due to discovering other games with a little more depth.  Whatever it is, it's rating has got to come down another notch.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is a jack-of-all-trades.  It has enough mechanical strategy to be a light gamer's game, but not enough to scare away casual or non-gamers.  This is carefully blended with a social aspect that gives it a casual, poker-like feel.  Luck can occasionally play too big a part, but there are a few ways to turn the tide on a bad hand.

The art and presentation are really nice, and the included expansion cards can do a lot to extend the replay value.  The play length is about right too, long enough to feel meaty, but without dragging on.

RATING: 6
I own it and only played it once (german version), but man, this one was a lot of fun with 5 players! The rules read more intimidating than they actually are and an experienced player can explain them very quickly to newcomers. I especially like the aspect of changing characters each round as it adds uncertainty to the gameflow. Determining the winning strategy seemed a bit too random at first, but I guess you would have to play it more often to determine successfull strategies.

RATING: 6.5
My gateway game. A good medium weight bluffing and tableau building game. Predicting the intentions of other players is a critical mechanic which lends the game far more depth than might be evident during the first few plays. It is, however, a bit too long of a game for the medium level of depth it provides.

This is designed to be a 5-8 player game, but it drags on way too long with so many players. The 2-3 player variant is far more interesting.

RATING: 5
Enjoyed this a great deal back in the day, but now find it too long for what it offers. Something very much like the role-selection / deduction portion is done in [gameid=170340], which plays faster - sadly it's not more broadly available.

[b]Old comment:[/b] Lovely game with partial-information on who's selected what role, making nailing a particular player [i]hard[/i] but not impossible. Role selection can take longer than I'd like (for myself as well as others) but the turns themselves tend to go promptly. I'm not sure I like the dynamic created by the Magician (where having a hand above one or two cards is just begging to get it stolen), it can be really frustrating being assassinated multiple turns in a row (ditto for getting final role-selection), and the Smithy district is overpowered (tweaking it to "...as your action" puts it roughly on-par with the other card-drawing purple buildings), but the game's worth playing even with these difficulties.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good party game, the hidden role card is nice and you do need a bit of strategy when picking the roles. There's a luck factor involved as the roles you need may not be available when you get to pick your identity but it can be mittigated by chosing the king and getting first pick in the next round if you really need that 1 role. 

New players seem to grasp it fast and most people I played it with enjoyed a game and had fun. It's portability is a big plus as you can easily take it with you wherever you go.

The downside is, playtime can increase greatly with a high number of players but otherwise it's a good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the games that, along with Carcassonne, got my friends to start attending my game nights regularly. We love the role mechanic, even though the Assassin can inadvertently kill the same person multiple times, but everyone has a fun time, it's a very social game. 

The game takes a bit too long for what it is, and analysis paralysis can be a problem, but I generally limit the buildings to 7 if there are a lot of players. Citadels feels completely different when there are few players, and while it's perhaps more balanced that way, I'd much rather play it with 4-6. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Just great. Simple rules, that still provide deep gameplay, interesting character-choosing idea and great art (really great!). And in addition it has pretty high interaction level, which is rather cool for me.
I really like this game and often use it to "capture" people that have never played board games :-)
My review in Russian
http://boardgaming.ru/blog/review/43.html
Upd. Nov 2014 - Mascarade has pretty much become a better replacement for me. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Citadels is a very fun game that plays relative quickly, and seems to be better with more players than less. 

After repeated plays, this game tends to really drag on way too long with too many players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Components: Great artwork on the cards. All-around good production quality except for the character cards, which need to be made of firmer stuff so as not to become marked or worn through repeated use. The most recent Fantasy Flight edition has the nice plastic gold pieces, a wooden crown, and a linen finish on all the cards.

Experience: This game fascinates me. The money/card management and district building is enough for a simple game on its own, but the character cards make the game superb. They really transform the game into a psychological battle, whereby if I can properly guess what others will take, and what others will expect me to take, and which roles others will attack regardless of who takes them, then I can make an informed choice about which character to choose. There is no certainty, of course, but it sure is fun trying to out-guess my opponents.

I've enjoyed this with 2-5 players, but find that it bogs down with more. I love it with 2 or 3, where each player gets two characters, and therefore the possibility to synergize.

The game builds very steadily. The character bonuses for the four colored districts is the only aspect that makes the game start to steamroll. I wouldn't mind if there were more powers on the district cards to increase their engine quality.

First Played: 2003-04-09
Last Played: 2014-11-21
Plays (19):
2 players: 4
3 players: 4
4 players: 7
5 players: 4

RATING: 10

RATING: 9
Bought new for $8.99.  Excellent card game for up to 8 players.  This can be a frustrating game.  I play with the expansion tokens, and sometimes with the expansion characters.  I just dumped the contents of my expansion box into my base game box.
I believe that Brent Clark owned the first copy of this game, and I subsequently bought my own copy.
I like Bruno Faidutti's games that have individual characters with different abilities.

RATING: 8
I love this game!!! 

Sudden Unexpected Victimization (SUV) stresses people. That's fun to watch. When it happens to you it allows an opportunity to show your gaming maturity and inner tranquility. 

Only Intrigue does it better.

RATING: 7
I first bought Ohne Furcht und Adel because I just loved the art. My one attempt to introduce it to casual gamer friends with the German text was a disaster but I'm glad I picked up the English version &  took it to the PutWets who proceeded to kill me off & steal all my cash (which meant they played the game as it was meant to be).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game was a 10 for me then as I overplayed it, it slipped to a 9.  Unfortunately I had a couple bad experiences which have whittled it down to an 8.  One thing is NEVER play it with 6 or more unless you have very experienced players who understand that people don't like to sit around a table and watch idiots successively stare at a slowly diminishing hand of cards.  Secondly, I'm not crazy about the endgame rule where once somebody crosses the line (gets the required number of building points) they are safe from getting buildings demolished while everyone else is still in the line of fire.  I went from first to second to last in a game because the eventual winner crossed the line and the next person to go who was out of the game, decided to torch me because I was the next in line.  (I was actually in a better position but no one knew that - I had done an excellent job of keeping my head down... well, until the last play:*)  I hate kingmaking!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
First played in a pub at a London gamers meetup while on Holiday.  Learned it fast, played it twice. ENjoyed it. Bought it when I got home.

Fun. Subtle mechanics with a light theme that can, while there is some randomness, have some deeper tactics employed.  Even the base set is fun.  The duration of the game (40 minutes or so) is about right, and it seems to avoid AP.  Fun conflict without being too direct.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
"Citadels" has a neat concept of constantly changing roles and plays quickly. It involves some strategies but mostly relies on predicting other players' moves. I don't like this aspect of the game because it quickly devolves into one of two situations: (1) a casual game where people don't deliberately try to outguess/block each other, so it's random who ends up winning; (2) a highly competitive game where people smartly gang up on the one who seems ahead, then it drags on forever. I prefer the first situation but then the outcome is somewhat unsatisfying.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
Card game in which players have to choose a character each round, and try to score points by constructing buildings. Each character has specific abilities which can be played next to the normal actions (taking money or cards, and constructing a building). Tense interactivity as murder and theft are lurking behind each and every corner. Can be quite frustrating when you're constantly victimised.

RATING: 7
Good game, work well with 6 or 7 players. The good ideas from Verrater and Meurterer are improved with citadels.

--------------
Date approximative du texte: 2002

Citadelles reprend le mécanisme de l’attribution de capacité spéciale à chaque tour par le choix d’un personnage. Ce système m’avait beaucoup plût dans les jeux de M. A. Cassola Merkle, Verrater et Meurterer.

But du jeu : marquer un maximum de point en construisant sa cité.


Préparation
Chaque joueur reçoit 4 cartes quartier, 2 pièces d’or. Un joueur est désigné au sort et reçoit la couronne. Les cartes quartiers ont un coût en pièce d’or dont il faut s’acquitter pour pouvoir les poser. Certains quartiers ont une couleur qui les rattache à un pouvoir particulier: religieux, militaire…


Le jeu (de 4 à 7 joueurs)

Les tours de jeu sont divisées en deux grandes phases:

1- Le choix des personnages
Il y a 8 cartes personnage, en fonction du nombre de joueur, un certain nombre de cartes sont retirées face visibles et faces cachées (voir tableau dans la règle)
Le joueur qui a la carte couronne prend le tas de carte choisit un personnage, et passe les personnages restants à son voisin qui en choisit également un, etc… Lorsque tout le monde a sélectionné sont personnage pour le tour la phase 2 commence.

2- le tour de jeu
Les joueurs ne jouent pas selon le sens horaire mais en fonction des personnages. Le Roi appelle les personnages dans leur ordre, d’abord l’assassin, puis le voleur etc…Lorsqu’un personnage est appelé, le jouer qui a la carte en question la montre et exécute son tour:
- il choisit entre prendre 2 pièces d’or à la banque ou de tirer 2 cartes quartier pour en choisir une et placer l’autre sous la pile.
- il peut utiliser la capacité spéciale de son action à partir de ce moment
- il peut construire un quartier dans sa cité.


Les personnages de base

1-L’assassin: annonce le personnage qui est assassiné et qui ne joue donc pas se tour ci.
2-Le voleur: annonce le personnage qui sera victime du vol. Dés que ce joueur est connu il donne sa fortune au voleur. La victime du vol ne peut être ni l’assassin ni l’assassiné.
3-Le magicien: quand il veut pendant le tour, il peut au choix échanger les cartes de sa main avec celles d’un autre joueur (cette fois c’est un joueur qui est la cible, pas un personnage), ou se défausser d’un certain nombre de carte qu’il place sous la pioche pour en repiocher le même nombre.
4-Le roi: il devient immédiatement roi et prend la carte couronne qu’il pose devant lui. C’est le roi qui choisira en premier son personnage au prochain tour.
5-L’évêque: reçoit quand il veut une pièce d’or par quartier bleu de sa cité. Il ne pas être la victime du condottiere.
6-Le marchand : Reçoit une pièce d’or au début de son tour. Reçoit également quand il veut une pièce d’or par quartier vert de sa cité.
7-L’architecte: il prend au début de son tour 2 cartes quartier. Il peut donc choisir de prendre 2 cartes plus 2 pièces d’or, ou bien 4 cartes et en défausser une. En outre il peut construire jusqu’à 3 quartier ce tour ci.
8-Le condottiere: reçoit une pièce d’or par quartier rouge de sa cité. A la fin de son tour il peut détruire un quartier (même de sa propre cité) en payant le coût du quartier –1. Il est interdit de s’attaquer à une cité terminée.


Le score
La fin du jeu intervient à la fin du tour où un des joueurs a une citadelle qui compte au moins 8 quartiers.
Les joueurs additionnent:
La valeur de tous les quartiers posés
+3 si les 5 couleurs différentes sont présentes dans le quartier.
+4 pour le premier joueur à avoir terminé sa cité.
+2 pour les autres joueurs à avoir terminé leur cité dans le même tour.


Mon opinion
D’ordinaire je suis assez sceptique face aux jeux comportant des capacités spéciales, mais ce n’est pas le cas avec Citadelles car elles sont peu nombreuses et tout le monde les connaît rapidement. La comparaison avec les jeux de M. A. Cassola Merkle est inévitable, mais Bruno Faidutti à crée un jeu bien différent. Souvent dans les jeux de société, le joueur qui est en tête est la cible d’attaques répétées, mais içi on ne s'attaque pas à un joueur mais à un personnge ce qui fait tout l'interêt de Citadelles. Nous avons à faire à un jeu de bluff où chaque joueur tente à la fois de deviner l’identité des joueurs et de se protéger de l’assassin et du voleur en évitant de faire un choix de personnage trop prévisible. Il est en effet possible de déduire pas mal de chose grâce d’une part aux cartes personnage encore disponibles quand arrive son tour et d’autre part à la structure des cités des joueurs. Un joueur avec beaucoup de quartiers bleus sera par exemple tenté de prendre l’évêque qui lui rapportera 1 pièce d’or par quartier bleu.
Citadelle à un défaut, la victoire du gagnant est parfois décidée par des éléments pas toujours contrôlables; le tirage des cartes quartier, où l'ordre des joueurs pour choisir leur personnage.
Mais dans sa catégorie de jeu léger il a des atouts: il fonctionne très bien jusqu’à sept joueurs ce qui est plutôt rare, et l'ambiance est au rendez vous pour peu que l'on ne s'attarde pas trop pendant le choix des personnages. Et la seconde edition nous offre des nouveaux personnages.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.3
A simple, though engaging strategy card game. With the intelligent addition of the dark city expansion in the basic product, great interchangablility and complexity is added to the game. You'll be eager to try out new and different combinations of characters and purple estates. 

Despite being a stand alone card game, sessions can take a while to play through, as a lot of strategy is involved, and the lead can change at the drop of a hat. Highly recommended, though not as casual a game as it may look at first.

RATING: 6

RATING: 6
Fun and simple card game that fills the "7 player" category nicely.  Players secretly draft roles such as assasin, thief, architect, merchant, warlord, etc.  Then take the action specified. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Citadels, along with Carcassonne and Puerto Rico, was a game that was suggested to me by Mr. Sam Black back in my CMG/CCG days, when I was just beginning to mull over jumping into more "serious" board gaming. 

At first it went over as well as Carcassonne did, and the girlfriend and I even enjoyed playing it two player at times. After a while however, it lost its luster a bit, and finally reached the point where I decided it was essentially not worth playing for many of the same reasons as Kung Fu Fighting. 

The chaos factor is essentially too high, particularly in games that have more than 3-4 people playing. So many bad things can happen to you based on other player's sometimes random choices that it can be almost impossible to build anything resembling a successful game strategy. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
badly designed imitates other games that are much better
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A spin off from Verraeter.  This game certainly has its fans but I can't quite admit to being one of them. It certainly is an entertaining game, where each turn you select a chararacter from a selection of eight. Each character has an ability that allows certain rules to be broken. The object is to build buildings in your play area by amassing gold. A couple of nasty characters turn this game away from being an excellent and light family game into something a bit more sinister. Worth a look, however if you're robbed or assassinated a few times, sit back and watch - you can forget about winning.

RATING: 8

There is too much sitting around with larger groups. The two player game is my favorite by far, even though my wife can read my mind. I applaud them for adding the extra characters to the basic game (instead of making it a separate expansion) which provides a lot of replayability in the card combos.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
First off - I had a very bad first (and only) experience with this game. I kind of got punked by being assassinated 3 times in a row early on. My review is despite that early setback (I came back to be on par with all the other scores except for the winner who slaughtered us all).

Moving on. I don't like this game one bit (well, except for the gold bits, those were kind of fun). We played with 7 players, and it took way too long for the turns to go around...and it happens TWICE per round. All of the interactions between roles that "balance" the game, more or less just make the game take longer without adjusting the end result by much. Many decisions are just too self-destructive to make it worthwhile interfering with other players too much (especially with that many people, you'll probably just hand the game to someone else by messing with the leader).

The lack of interaction makes the game seem longer than it actually is. Frankly, half-way through the game I thought to myself "I wish we were playing Shadows Over Camelot instead".

Normally I can see the things I "might" like in a game, or at least something the designer did well. Honestly...I didn't see much of anything in this game positively. (I had more fun joking around and discussing other topics than actually playing).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great game where you need to balance several individually simple elements into a dynamic whole.  Scales from 2-6 players pretty well.  The game is excellent with 5, 6, or 3 players, and still good with 4 or 2 (but with those numbers I'd probably play something else).  The cards in the Fantasy Flight Games edition are of disappointing quality.  The character cards especially need to be made of stronger stuff, but this is easily remedied using standard baseball card sleeves for the character cards.  I would rate this game a little higher if it wasn't so often the case that you get beaten down and there's not a thing you can do about it.  The game entices you to plan more more strategy than you are actually likely to be able to execute, and that can be a little frustrating at times..

RATING: 6
I like this game... the roles are fun and there's some good strategy. However there's WAY too much down time. Only one player can be doing something at a time, and there's relatively little player interaction. For new players, learning the rules, the time between each turn can be something like 5 minutes, and by that time phones have come out, conversations have started, etc... You really should teach in small groups. Once they know the rules turns go pretty fast.

RATING: 5
Build a medieval city while each turn taking on a different, hidden persona.  Examples include thief, assassin, merchant, priest and king.  Each with a special power and each going in a pre-determined place in the round. Great for trying to figure out who each player would pick.  Best with large numbers of players (6-8). =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Kipróbáltuk a játék 4 és 5 fős változatát. Egyenlőre az alap karakterekkel. A játékosszám növekedésével megnő a holtidő is, ha valakit ez zavar, számolni kell vele. Egyszerű szabályokkal rendelkező, egymással kiszúrós, hangulatos, kiváló kártyajáték. A sikeres játékhoz kulcskérdés a karakterek megfelelő használata. A játék egymással kiszúrós jellegére álljon itt egy jó példa. A feleségem öccse az egyik körben a tolvaj karaktert választotta titkosan. Mivel nem volt egy vasa sem, gondolta szerez a többiektől. Azonban az orgyilkos mivel féltette a pénzét kinyírta őt, mert elfelejtette, hogy a tolvaj nem lophat az orgyilkostól. A következő karakter a sorban a tolvaj, ezért a szabályok értelmében a feleségem öccse csöndben maradt. Majd következett a feleségem a mágussal. A feleségemnek csak egy értéktelen kerület lapja volt, gondolta elcseréli előnyösebbre és kérte az öccsét (a tolvajt), hogy adja át a 4 db értékes (ez később derült ki) kerület lapját. Majd miután szólították a királyt, aki ecsetelte mit szeretne végrehajtani, a feleségem öccse feladván a titkolózást, csalódottan csak ennyit mondott: "a tolvaj pedig tölt magának egy pohár bort". Hatalmas röhögésben törtünk ki, mert mindenkiben ekkor tudatosult, hogy milyen pórul járt. Se pénz, se értékes lap, se cselekvési lehetőség, gyakorlatilag kisemmiződött egy körön belül :). Bocs a hosszú történetért.

RATING: 5
I really like Citadels. It introduces people role selection mechanics before you hit them with Puerto Rico or (god help you) Twilight Imperium. The action choices are simple enough but can change your strategy. The included expansion adds a lot of new, interesting interactions to the game. Also, the money looks like Werther's Originals, which may be a bad thing if you have children. In my book, however, that's a positive.

I love this game. The artwork is fantastic, the secret role selection is perfect, and it's just great. However, this game feels like it takes just a bit too long for how much you're doing in the game. It's a light-medium game that takes as much time as a medium-medium.

UPDATE: Basically, Mascarade does everything I want with the role mechanics and then some without overstaying its welcome.

RATING: 6.3
Fun and light card game with nice character selection mechanics. The goal is to complete your city by building 8 different districts, using 1 out of 8 characters every round, each with different special powers and bonuses. And there are 2 sets of 8 characters and there are even advanced rules so it will hold up for more than a few games. 
It plays well with more than 3 people but can easily drag on way too long for a light game which makes it boring.

[b]Update:[/b] Rating dropped from 7 to 6.5 after few long boring games with large number of players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Citadels is a game about deduction and spite. It's easy to learn, and can fit up to 7 players, but remains a surprisingly long game. 

There's two main concepts going on here. There's a collection of "role" cards that are drafted each turn, and these provide each player with a unique turn order and special ability. These special abilities range from increasing your economic prowess to shutting down another player's turn. What makes it interesting is that, in many cases, the role cards that negatively impact another player require you to guess which role card they selected during the card drafting.

These role cards are used in the context of each player racing to build 8 city districts while simultaneously throwing spanners into each other's way. The winner is the player with the greatest value of city districts constructed, with some additional bonuses for finishing first or building a multicultural city.

I used to love it, but over a few plays the game length has really started to get to me. There are very few plays where it doesn't feel like it's outstayed its welcome. Also, after several plays we've decided that the way to win is never to be targeted by the assassin (lose your turn) or the thief (lose your money). The best way to do this is drafting roles that aren't useful to you, which isn't fun for an entire game.

Love Letter may have made this game redundant.

Edit 16/12/2015 - downrated to 6.5. This game is OK, but there are other games out there that do asymmetric role selection without draaaaaaaaaaaaagging on for an entire evening. One Night Werewolf being the shining example.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My group likes it more than I do, but I generally enjoy it when I play.

RATING: 7
Citadels is basically one of the best card games out there in my opinion along with Colossal Arena. With the extra characters, it makes the game different from game to game compared to playing with the same characters all the time. It adds to it's replay value.

I find Citadels to be a bit too long when playing with 7 players. I like playing Citadels until 7th building is finished instead of the normal 8. It makes the game a little bit shorter and helps move on to a different game afterward.

The Citadels expansion characters are an interesting addition to the game. I have tried a few of them and the feel of the game is different between characters.

Traded Citadels 1st edition in a three way deal. I own the 2nd edition.

RATING: 4.5

RATING: 10
I don't know what it is but this is a game that I like so much that I want to buy it again just for the pleasure of purchasing it a second time... not only that but I want to eat it!  Those butterscotch golden tokens I just want to pop in my mouth!

Why is this a 10?  Mind you, if you play this with a dry and analytic group it can be painful, but that seems to be a minority of the time for me.  Instead it just hits the sweet spot for me.  Players get unique advantages each turn, there is an element of bluffing going on in how you pick your roles, there is a building aspect to the game which can possibly gain you even more special powers with gameplay.  All of those elements are things that really excite me when it comes to games, and so dress it up with some wonderful artwork and those yummy looking gold tokens and it is just a winner for me.

Ah, I've been using the original german version all this time.  The english version does have a cheaper production value, but the german works great!

RATING: 8

Thematically the game is spot-on; you build a medieval city, become a king, merchant, general, bishop etc. and become quickly involved in medieval politics trying to outguess your friends' moves. Good times!

RATING: 6.5
This game rewards you for recognizing the progressive complexity of interaction between character cards. There is an intuitive strategy in what you choose depending on where you are in order, what you know has or hasn't been chosen, and what each other player is likely to select. That said, Citadels is not difficult to learn and can be fun without expending a great deal of brain power.

RATING: 8
Un juego INDISPENSABLE para nuestra ludoteca. Barato, original y apto para todos los niveles.Tenemos varias opciones de juego, construir barrios muy grandes o construir rápidamente barrios de menor tamaño.Es importante intentar construir un barrio de cada tipo para obtener el bonus final, los barrios "maravilla" nos podrán dar beneficios notables sobretodo si los construimos al principio. En cuanto a los personajes: hay que intentar pasar desapercibido para el asesino y el ladrón, al mismo tiempo el mercader nos permitira crecimiento rápido pero es a menudo objetivo de asesino y ladrón. El arquitecto es muy útil y nos puede permitir cerrar la partida muy rápido.
PARTIDAS:05-04-2008 Partida de ocho jugadores (Pi, Gato, Chuchi, Olga, Peto, Richi, Iuliano, Charlie "Salinas"); jugamos con los personajes "normales" más la Reina. Richi es objetivo constante de ladrón y asesino; el Rey cambiaba de mano casi cada ronda y Julio alternaba constantemente entre Condotiero y Mercader. Pi fue la primera en cerrar gracias a una doble construcción con el Arquitecto y además completó los 5 colores para sumar un total de 27 puntos; Gato (yo) construyo mi quinto distrito con 5 colores y gracias a la bonificación GANO LA PARTIDA, aunque peto me hubiera destruido con el Condotiero un distrio pero yo había cogido al Obispo  ;-)

This is easy to learn and has just enough depth to feel worthwhile.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Citadels definitely isn't a game for players with analysis paralysis, but if you can keep the pace going this is one of the best large group (5+) games out there. Secret role selection, lots of screwage, theft and conflict all combine to create a surprisingly tense card game. It doesn't usually pay to grab the role that best fits your current situation (especially if you're in the lead), since there's going to be someone that will directly target your presumed play. 

This is a game that can be a bit challenging for first-time players, and it can drag on for a bit if you don't know the abilities of the characters. In that case, downtime can be significant. But after a few rounds, the game's pace should pick up dramatically.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent role drafting. Great for building up a meta with a regular group.

RATING: 8
A card game that is basically a race to play buildings/districts worth victory points (much like San Juan), but has character roles that remain secret until they are active.  Medieval theme with lots of bluffing, can be lots of fun, and is very good for a group of up to 8 (although it perhaps gets bogged down with more than 5 players).  Role-playing and getting into character can add silliness and fun (for example, get the King to wear a crown).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Ugh, this game annoys the hell out of me! Seriously, I can't believe people enjoy sitting around a table and playing a game of "random take-that" that goes on and on and on... and on and on.  If you get assed out of a turn by the Assassin or Thief or whatever, you're looking at a good 10 minutes (8P game) without doing much at all.  And the thing is, the other player was probably not even gunning for you; you just got hit randomly.

I played Mission: Red Planet and it was the same thing. I could not figure out why I was at the table when a monkey would have the same results as a human playing that game. I guess if you want to be absolved of any responsibility for winning or losing, these types of games may appeal to you.

I can't stand Bruno Faidutti games and their chaotic, random style of "take that." Mr. Faidutti, you know what? Chicken butt.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very excellent game of bluffing and reading others. And it scales well from 2 to 8 players!

I like to play this variant: Start with the original character cards. Each round, one of the characters is not picked at the end (not counting any cards that were not used, face down in the middle before characters are picked.) This card is set aside. After the round is over, the unpicked character is replaced by its numeric equivalent that was not in play (such as trading the King for the Emperor). This give a bigger variety of characters that are in play in a given game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

+ A good game for 2-5 players and ok with more. It is a different game with 2 and 5 players, though. I enjoy both but prefer fewer players.

- Having too many players (6+) slows down the game tempo.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite games.  The more people you have to play, the better, IMO - get 8 if you can. Which is one of the great advantages of this game - that it tops out at 8 when so many other games only play 6 or 4.  So its playable for those larger game nights.  Its also a really small box, so its great for taking on trips.

Its also the most well designed, in regards to balance, game that I've ever played (not counting games like chess where you and your opponents all have the exact same pieces and moves at your disposal).

This is a must have for a game collection, in large part because its so easy to travel with and plays so many people at a time.  I often find myself at game nights where you genuinely need an 8 player game to include everyone, and there aren't that many of those.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I feel the card drafting phase can be quite boring with slow players. That subtracts a lot from a nice and simple game like this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Slim box version, with [thing=13291]Dark City[/thing] included. It's a quick game, but it feels like a "deluxe" filler. A key to doing well is to try and keep your opponents guessing as to which character you're going to take. I think I've played with every number of players up through 6 now. I'd like to try 7 and 8 each at least once, just to say I did it.

In our two-player games, we usually use the Witch instead of the Assassin (if you're "bewitched," you at least still get to take an action) and the Diplomat instead of the Warlord (destroying districts slows the game down). We're very close to making these changes in all of our games, as both the Assassin and Thief are falling out of favor in our group, even with the teenagers.  

Other than that, we switch characters in and out based on our mood, but never more than a few at a time.  The only one we're not really interested in using is the Emperor: none of us can think of a good reason to let someone else  be the king for a while, especially in a 2-player game. Also, we find the Alchemist too powerful.

I recommend laminating the character cards, or buying sleeves for them, as they take a bit of a beating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Citadels 富饒之城 2-8(6)

[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/geekbuddy.php3?action=doanalyze&groupid=4204&B1=Analyze&gameid=478]Ratings[/url]

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Pros
-Decent role taking game
-2 different roles for each number leads to good variety between games
-Fairly easy to learn and teach, good for most groups

Cons
-Very swingy/random. E.g. one of the card/roles lets you prevent a player from taking a turn, but you don't know who is who each turn.
-Very strong powers on some roles (possibly imbalanced)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fantastic gateway game with depth, though there are some fiddly rules to explain, it's repeatedly been successful due to the guessing and bluffing, and the simple, brutal interaction (assassination and theft).

I think that there are too many points in city completion and dislike how the Smithy overshadows the Observatory/Library. The the Haunted City and School of Magic are great.

I've recently noticed that the art is excellent.

Duration: Whether this is quick depends on how long people take to choose their roles. When performed swiftly this is a great game, otherwise the fun is killed.
Design: Minimalist, elegant with variable role powers balancing turn order, hidden information and very little randomness. The weakness is in the limited variety and styles game-to-game; I've played a lot of it recently and while it stands up, I'd like more variety.
Strategy: There's a lot in here, with direct aggression, deduction and guessing, but this is a tactical game.
Components: Fantastic art.
Theme: Fun, fairly abstract but still fits.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is the first and only game that we just wore the cards down to bits from playing it so much.  My introduction to modern games - a masterpiece for my biased self.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[Special Powers, Fantasy, Building] [4P:5, 5P:4, 6P:3, 7P:2.5... see a trend?] Card game where players take turns selecting a fantasy role each turn - there are 8 roles and each provides a certain power to the player that turn. Entertaining game, if a bit chaotic. Can slow down to a crawl with more than four players, but as long as players don't take more than a couple of seconds to choose a role, it shouldn't bog down too much. ***UPDATE: While a bit more "fun" than its younger distant relatives, San Juan and St. Pete, Citadels doesn't see much play unless we need a 7-player game, and even then it takes a back seat to BANG! and other lighter (and faster-playing) fare. The drafting time is almost always an issue with more than 4P, and with 4P for the same playing time, one can easily find better games. Still Faidutti's best game, and not a bad one at all, but it's far from best-in-class. *** UPDATE: Funny how a descendant of Meuterer and Verraeter turns out to not be as goood as its forebears. Unless you really need to have a fantasy-themed game of this kind, seek out the two aforementioned older games instead. Not only are they cheaper, they're better. Besides, you don't want to play Citadels with more than 4P anyway, and 4P is exactly what you need to play Verraeter and Meuterer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of the best card games I've played. It feels a bit like RftG, only toned down a bit.

Pros:
*Roll selection is a huge blast, and adds a element of deduction to the game. This is really where the game shines.
*Variable Player Powers is a huge fav of mine, and there is a wide range of rolls to choose, each with their own specific ability. You can get extra cards, blow up another players city, get extra gold and so on.
*City building theme is really fun.
*Options are never scarce, you always have to think about what you're best bet will be. 
*Deduction (already stated a bit) is key to the game. Many more times than not, your entire strategy can flourish if you know what everyone else picked.
*Cheap, small and portable.

Cons:
*Too long for what it is without some house rules. I play to 6 districts, rather than 8 (if playing with 5 or more players). 
*Black boarders on cards show any tiny fray really badly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
For some reason, I'm not as in love with the game as everyone else. The theme doesn't draw me in, and I just don't really enjoy the decisions.

Actually, I finally figured out why I don't like it: I don't like having to think that hard to avoid getting hurt or to inflict hurt so that I can have an advantage. Very tactical. 

I got it because I heard it worked well two-player. I'm sure it does for others, but not for my husband and I. Very painful to have a plan and try to execute when you've got to be attacking or attacked the whole time. I've only played it with up to 3, though so I really need to try it with more to get the real flavor of the game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
$20

RATING: 7
Una lastima haberlo quemado y que para dos no sea el mejor juego del mundo.

 Rápido, apto para incluir a no jugones, y con el punto justito de puteo que hace al juego entretenido. Ni se os ocurra jugar más de 6 a no ser que esteis todos muy comprometidos con la partida, sino tus ansias de matar se iran incrementando cada vez que ves a los juagdores (en su turno) comentando lo fantastica que fue la fiesta de ayer

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After two plays, both with six players, I must say I enjoyed the game a lot.  It was accessible two the new gamers in the group, and yet the more experienced of us had fun too.  The game was a bit chaotic, which probably worked well for the newbies.  I found there was not a lot of advanced planning possible, which evened the playing field.  I am looking forward to playing this with fewer players, to see if it is truly more tactical as is said.

This game will have a particular place in my collection.  Like Carcassonne, this game covers a wide range of players, is very accessible, and fun.  Unlike Carc, it travels in a little package.  It will probably get called on a lot, even when I don’t personally feel like playing it, which won’t be often.

I rated this as a provisional "7", which I suspect may go up with more plays.

PS - Just to be clear, I have the second edition, with the Dark City characters, but no additional districts.
---------------------------------
Update:

Better with five players.  This is an excellent game.
---------------------------------
Update (3/21/2011):

There are better games to play with 3-4, and it's a little long for more, with too much downtime.  Moving my rating to a "6".

RATING: 7
[b]Duration:- [/b]:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:  [i]Relies upon a set number of builds, so can outstay its welcome; soldier actions can extend play, but generally not too far.[/i]
[b]Engagement:- [/b]:star::star::star::star::nostar:  [i]Quite engaging; character actions frequently involve other players.[/i] 
[b]Experience:- [/b]:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:  [i]A great combination of bluff, suspense and competition; however, often reliant on a lucky card draw.[/i]
[b]Presentation:- [/b]:star::star::star::star::nostar:  [i]Great art, good quality components.[/i]

A brilliant multiplayer game; we tend not to play with fewer than 6 and don't see a problem with the King not changing hands.  This happened (once again) to me in my last game for most of the first half; I won the game.

My most recent play was with the English edition, the Witch and the Tax Collector substituting the Assassin and the Thief respectively, and the Queen added in for a 6-player game.  It seemed much better playing with alternate characters, as the choices were more difficult to make, nobody was completely losing their turn by assassination and without the thief there was more gold in circulation.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorites, for sure.  I only like to play it with 4 or more players (there are rules for fewer, but it doesn't have the same feel).  Every round is intense, as you worry if you are going to be killed or robbed from, or if the person you are trying to kill or rob eludes you.  AND, you need to be making money and building structures at the same time.  Classic Bruno Faidutti -- VERY limited resources, painful choices to make, very exciting and intense.  (With 2 or 3 players, the game rates about a 6... 4 to 7 players, and the right crowd -- perfect 10.)

RATING: 8.4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm very fond of this game. It was one of the first games that I bought when I got into this hobby.

It's easy to teach and quite accessible.The hidden role selection is cool and in smaller groups can lead to some fun bluffing and clever deduction.

I enjoy this as a 2 player game a lot. With 3-5 as well. With larger groups it can seem a bit random at times and is nowhere near as tense as the smaller games. But then, I just look at it as a bit of a party game. It's just good fun.

Occasionally in the larger groups it can overstay it's welcome but its a great game to own as it's so versatile. There aren't many games that can play 2-8 and are as accessible. All in such a little, easily transportable box.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Pretty cool, pretty funny, pretty clever, very cheap, plus: easy to teach and to learn, what else could you ask for?
Each round, each player takes a different role from the ones available (murderer, thief, mage, king, bishop, merchant, arquitect or condottiere).
Belive me when I tell you there are just a few games that provides so much entretainment as this one does! The intrigue of not knowing who's gonna kill you... The emotion of discover the thief's plans... The crappy you feel when the condottiere destroys that violet-special building that you love the most in your district... (!)
And for the price, you won't get anything better arround there.
Note: I have the 9 extra characters from [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/13291/citadels-the-dark-city-expansion]Citadels: The Dark City Expansion[/url]

RATING: 9
PROS:
-Las habilidades de cada personaje en relación a su número están muy bien calculados
-A 2-3 jugadores es un juego muy psicológico y de faroleo
-La expansión Ciudadela Oscura y sus personajes nuevos permiten una combinación de habilidades que cambia la forma de jugar
-Amplio rango de jugadores (2-8)
-Se aprende a jugar enseguida
-Las habilidades psicológicas superan a la experiencia en el juego


CONTRAS:
-Hasta haber jugado un par de turnos no se entienden bien las mecánicas, ya que algunos aspectos como el orden de turno son diferentes a los más habituales
-A más de 4 jugadores se vuelve un juego muy azaroso
-El dorso negro de las cartas hace imprescindible enfundarlas para evitar identificarlas a través de pequeños arañazos o marcas

RATING: 7

Then we played with four--now I understand why others consider this such a good game.  Scores were close even though everyone was trying different strategies, and the interaction with four players and the potential characters really made this sing.

Great game, look forward to playing again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Citadels is a really neat card game.  I love the idea of choosing roles to aid your gameplay (a la San Juan), but Citadels is even simpler and even a first-time player will feel like they know what they have to do.  Because only one player can use a role at one time, and some roles affect others, this game feels very interactive.  As well, The cards are magnificently illustrated.  Gameplay is quick but surprisingly deep and this can be a great game as a filler, main play, or beer 'n pretzels.  It really shines as a 4-player game, but just passes as a 2-player game (where choosing two roles per turn doesn't feel as crucial.) 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
[b]Recommended player count: 2-6[/b]

When playing with 3 players, ensure you add an extra character to the card draft to avoid any certain knowledge of which player picked which card.

Game goes on too long with more than 6 players in my opinion.

[b]Why I got rid of it:[/b]

Slightly too complex and plays too long for what it is. Has been superseded by better games since.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Citadels can offer a wonderful variable player power system.  What is basically a city building card game with a similar building mechanic and end game condition as San Juan, Citadels' many character offerings provide a much different approach to reaching the winning conditions.  Although I find San Juan to be the more structurally sound of these two, Citadels with its ability to scale to a larger group, and its stronger player interaction offers the more 'fun' experience. The depth of the game however sometimes leaves a game feeling empty, and an ill-fated card draw can hinder. However, the latter is often remedied by savy character selection and play.  

Update:  I have found Citadels to drag on many occasions, and loses the luster of its inital charm.  I still enjoy the occasional play but it's not a frequent visit.

RATING: 4
I found this game decidedly mediocre. With a large number of players, it suffers from gameplay time - the turns don't go quickly enough for 7 or 8 players to go around, there's a lot of downtime. With a small number of players, it suffers from imbalance - with only a few players, cards like thief or assassin become trivial to target. 

That said, it is a game that rewards guessing/predicting what the opponent is going to do next immensely, so if that is your favorite thing to do in a game, Citadels will be ok for that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Some luck, but not too much, lots of player interaction, relativly simple, short card game.  High "take that!" factor.  Enjoyable game, but is is probably a bit to chaotic for me.  The last time we played, we used alternative characters: the Witch and The Tax Collector and it really added a lot to the game.  Be sure and reduce the required number of buildings for victory to 7 from 8 if you are playing with more than 5 players.  With more than 5, the game is long for what it is and in my book doesn't highly.  Check out my "Definitive" 2-player variant posted in the forum... With the variant it is a very good 2-player game.  A similar variant is also necessary for the 3-player game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is one of those rare games that is good both with two players and with many players.  The mechanics of the game change slightly between games with 2 or 3 players and those with 4 or more.  As a result, both are very interesting games to play and I'm looking forward to many more plays of this.

One thing about this game though, the time to play seems to be directly related to the number of players in the game.  A two player game only takes 20 minutes or so, but a seven player game easily takes over an hour.  In fact, 10 minutes per player is probably a good rule of thumb, longer if just learning the game.

Edit: This was one of the first "modern" board games I played. I still enjoy it, but not quite as much as I did six years ago. Lowering the rating just a bit to reflect that.

RATING: 5
I've played one and only one game of this, but I feel I can rate this because I had the worst possible experience of the game.  I started last in turn order in a 5 player game, and had my gold stolen each of the first 4 turns, and 5 of the first 6.  It was incredibly frustrating.  Because the game is so affected by turn order, I can only give this a mediocre rating.

I think I'm ready to give this game another chance.

Ok, I've given it another chance with four players.  It wasn't as bad as I remember.  It was fun, but I enjoyed it mainly because I played with three people I know well.  The psychological screwage that goes into choosing roles was fun.

I can't believe this, but my rating for Citadels has climbed over the past year from 3 to 6.

Played a few more games including once with 3 players.  It was awful for 3.

RATING: 6.7
Easy to pick up and fun. Best of all it can be wrapped up in a relatively short time. For us the end of the game is often not close. There is a "pick on/revenge" factor that can get out of hand with siblings and tends to take the kids out of the game making them more concerned about each other.  My understanding the term for this is metagaming, probably not the fault of the game.
  Haven't been able to convince the family to play this over the past year.   Perhaps playing with new people is the key to this game, once you have become familiar with your regular opponents.

RATING: 10
Received from BGG Secret Santa, December 2008

May 2009 -- This game has quickly become one that we choose to play often. We have not yet used the Dark City expansion cards included with the game, but are enjoying the basic cards very much.

October 2009 -- We have begun using the Witch and Tax Collector in all our games, and will soon try some of the other Dark City cards, which look very interesting.

January 2010 -- We have played with some of the Dark City cards and like the ones we have tried.

October 2011 -- We still play with the Witch, Tax Collector, and Abbott cards, as substitutes for their original counterparts. We have not experimented with the other Dark City characters, but we do mix in different purple cards for variety. It is a fun game for us.

November 2012 -- Our adult daughter doesn't care much for this game, but since the rest of us do, she is willing to play it occasionally. I prefer playing it with 5 or 6 players, and that's our usual group.

2013-November:  Played this recently and still find it to be a fun game.

RATING: 8
I really enjoy this game *if* players remember to choose quickly.  It's always slow for the new player who is trying to remember who does what, but it should go smoothly by the second game.  Fun psychology, though.

The sweet spot is 4P for me.  The assassin and thief seem like a less sure thing.  It's also good with 3, each player taking two roles, or with 5.  For 5 or 6 players, only build to 7 districts to keep the game length reasonable.

I never hate having played a session but I never ask for it either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
If you manage to play this game in under an hour without sacrificing the bluffing, double-think and general getting into each others brains. Then this is an excellent and devious little game and deserves a rating of 7-8 . My rating is lower because I have been burned out on the game after playing a number of not so exciting game sessions.
The game plays best with 4 players. with less players you each get multiple roles which I find not as interesting. And with more players the chance you have of figuring out what roles your opponents have chosen decreases dramatically. Which again makes the game less interesting.

Rated 8 After 2 Plays:

I really enjoy this one. Our first plays went rather slowly as everyone tried to learn the game but I can definitely see this one speeding along after more plays. I love the tension of choosing your role and trying to figure out what everyone else has chosen or will choose after you. 
A game where you get to murder, steal and break stuff is a winner in my book.

Rated 5 After 10 plays:

Unfortunately the game has up to this point always taken longer than it should for the amount of fun it provides. I've played a number of games with a few very AP-prone players, where it seemed like the game would never end. The problem here is that the whole double-think role-choosing mechanism can trigger an infinite loop of "I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me..." in your most AP afflicted players. A game can easily drag on for 2-3 hours, which is at least an hour too long for me. 
Another problem is the warlord card. Yes it can be great going around knocking your opponents buildings down, but it really only helps the people not involved. And again it makes the game longer than it has to be.
I'm going to try it again with some of the alternative character cards to increase money flow and remove the possibility of razing buildings to see if that can speed things up a little.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Don't know which game to play? Play Citadels!

RATING: 8
machiavelli
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I would like the Citadels mechanism, if there was a game to back it.

The core of the game is hidden role selection, yet beside it there is very little you can do to play satisfyingly.
Moreover, the game is prone to be determined by a big mistake of one player who, trying to target one opponent, ends up screwing both his own game and a random other's.

Finally, a lot of time is spent trying to convince other players to do what you think is suitable and appropriate, in order to avoid to be hit by the aforementioned random screwage effect!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3

I reality it turnst out to be just very frustrating and random.The truth is you have very little control because others players' choises can give you no chance to do anything. In my last play during the first 4 rounds I was robbed 3 times and one my building was destroyed. So I was just drifting towards the end of the game, watching others getting stronger and stronger. No fun, just sheer frustriation.

RATING: 5
There are far too few interesting choices in this game. Either you pick the character that benefits you the most or you don't because you're afraid of the assassin or the thief. It's kind of interesting to be the assassin or the thief, but it doesn't necessarily help you so why would you choose them over other options? The districts are all pretty much the same which is also boring. It can be fun when the assassin or thief misses, but it's equally as unfun when they always accidentally hit the same player.

RATING: 7

As a plus, it's fantasy themed, allowing you to get the family into heavier, fantasy games quicker.

The secret roles are what really make this one shine. It's a good one for just about any number of players. Even the two player, 'double role' works out great.

As far as card games go, this one is top drawer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Most replayability of any game. This game is best played with a rule that permits negotiation during the character selection round. No player may reveal the cards they are holding or the card that they have selected, but they may make any claims they wish about the cards they are holding or the card they selected. This can become quite nasty. Limit wine consumption and don't assasinate the same person too many times in a row, if possible. Don't sit to the right of a player who likes to choose the King.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Our group liked this one, but weren't thrilled by it.  We'll probably play it if we want a light game that we can play quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Provides a very different experience with two, with three, or with four or five players.  Not recommended for more than five players, and you should consider requiring one fewer district when playing with more than three players. The game is only fun when played *quickly* - this is not chess, after all.

The three-player version suffers a bit from one quirk.  Each round, every player will know with 100% certainty that two specific characters were chosen by someone else.  Consequently, the assassin and the thief become a bit too powerful with three players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.5
The character distribution system is the best thing about this game, the building phase is rather simple and unremarkable. The problem is that with more than four people it becomes really tedious, you have to wait until everybody has chosen a character and then finally start the round. There are better, faster games for 6-7 people, such as 7 Wonders (more complex) or Between two cities (a light game like Citadels).

RATING: 7.5
We always play with The Dark City Expansion,mixing in any number of characters up to nine. It took a while for the rest of the family to warm to this one. But now, its a firm favourite. We all like doing the devious cloak and dagger stuff. Trouble is, the tit for tat can get a little annoying. 
But then there's nothing like pulling off a key bluff, and ending up with somebody else's loot, only to get assassinated next round. We play this with four usually, in under an hour.
But if we don't play for a while(3 months of more), forgetfullness can play a major part in slowing things down!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I loved it for a few years, then I noticed that many times when I played, that luck was wiping me out no matter what I did, then I started really hating it and the last 5 times I played, I got assassinated at least 3 times per game (4 out of those 5 games), which meant I had zero chance to win. When you know that you have zero chance to catch back up, and still have to play for another hour anyway, it becomes very grueling.

I finally sold my copy and don't ever need to play this again.

And yes I tried the variant assassin (witch) and folks at the table were not a big fan of her. Whoever went first - seemed like they would be stupid NOT to choose her, so she was kind of an auto-choice, which they didn't like.

In that game (with another player's copy) I chose my roles randomly and while I didn't win, at least I didn't lose as badly as I usually do when I get assassinated or stolen from a dis-proportionate amount of times, so the experience was only bad instead of awful.

Cards. Pick a role (like San Juan) to build cities.

K-Rated: 6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
Bruno Faidutti has come up with a slew of games that utilize a single mechanic - hidden identities. 
Citadels was his first, and I might argue, his best. The game is a little too long, but there are ways to shorten it up, especially when you have up to 8 players. Even though his more recent Masquerade is the best hidden identity party game EVER, I keep coming back to Citadels for it's compelling strategy and knife-in-the-back game play. It's almost like Dominion in it's simplicity, but so much more fun because of it's "gotcha" secret identity mechanic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Wonderful card game.  The role choosing dynamic works perfectly.  The fact that it can be played with a varying amount of players is a huge plus.

RATING: 6
Menacingly fun game with heavy interaction. Have not enjoyed 2 and 3 player games but great for groups. I have to force myself to enjoy the experience of Citadels and not be too concerned with victory. That DOES NOT mean there is excessive luck involved OR that there is no strategy (i.e. choosing cards is never random). I have never thought so intently as when choosing a character in an intense game of Citadels. However, the chaos of this game is soooo high. Nothing can save you from being killed 17 times or having the Warlord (played by the loosing player) dump all of his or her gold into taking you out because you are in the lead (while the Bishop sits face up, discarded, on the table).

I have a hard time accepting that the second place person wins more often than the leader. Can't seem to work this into my strategy. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
There is a lot of interaction, but it doesn’t seem to have the same take that mentality like many other games of this type. Instead the hidden roles make you think twice where the cards have been lost in the mix. I really like this deduction aspect of the game along with the different roles players can take. It’s simple to play but the thought aspect of the game doesn’t make the simple to decide. Should I take the most beneficial or trying to avoid conflicts? In the end I go by gut feeling, but it isn’t trivial.

I like to play with slightly different characters since the FFG version includes the Dark City expansion. I am not entirely fond of the Warlord from the basic game, since it makes the game longer and small buildings not a viable strategy. Sometimes I play to one less district than in the original rules for a slightly shorter game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Drags with too many players but with 2-3 it's fantastic! Having two characters a turn really speeds things up. Lots of player interaction, bluffing and deduction.

RATING: 8
Love it. A good mix of simplicity and depth (choosing characters is really the only thing that slows things down, and it's not too bad). It's basically a game of bluff, and second-guessing your opponents, with hilariously disastrous consequences.

I do think the three-player game is horrible, though (too many characters in play, spread between too few players, making the use of Thief/Assassin overpowered as tools to nobble your opponents as with so many characters in play, they nearly always find a target).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Pure annoyance in card form. No interesting decisions to make as far as how to spend whatever meager gold you manage to scrape together before someone steals it. Most every building power is boring so the tableau you're building isn't interesting at all. The most celebrated part of the game -- the role selection -- far from being tense and psychological as some Citadel fans claim, is just a glorified game of rock-paper-scissors. On top of all this, there's a huge runaway leader problem, and you can't cycle cards quickly, so one bad draw can easily knock you out of the game. There's barely a game here, and what game there is sucks balls.

Alapmű a gyűjteményemben!
Nagy dobozban szép tartalom (bár kisebben is elférne). Nagyon tetszik a kártyák grafikája.

RATING: 5.5
One of the better (small) games that can handle a bigger group of players. This is a nasty little game that can and will screw you one or more times, which can be frustrating.

There can be rounds, where you don't participate due to the assassin, or where you lose all your gold or cards. There's no real balance here, just a nasty bluffing game.

Having that said, I dislike games, where you can lose full rounds and I also dislike most bluffing games, which puts this one onto the trade pile.

Great for it's time and for bigger groups, but nothing I enjoy much.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is by far the most popular game in my circle of (non-serious gamer) friends.

I attribute its apparent popularity in Singapore to its closeness to Bridge, which is gaining popularity in Singapore. Like Bridge, part of the fun of Citadels is guessing the other players' roles. This is the most exciting element in the game for me. To me, nothing is more thrilling than correctly guessing what someone else.

It's proven to be a great gateway so far. Most of my friends love this game (it's even my class favourite). I am yet to get all these Citadels people hooked on some other games I play.

What I like:
As aforementioned, the system of different characters, especially trying to guess choices
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like this game.  It is sort of an interactive version of san juan with fewer, less meaty, but more interesting decisions.  If you liked the idea of san juan but didn't like the game because it had little interaction and no screw-you factor, Citadels is the game for you.  The assassin and thief are obnoxious if you are playing with people that aren't using them to bash the leaders/strong characters but instead just randomly hitting people for no reason.  The double-bluffing and deduction are pretty awesome and the alternate characters are pretty cool, though I wouldn't use them all.  I'd definitely just throw in a few now and then to mix it up.  Same with the alternate buildings.  This is a great game that can be easily sped up by playing to 6 or 7 buildings instead of 8.  My rating could easily go up with more playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice outsmarting/secondguessing game with secret role selecting from common pool of roles. Theme is medieval city developing, so you can choose roles of: merchant, assassin, bishop, thief and so on. Good light social game with nice tension and opportunities to stab other players.

RATING: 8
This is one of those games I enjoy but tend to do poorly at. I like how the game changes based on player numbers, which keeps it fresh. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It can suffer a bit from the "player on my left doesn't know what he is doing" syndrome. In general though, this game has been beautifully balanced and a great test of psychology. Luck is generally pretty minimal and you have some control over how much luck there is. This would rate about an 7 except for one thing. I give the two or three player game a 8. Getting to take two roles and only having to think about what one or two other players are doing turns this into a serious thinking game. If this was ONLY a two-player game it would still rock. The fact that it scales, and scales well, to 7 or even 8 people is just gravy. After more plays, the viciousness has become a bit more aparent than it was at the first. Getting assasinated and losing your entire round makes this only suitable for more than 3 players with the right crowd.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Although this is arguably the granddaddy of the whole role selection genre, it's feeling a little long in the tooth now. Can suffer from large amounts of downtime and the game claiming to support 6-8 players is more of a detriment than a benefit. At high player counts there is a *lot* of downtime and the amount of control anyone really has plummets quite greatly. Still decent with 4-5, but there are so many games for that player count that take about the same amount of time as this that I'm not sure I'd really pick it anymore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
An instant classic reading game. by reading, I mean reading your opponent.

Of the 8 Character cards, it's important to choose wisely, and to try and guess which one the other players have. In an 8 player game, this would be easy since everybody will have one card, but this gets more difficult with less players.

In a 2 and 3 player game, you take two cards each, which might make some things easier, but certainly hurries the game long as each player will get two turns!

Fun, well made, and easy to pick up!

RATING: 7
[Initial Impression: 7] A fun little card game with hidden roles and the accompanying double-bluffing, although we usually play to a lower number of districts built for a shorter game.  I've seen games in which one player keeps getting killed or stolen from throughout the game, and they just don't have any fun. (Obvious Hints: Don't choose the merchant or architect a lot, and don't take the role for which you've already built a lot of districts. If all else fails, take the assassin or thief as your own role!) But I like this game quite a bit - it's especially good with non-gamers, and it is fun to watch (and engage in) the out-guessing that the game encourages.

RATING: 7
A game of gaining trust or betraying one another depends how you play the game !

Players pick a role and gain character's special abilities. The abilities may be stealing other player's gold, swapping building cards, killing another player and that person skip his or her turn, be the king, etc.

A very interesting party game and recommended for party of 6-8.

RATING: 8
2-21-10
Lowered from a 9 to an 8 as I haven't played this in almost a year.  The member of our game group who comes up once every month or two doesn't bring it anymore.  I also don't know if it's worth buying for me since I have a bunch of other light games now that are just as fun.  Below comments still apply.

I see this game as sort of a Race for the Galaxy-lite version.  I played RftG before this, and while friends were saying RftG was super-fun, I still haven't found what they find in that game.  This game though, definitely is fun.  Easy to pick up, but has some depth to master.  Each round is different, much less each whole game.  Especially when you play with different groups of people who are more/less hostile.  It's a game I wouldn't turn down a play for.  It may lack a little depth, but I think the gameplay more than makes up for that.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
“Lands, titles, men, power, nothing.” - Robert the Bruce

GAMEPLAY
Players build their cities up to eight districts. Every turn each player chooses one of eight roles. All roles, all secret until played, give the player a special ability from gaining extra gold for having districts of certain colors, choosing a role first next turn, destroying someone else’s district, or building multiple districts. On the turn the first player gets to eight districts finish the turn and count points to determine a winner.
COMPONENTS
The box is small and the pieces consist of two decks of cards (roles and buildings), gold tokens, and a king token. The art is a generic fantasy setting but bright and crisp and very well done.
THEME
The city building is secondary to the role selection process. The gotcha gameplay is well related to each of the roles. Some roles promote winning and some negatively impact the other players.
WHO IS IT FOR?
This game is simple to learn but there is a great deal of bluffing and deduction. The replay-ability comes from your group how well can you predict their actions and bluff your own? There isn’t back stabbing because there are no long term strategies. Knowing the others who play or guessing their tendencies is where the fun is. A great game for a group to warm up a game session. Players 10 and up will enjoy the game, it takes about an hour to play. It plays 2 to 8 players, try playing with 2 or 3, each player gets two roles, changing the dynamic great fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I imagine my rating is artifically low.  I only played once, with seven players, one of whom was obnoxious as hell.  So I imagine it&#039;s actually a better game than that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game goes relatively fast with experienced players, but with AP, a seven or eight player game can be unbearable with substantial down time between turns, and waiting for the character cards to come to you. I've played it with 3 or 4, where you get two characters, which can be great fun. Rating: '8'.

Update (06/25/09): Played a 5P game, with one newbie. Relatively painless. Note to self--next time, make sure to sleeve all the cards!!! The role cards wear out pretty quickly.

Update (08/01/09) 4 plays: I'm beginning to get annoyed with this game, as it seems to be too chaotic for my tastes. The assassin and thief can be useful, but they can also be totally unpredictable. The merchant is logically the one who gets killed the first round (usually, so now we all avoid it like the plague), due to its lucrative powers, but what is it with the architect getting killed instead? There seems to be several layers of meta games developing here. Those that get assassinated early on, or stolen from, don't necessarily seem to recover with respect to the rest. Is that me, or is it generally true?

Update (02/10/13) 6 plays: Not much movement in nearly five years of ownership. Hidden role-selection is still novel, but getting randomly killed is infuriatingly frustrating. The game would be awesome with 7 experienced players, but the thought of excruciating downtime kills the thought. No one wants to play this. No one. Downing to a '6'.

RATING: 8
Portable, elegant, inexpensive & excellent themed artwork. Considerable player interaction with short-term bluffing / guessing attempts. Some of the character cards are nasty because they can significantly hamper opponents thus bluffing is a necessity. Yet the game rounds are fast and with ample opportunity for payback. This keeps each round tense because offense-defense exchanges occur so frequently.

RATING: 4
2-7 (or even 8) players.  Works best with more players.  The bluffing & deduction are excellent.  We usually end up playing it in a similar way to the way we play Risk - always trying to tell other players who the "real threat" is & get other players to try to stop them while each trying to sneak ahead ourselves.  When 7 or 8 players are doing this at once it becomes very interesting.

However, the game takes a bit too long & can't really hold my interest.

Overall my opinion has deteriorated with time, there's just a bit too much luck and chaos for the playing time, more recent light games like Blueprints are much quicker.
