RATING: 6
Muy buen juego si es a partir de 4 jugadores. Se organiza en un momento y las partidas no duran mucho, además las reglas son sencillas. Alta interaccion y mucho puteo. Imprescindible tenerlo en cualquier ludoteca, aunque ahora lo tengo bastante "quemado". Contras: elevado tiempo de espera, frustrante y caótico. ¿Tienes muchas cartas? El mago te las cambiará. ¿Tienes mucho oro? El ladrón te robará. ¿Muchas cartas construidas? Te las destruirán. ¿Eres el último en elegir? Seguro que te matarán porque habrás elegido el arquitecto o el mercader. Llevo un año sin jugar a él y no lo echo de menos. Si quiero jugar a putear me pongo con Junta o Juego de Tronos... por eso baja de 7.4 a 6 en Enero de 2010

RATING: 4
Liked this one the first time I played it, but every game since then has been less and less enjoyable.  The role-choosing mechanic is clever and nicely implemented, but there is way too much down time when everyone is choosing their roles and the game really drags after the first hour or so.  Maybe with the right people the gameplay would move more quickly (every game I've played has had at least one first-time player in it).  I think decreasing the number of cities to trigger the end of the game would add a little more excitement - as it is, I think 8 is too many.

RATING: 9
A tableau game with unique player powers that change each round, Citadels forces players to read their opponents and form strategies that indirectly rely on opponents' secret power choices. It's not too long where a misplay or a loss is very bothersome, but is is lengthy and deep enough for choices - good or bad - to have some teeth. A great game for friends who know each other and aren't afraid to get in character with the differing roles and beautiful artwork.

RATING: 8

RATING: 7
(note: so far my rating and comments are based on games of the 2-player or (modified) 3 player variant)  

This game has almost all of the qualities that I am looking for when playing a "lighter" game.  1) It is of fitting length for its depth. (if not played with too many people) 2) It has an engaging theme. 3) The luck is manageable (luck in drawing hand card can be counterbalanced by proper role-choice) 

In addition to these favorable characteristics, the game contains a large element of bluff and counterbluff which creates a wonderful experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
City building:role selection:bluffing
variable player powers:screwage

Rules read so far, looks a lot lighter than I expected which will be bad for me, looks like a filler type game worthy of an 8 rating or so...

Update: Well after one play, this really lacks any kind of depth and substance which I didn't see coming, a neat little role selection game that provides some fun but quite light for my tastes. Like a lot of games, I think it will be slightly more fun with more than 2 players but it lacks options, you choose a role, you build if you can, and you take a stab at someone if you can. That wouldn't be so bad but the building aspect of it really lacks here and it isn't enough to keep it interesting...will be played as an occasional filler for now and change rating if needed with more plays and players...Rating could edge up a bit...

Update: Although I am not raising the rating I have come to appreciate this game and lighter games in general(great for weeknights). I'm not sure this would ever be suggested with 4 players as there are so many good games for that number, but maybe 6 or 7. We are currently playing it with just the wife and I and I'm enjoying it more and more. We also noticed that some of the buildings have special powers also which makes it more interesting and we haven't even added in the expansion yet(got FFG version). I really like the different roles and trying the guess which roles your opponent is choosing so you can screw him/her or avoid getting screwed. Fun little game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I bought the German version because, at the time, I thought there would never be an English version.  I put on English stickers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this card game, players select a hidden role that specifies their turn order and confers a unique ability.  Identifying who has what role (and disguising your own) is often a big part of the game. The roles can be partially deduced, but usually you have to rely on a little psychology.  This can be a lot of fun.  The rest of the game--building buildings to score points--is simple and a little vanilla.  This is not necessarily a bad thing because it allows you more time to worry about whether the thief or assassin is going to get you.  Scales well to six players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One day I will formally decide whether I love or hate this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A fairly light game.  Each turn every player chooses role that provides certain advantages.  They then play cards representing different parts of a city that they are building.  Most have no function except having a color that corresponds to some of the roles.  The game ends at a certain number of cards and the most card points wins.  Most of the interest in the game comes from trying to guess who is choosing which role.  For example, one is the Thief which lets you steal money but you need to name your target role before you know who they will be so if you're targeting a guy with a lot of bucks, you have to guess which role they will be choosing.  If you think someone will try to demolish part of your city as Warlord, you might choose to be Priest to be safe.  Solid concept but in practice lacks interesting tension and strategy.  Somehow there isn't the sense for me that it actually makes that much difference which role I choose or that which roles others choose makes that much difference to me.  And the city cards are mostly pretty uninteresting or just worth points.  Still, not without enjoyment and pretty quick.  Sort of like junk food.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Recipie: Take San Juan.  Subtract two parts long term strategy.  Add two parts backstabbing chaos.  Add one part poker-like bluffing and mind tricks.  Shake well.  Drink.  Smile.

We play two players.  Your chaos mileage may vary.  

Update: played this with three players last night, and it was great fun.  Bump it up half a point if you're playing a) with three or four people, who b) don't take themselves too seriously, and c) love backstabbing and trash talking.

Update II: had a rough seven player outing of this.  Took WAY too long, and was a three horse race about an hour in.  Dropping this a half point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
There are two major issues with Citadels. The first is the way that certain roles can be too aggressive. It goes beyond "that player nudged me out of first" and into "I can't win but the game is far from over" territory. The second is that the process of selecting roles is flawed. There is often not enough information to make an educated decision. This slows the game down, especially for new players who are not familiar with the roles and think each decision can be "figured out."

With two or three players, these problems are minimal. Selecting two roles means that every turn will see each player at least making some progress. Seeing the hand of roles multiple also makes role selection much more intriguing and tactical.

With four players, the aforementioned problems start to reveal themselves. With five players (or several new players), the game is one of the most unpleasant game experiences I've ever had. Such games can drag on well past an hour and mostly consist of waiting on players to choose a role and hoping one doesn't become a random victim too many times, making it impossible to win.

I'd give it a six for less than four and move it closer to a two as the player count goes up and the experience level of the players decreases - so I'll average it out and give it a four.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
2014-10-07

Initial Rating: 7.0 (June 2010)

Citadels was one of the first games I ever tried, Still I remember I never wanted to play the game very often. I’m not sure why because it is a fun game. Easy to play and teach. I prefer to play it with 5 or fewer players, with more, the downtime, playtime and uncontrollable luck increase a lot.

Nowadays, I almost never want to play it, I love hidden roles games but there are a lot of better options. The playtime is high for such a simple/light game. Also it has a lot of “take that”, a mechanism I almost never enjoy. The game gets old quickly so it has a low replay value for me.

Bottom line, Citadels is an ok game for me now. I don’t particularly want to play it, but will do if requested. It has way too much chaos/uncontrolled luck and the playtime can exceed the one hour mark. I downgraded its rating so it matches my feelings for the game with the BGG recommended rating system.

Current Rating: 5.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

---------------------------------
This game has become one of our regulars. Rating stands.
---------------------------------
After 1 play: For a purpose-built themed deck of cards, this game actually works pretty well. The role-drafting feels like a significant decision point where the consequences of the roles have clear impact on the immediate development of the game (unlike my feeling of Puerto Rico). Balance is good, player interaction is present and direct but not overwhelming. Play is simple and was quickly explained. The game would benefit from a second set of role cards to have face up for newbie reference.

RATING: 5
I hate, hate, HATE the lose-a-turn mechanic in games.  Some games are fun to watch, but only if I don't expect to be one of the players.

I will actively avoid any game that features the loss of turns so prominently, because if I want to be doing nothing, I have many perfectly good ways of doing so without wasting my limited gaming time to do it.

Other than the potential lost turns, there are many elements to like about the game, such as the unique aspects of some of the other roles; too bad the fun ones get cancelled too often to really make an impact on the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Clever mechanics put the emphasis on judgement, probability and bluff, rather than analysis to the nth degree - which puts it up my street!

Most significant decision is which character to play each turn. Get this right, and you can make real progress. get it wrong......

Because of this, only real drawback is amount of time players take to choose their character each turn - character choice can often take far longer than actual play.

It's worth it though, as it's full of suspense and surprise. It's a looker, too - the card artwork is exceptional.

Update Dec 2006: I've been playing this (a lot) for over 3 years now and have yet to tire of it. He's released other great games I've enjoyed since (Boomtown, Mission Red Planet) but this is still my favourite Faidutti (and one of my favourite game). Hence, updated to a 10.

Update Jul 2010: finally getting to the point where I've just about played it enough, but that took 10 years!

Kari's Copy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
First STOP comparing this game to PR.  Any similarities to the role-choice mechanic between the two games is purely superficial.  In addition to the private nature of the choice, there is the more important idea that only one person performs each role per round.  Also, the number of real choices is more limited.  Regardless of your role, there are only four possible things you can do:  increase your income, increase your building possibilities, thwart an opponent, or go first in the next round.  The meaningful choices in Peurto Rico are more varied, and more difficult.
More importantly, though, unlike PR, where the person choosing roles first rotates in a predictable way, in Citadels it is possible to play the entire game and _never_ have the opportunity to choose roles first.  (In fact, this happened to me in the aborted game mentioned above.)  While there are certainly ways to win in these circumstances (I was winning the game above), it does make the game feel chaotic.
Overall, a playable game, but it will never be more than "light" game fare for me.

Update - 7/3/05:  Finally played this game FTF, this time with 6.  This is a very chaotic game, requiring more tactical skill than strategic.  It is impossible to control what roles will be available to you unless you first take the king.  And it is possible to never get that chance.

Final update: 9/6/05 - This game is too long.  It is completely chaotic (don't believe me?  Then explain why the last winner at our table was the only newbie, and he was drunk!) and therefore should be a 30 minute game, but it's more like 1-1.5 hours.  Feh.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I think it helped that I wasn't expecting much going into this game, because I ended up pleasantly surprised. The game as two types of cards - character cards (8 of them) and district cards (a lot of them). The goal is the play district cards to the table for points. The game ends on any turn when a player plays an eighth card to the table. Before playing district cards, though, players pass the character cards around the table and select one to be in effect for that turn. Characters all give a special ability and/or extra money or cards. Character selection is the most interesting part of the game, but it is also the part that takes the longest, as everyone waits while players mull their options before passing the stack along. This is one of the big criticisms of the game - the downtime, especially when playing with slow decision-makers. But I thought picking the right character from what was available while considering your needs for that turn was pretty interesting.

After picking characters, players either collect two gold or draw two district cards, keeping one. Then a player can play one district to the table by paying the cost in gold. That's all there is to it. A character's ability will change things up a bit for that turn. The other big criticism for the game is the "take that" type characters that can steal another character's gold, "assassinate" another character so the player loses his turn, or destroy a district played by another player. People who hate to be messed with won't like this one.

My main concern with the game is that it takes too long for what it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun game with lots of chaos. I think this would require players who are a little cutthroat to reach it's peak.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Another game that would have been rated higher several years ago.  There is a bit of an issue that whoever is the King can keep selecting it or keep it, and the player who winds up with the last pick is screwed as a result.  (Agricola has this same issue when someone picks start player for the next round.)  One thing that irks me is how people think the game is best with seven; I actually think three (two roles apiece) may be the best number, because if one of your characters is assassinated, you can still make a play that turn.  The luck factor in trying to pick who gets assassinated/stolen from probably is one factor that prevents me from giving the game a higher rating, but when it first came out, it was fairly unique.

RATING: 5
Good game which stands or falls depending on the group.  If people are interested in problems of the 'if you pick this and he picks that then I can pick this and then he will have to pick that and then ...' kind and they are also quick at decisions then it will be loads and loads of fun.  Biggest problem is if that there can be considerable downtime if some players can't choose their character quickly - then it drags.  I have played in both scenarios.  If you have a bad experience with this game then don't write it off!  Cards are wonderful and the game play is fascinating.  I am still not sure how much genuine strategy or tactics there are but I am enjoying trying to find out!
Update - played some 2-player now and it really works - probably better than with more players (too much downtime).  I would give it an 8 for 2 players and 4-ish for 5+ players, depending on how quick they played, although even if they DO play quick the downtime is still considerable.
Update - the downtime with 5+ people is horrific.

RATING: 6
This is an alright game when you have a larger group of about 6 players. Players select various role cards with special abilities. Then on their turn they collect coins and build buildings. The cost of the building is also equal to victory points at the end of the game. The roles of thief and assassin add some chaos. Whoever takes the king gets to be the starting player. There is definitely some strategy, but it seems like there is a little more randomness and unpredictability. Still, there is some fun to be had.

RATING: 8

I think the trick is to make sure that everyone chooses their roles quickly and that people don't restrict themselves to only building expensive districts. It's a great game, as long as you play it fast.

Fun Factor: Constantly changing secret roles every round

RATING: 5
I've only played this in groups of five or more. I found the game very frustrating. Accumulating gold is crucial for building, but as soon as a player has two gold pieces she becomes a prime target for both the Assassin and the Thief. If either strikes, the victim cannot make use of that gold.

I found the game had quite a bit of downtime while offering me nothing interesting to do while other players take their turns. Hmmm. . . yup, the few cards in my had haven't changed and, yup, that small stash of gold is still a small stash of gold.

And to make matters worse, this seems to be promoted as a good game to play with newbies. And in my expeirence newbies have a terrible time understanding the role selection and variable player order.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Mass psychology game: which of my choices is the best for me? If I choose this role, then my neighbour will understand it and he/she will kill me. So I'll choose the other role. But what if my neighbour thinks that I chose not the one which is the best, but the second best role?.. Or: He has a lot of money and the best decision for him is to choose this role. However, if he knows that somebody wants to rob him then he will choose this one instead... To sum up, you must think about what others think even though they know that you thing about what they think. A fun and not too long game. Simply do not take the bad luck too seriously.

Grupinės psichologijos žaidimas: ką pasirinkti, kad man būtų naudinga? Jei pasirinksiu šitą rolę, tai mano kaimynas tai supras ir mane nužudys. Taigi rinksiuosi šitą rolę. O jeigu mano kaimynas sugalvos, kad aš pasirinkau, ne tą, kuri pati geriausia bet kitą?.. Arba: jis turi daug pinigų ir jam apsimoka imti tokią rolę. Kita vertus, jeigu jis žino, kad kas nors gali iš jo vogti jis to nesirinks, o rinksis šitą... Žodžiu būtina galvoti, ką galvoja kiti, net ir tada, kai jie žino, kad tu galvoji, ką jie galvoja. Visai smagus ir neilgas žaidimas, tik nereikia perdėm į galvą imti nesėkmių.

The sort of player who likes to annoy his opponent by thinking way too long about his turn will love this game. He will have many, many opportunities to do so! The fact that this game is rated so highly really makes me wonder about the tastes of gamers in general.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Character distribution system is absolutely great and leads to the game's overall goodness. And even though the system is a bit luck-oriented it doesn't actually bother. It is rather nice when situations like "Why, oh why isn't that character among the ones from which to choose this turn" occur. Games don't last for too long and the endgame is usually very tight. Great opportunities to beat-the-leader, but it is not straightforward. Bluffing and seeing through it are needed here. The game also looks really pleasant. In emergency situation also playable with 2 players, but I suggest not to play with 3 players. It will only end up in one player picking assassin to protect himself from the thief. Then this same player either assassinates thief or picks thief himself. German version is highly preferred with its candycoins and  higher-quality cards. I originally had FF version, but decided to get the German as an upgrade.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rating based on 2-player play so far. This is a light and quick 2 player game that's very fun. Shares some elements with San Juan in terms of picking a role that lets you perform actions to benefit you or hinder an opponent (however your opponent doesn't share that role, they have their own roles they've chosen for the round). There is an element of bluffing as well, which requires players to second guess their opponent(s). Good bluffing will give you an additional edge. I can't wait to play with more players. So far it ranks right up there with my other top 2 player games but can expand for more players like San Juan.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very clever card game that's fairly short and light, but with fun bluffing elements. While I've not played it a lot, I always enjoy it when I do.

Glory To Rome is FANTASTIC, though more complex than Citadels.  

San Juan is excellent, the same weight as Citadels but much faster, better, and gives a more satisfying feeling of building.

RATING: 8.3
Fantastic mix of building your estate by hand management / set collection and drafting different characters to get the resources and interfere with the other players plans.

The meta-game of bluffing and double-guessing your opponents is really fun, although a few deaths in a row by the assassin can really screw over your whole game and the fun you are having with this game, quite honestly pretty "90ies" in game design :)

Very nice artwork and plastic coins. So much game with just a few cards.

RATING: 8
Good game. The rules are easily learnt so even newbies are up to speed after a few rounds.

The character role swapping mechanic adds the strategy and creates more player interaction than you get with a lot of Euro card games.

The components are good and the package is compact and easily to carry -- you can fit six of these Silver Line 'brick' games into the space of a single Ticket to Ride Europe.

RATING: 7
The goal of the game is very simple - build the best "Citadel" by purchasing up to 8 District cards, which come in 5 different colors.  There are other ), but the use of the different characters and their special abilities makes it fantastic. Plus, the way that the characters are chosen is brilliant.

The only drawbacks I see are that it is a little prone to analysis paralysis during character selection (especially for new players), and that it can get pretty long with 6-7 players. Otherwise, it's one of my favorites!

RATING: 8
Love this game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Play with Citadels: The Dark City expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Citadels is a good choice for getting your "non-gamer" group to advance a step or two in game complexity. Citadels has only a few important rules to remember, includes variable role selection and hidden choices, and with the right group, will play fairly quickly. But it is susceptible to analysis paralysis - if you have one or more people in your gaming circle that spend too much time thinking about their move, this game will bog down during role selection... big time. The game needs to move along at a good clip to keep people interested and engaged.

It's a good game with just three - the double role selection actually works quite well with three players and changes the tactics of the game, but in a good way. Not a great game for just four players - seems the game is ideal around 5 or 6 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good with 5 or more players.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(October 2004)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I loved this game a few years ago, but it has been replaced in my lineup by 7 Wonders and more recently by Witch's Brew. I like playing with the Diplomat in place of the Warlord sometimes, but would never use any of the other expansion characters. The gameplay can get repetitive and it really sucks to be the Assassin's victim (wasted turns in games really bother me). I do enjoy its portability, though, and the little gold pieces look just like butterscotch candies!

RATING: 5.75
[b]Purchase/Selling History:[/b]
First played at Millenium with Rick.

[b]Rating: [/b]
[i]Design rating[/i]: [b][/b]
[i]Component rating[/i]: [b][/b]
[i]Willingness to play rating[/i]: [b][/b]
[i]Fun rating[/i]: [b][/b] 

[b]Player considerations:[/b]

[b]My thoughts:[/b]
Liked this game a lot more the second time I played, like it a lot with 3 players.
I don't like how easy it is for the king to hang on to the king, I think it should rotate, idk.
I include the dark city expansion with this rating as I've never played the game without it. There are aspects of this game you cannot control, because of what other people choose as their roles, what you're left with, or because you just get unlucky. There's just no super well planned killer combos though that this game needs, imo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Been playing this a lot in my group. Excellent game. If you like Puerto Rico you should like this. Plays faster and can be a bit more diabolical. I prefer it to PR just because I like games that move and don&#039;t bog.

Scales from 2 to 8 players better than any game I own. Even better, it plays differently. For instance, the assassin is a monster card in small games but the more people who are in the less powerful he is. The opposite goes for the thief.

RATING: 8
Best with 5 players
Recommended with 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 players
2-8

While there are things about Citadels that I think could really improve it and I sometimes think I'm losing interest in it, I really do like this game. But more importantly, everyone I've played it with really likes this game and asks to play it again so for that it's a big winner in my book. One of the rare games that I'd recommend to people just because I'm so confident they'll most likely like it.

Of all the games I've played, this one most makes me want to design my own game and I love that about it.

Part of me really wants to get the 2016 version as well as I love that it has new roles, but I just hate that the box is so big. That was one of the great things about the old Citadels: it was a great portable game.

RATING: 9
Fun game! I introduced this game to my friend, he got addicted to it, so I gave him the original "crappy" deck (I kept the "better" replacement cards (^_^)) The cards have magnificient artwork. One annoying thing is having to always redistribute the character cards. And yes, it's probably a good idea to get card protectors. Some of my characters cards have white "scratches" on the edges from our fingernails...Now people can tell which card is which! I don't have the English Citadels version, but I do like the gold pieces for Ohne Furcht und Adel. I've been taking German since I was in Middle School (now HS senior w/ same German teacher!), so the German wasn't too intimidating for me. 2-players is OK and we sometimes make our own variants to the game. Print out the card references for the game! Thank God Boardgamegeek has all these download goodies.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simply ingenious. Addictive with two of my favorite game elements, variable turn order and asymmetrical abilities.

I suspect this works better for 2-3 players with doubled-up turns than it does for single turns, where it might get frustrating and less strategic. I'd even suggest 4-player games add a 9 card so they can still play doubled turns if it doesn't lead to too much decision paralysis.

The addition of the Dark City cards is clutch - for each character rank they introduce something either less confrontational or more powerful than the original set.

Suggested House Rule: The Tax Collector should make buildings cost one more gold to be built, so that if you can afford to pay him you cannot build the building.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Really interesting game that I recognize requires repeat plays to appreciate. Also: don't play with new players heavily under the influence.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Hmmm

It's been ages since I played this game (introduction to this hobby) and I immediately knew this wasn't a game for me.
At least not with the group I've played it with.

The lovers say there are tons of strategies available.
the other says that in the end it is just a luckfest.

And I think if you can ever favor someone pretty unseen in a game this is the one.

I don't like favoritism in games where negotiation isn't a "listed" mechanic. 

Why is there favoritism because people  are practically telling which role they took. (by using limited deduction skills and look for tells)
and in the game I played there was no real variation shown.


Maybe I have to play it more to appreciate it more since  some say it takes a while to appreciate.
I however think there are way more interesting and challenging games out there and don't feel the need to play it ever again.




=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
2-7 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Clever design. I simply love its role selection mechanism.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game is very unique due to its role selection mechanism. It is simple to teach, simple to learn and engaging at the same time. 
The expansion brings in a lot of interesting options and lets you change the balance. With the possibility of Warlord being replaced by Diplomat and Assassin by Witch every role is rewarding now and the tension is even better. New buildings are also cool.
The weaknesses of the game are: the lack of special features for most of the buildings (other than purple) and too few scoring options. 
Otherwise the game is great. It's great for getting people together even when they don't usually play board games- it's simple, light, entertaining and there's lot of tension and interaction.

RATING: 6.9
Our first, own, 'true' modern board/card game. It's a really nice game, also for 2 people - and that's what I was looking for. Nice appearance, interesting (each round you choose a different character to play) and 'customizable' (by adding/removing expansion cards) rules. 

With 2 players - quite quick but strategic, with 6 players - 60 minutes of laugh!

The more I play it, the more I like it.

One of my favorites for every occasion.

It burnt out after a while... Sad, but along with my growing collection, this game just keeps laying on the bookshelf... Anyway, it's still great when thinking about playing with some friends on holidays.

RATING: 4
This is certainly a clever game, but I always get [i]hosed,[/i] and it's usually my fault.  Like, I'm last in line to choose a card, and I'm handed the assassin and someone else, and I choose the someone else; then the person before me, who took the thief, steals from me because I didn't go before him, so I couldn't have taken the assassin.  I mean, losing is fine, but losing because you're [i]stupid[/i] is a little embarrassing.

I'll play this, but not too often, and it's not one I suggest.  Several people in my group really like this, though, and it gets asked for more than a lot of other games!

2009-10-31: This hasn't been asked for in a while; dropping to a 4.

RATING: N/A
In Citadels, players take on new roles each round to represent characters they hire in order to help them acquire gold and erect buildings. The game ends at the close of a round in which a player erects his/her eighth building. Players then tally their points, and the player with the highest score wins.

Dark City expansion is now included with the base game

RATING: 7.5
[2007.Oct.16] Heavily based on role selection card games like Meuterer and Verräter, Citadels is light-hearted, fun game where each player attempts to build 8 buildings, while at the same time trying to avoid the other players efforts to sabotage their progress. Beware of the Assassin, Thief, and Warlord!

The best part is guessing what roles your opponents chose and counter-picking them!

RATING: 4

After playing with new characters in the dark city expansion, I think I prefer most of the original characters.  It might be interesting to interject just a couple of the new characters in place of a couple of the older characters...maybe....Bruno's game designs generally don't fare well with my taste in games; this one I do enjoy to some degree.  This game must be played quickly to be enjoyable - it is too simple a game to be played slowly.  If played slowly, I want to poke my eye out!

RATING: 8
Eleinte nagyon tetszett, de aztán túl gyakran lett olyan érzésem, hogy tehetetlen vagyok, mert se pénzem, se felépíthető épületkártya nincs a kezemben, ergo valószínűleg semmi "eredményeset" nem fogok tudni csinálni a körben. Lehet, hogy csak kicsit szerencsétlenebbeket játszottam párszor, és azért érzem ezt, nem tudom, de tény, hogy most kicsit visszavette a kedvemet (és a pontszámot is: 8 -> 7.3).

Update: Továbbra is szűkösnek érzem a - pénzbeli vagy épületbeli - gyarapodási lehetőséget, de ezúttal egyszer sem fordult elő, hogy ne tudtam volna építkezni. Viszont meg kell jegyeznem, hogy a 8 szerep közül 4 támadó képességű (orgyilkos, tolvaj, mágus, hadúr), ami problémát okozhat akkor, ha valamelyik játékos a szívére veszi, hogy már megint megölték/kirabolták/stb őt. Ha túl gyakran fordul elő ugyanazzal a játékossal ilyesmi, az érthetően könnyen a kedvét szegheti. Más megközelítéssel viszont pont hogy érdekesebbé teszi a játékot, hogy sikerül-e túljárni a többiek eszén, és olyan szerepet választani, amivel megússzuk a támadásokat, támadás esetén pedig eltalálnunk, hogy mely szerep is a helyes célpont - hozzáállás kérdése.

Update2: Lehet ebben pénzt és épületet is szerezni, hiába tud elfogyni a pénz és a lap a kézből. Nem éreztem túl szűkösnek az erőforrásokat, pont jó volt. 7.3 -> 7.8 pont.

Update3: 7.8 -> 8 pont, megérdemli.

RATING: 7

The downtime seems to be a problem with how short this one should be. Maybe with more plays players tend to increase their decision making during the first phase of each round. I don't think will be in regular rotation for me though. The player order for each role is definitely brilliantly constructed as to make those choices agonizing in the first part of each round.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's a fun game with some psychology and light M:TG style rules-breaking special abilities. 

Killing your opponent, stealing his gold, taking his cards, blowing up his buildings and suchlike nastiness are all great additions to the building race genre.  In Citadels, you simply can't ignore what your opponent is doing and that's great.

The card art is among the best you'll find.  It's a keeper.

I like this best as either a three-player game with the  mean characters in (Assasin, Thief, Warlord) or a four-player game with some of the gentler ones cycled in (Witch, Diplomat).

I don't find two-player interesting and with five you've got to play to 7 buildings and really hurry everyone up or it drags.    Haven't played with more, don't really want to.

UPDATE:  Actually been playing this as a 2-player and liking it a lot, maybe even my favorite way to play.  You have to keep the nasty guys in and then it's a balance between racing to 8 districts and bashing your opponent to slow her down.  Fun!

Note that I only like playing this game under two conditions:  (1) use the variant where players draft 2 characters per round.  This means that player count is capped at four, which is fine.  (2) Make the choice per turn "two gold or two cards" INSTEAD of "two gold or draw two cards and discard one."  I simply like having the cards flow into the game at a faster rate.  The effect of both these changes is to make it a faster-paced game that concludes in 30 minutes or so, which to me is perfect for Citadels.

If played by original rules (one character per player, the "draw two, discard one" rule) then the rating drops sharply for me, to a 5 or maybe even a 4.  Playing with more than five people under those circumstances is something I'd positively not attempt.

Oh, and I also never play with the Architect, as I consider him an overpowered character.  When he's in the game it simply revolves too much around him and you have to use the assassin / thief every turn to stop him.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A building game designed by a French.  Usually this kind of game won't interest me.  But this one is recommended by some of my wargaming friends and the setting is in Medieval.  Besides, I want to play more multiplayer games.  Why not try this to recruit more potential Euro or Wargamers?  The game is fun and absorbing to complete in 40 minutes.

RATING: 10
Great balance leads to super strategical flexibility. 

Choosing characters for every round make it possible to counterbalance character abilities and to adapt different strategies each round, which simply enable a player to make his or her every move perfectly intentional and reasonable, rather than just random guesses. At the same time, any specific, deliberate action is not gonna have irreversible lasting effect to the end of the game; in other words, anyone with an advantage in this round does not guarantee a same advantage two rounds later.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Un buen juego de estrategia dónde la especulación, la conspiración y la traición hacen que sumados a su sencillez, su buena factura gráfica, precio inmejorable (que además, en su tercera edición incluye la expansión del juego), rapidez, facilidad de aprendizaje y la posibilidad de que puedan jugar hasta ¡8 jugadores! permiten encontrar un hueco en la estantería de toda ludoteca que se precie.

Consejos:
1. Una buena estrategia puede ser tener de entre los 8 distritos, 2-2-2 de 3 colores distintos y los otros 2 que restan,1 de cada color de los distritos restantes. De esta manera es más difícil que otro jugador tenga claro a qué personaje tuyo va a asesinar o robar´; así tienes más posibilidades de éxito.
2. Constuir distritos de coste medio-alto (a partir de 4 ó mas monedas) dificulta la acción destructora del condotiero.
3. Ser el rey te asegura en parte poder prever las posibles estrategias de tus rivales. Ser el rey al principio de la partida puede ser muy buena idea pues hasta que a nadie se le ocurra arrebatarte ese puesto pueden pasar varias rondas.
4. Tener una mano inicial variada de distritos de bajo coste de construcción puede ser letal si se combina con el Arquitecto. Esto puede suponer una victoria relámpago.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played only twice, not enough yet, will probably play this soon

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I expected this to be somewhat like a "light San Juan" or some light building game. It is more intricated than I expected, not at all hard or really heavy strategy, but you need a real sense of knowing what to do in the next 1-2 turns. Your plan will always be delayed, always, no matter what. You will have to balance the expect of loss with the screwage you need, to win. 

A nice, fast-paced game that a lot of people will like, I've already tested it with 6+ of my gaming buddies (in different games) and all of them liked it in some level. One of them even got hooked with the "internet version" (I'm not sure wich one).

One thing: never, ever play it with more than 5 players. I like it with 5 players, it gets enough conflict around the table but it's still a 1-1.5 hour game, but whe you add the 6th player it will get long and boring, even when choosing characters it gets tedious and overcomplicated, after 2-3 hours of pain you will notice that someone managed to get the 8 buildings, and be grateful that he did!.

[Played mostly with: 4-5, played best with 4]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Still one of my favorite games, especially when 5 players or more, actually less then 5 isn't advised. You build your plans on assuming/guessing, and when that goes wrong so much can happen, that's the real fun ! I don't tend to win this a lot but it doesn't bother me, we always have a good time.
Not a game you should play with people who aren't really focused though then it gets ruined, we mostly start a game evening with this. Too much talk can ruin it as well, but eventually players will learn not to reveal too much by accident.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
In an early visit to a now regular Thursday night boardgame session I got lost in the blizzard of cards that is San Juan (on reflection I can blame my own gaming naievety).  So when a game was brought to the table and the words cards, roles and buildings were mentioned I had already started to think of escape routes ... maybe jump through a window or fight my way out ... but with no chance for getting a run up or no sharp objects to hand I was cornered and forced to stay.  And I am glad I did.

Citadels is now one of my favourite card games, it has a theme which appeals to me, balanced gameplay, very neat mechanics, easily understood rules, a 'try and read your opponents minds' element and strategy which becomes slowly apparent but never fully reveals itself which will add to replay value.  Played with 5 players (three discarded cards - 1 face up) there is the chance to bluff by taking the architect or merchant card early.  A very enjoyable and rewarding experience.

2 criticisms that assault the walls of Citadels are that it is prone to analysis paralysis - to an extent a game is as successful as the right mix of players for it, yes there is delay but even a few simple house rules can minimalise it and healthy banter should be encouraged during downtime.  Secondly, the role of the king means that hypothetically a player can have first choice every time but this would only mean dragging behind the rest and soon becoming irrelevant to the game and a target for assasination ... the more I think about it the more I like the theme.

RATING: 3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great game, got me into board gaming by showing me the potential in the hobby. Love guessing which card my opponent picked of the ones that are missing, and trying to figure out if he would single, double, or triple bluff, or just take what he needs.

Now I would rather play Libertalia or BattleCon for something more meaty (and with less downtime) with the same element of predicting each other's card choices, and Skull and Roses for something with bluffing that is faster and more consistently fun. Citadels still has a place on a game night with 4-5 players where everyone is getting tired and doesn't want the brain burning or setup of Libertalia.

Some things annoy me about the edition I have:

1) The expansion cards seem really mismatched and on a completely different power level from the base game, and the art style has less charm and doesn't match.
2) The assassin is anti-fun, and the Warlord is a waste of a turn. (These are the characters most begging to be replaced by expansion characters.)
3) The only depictions of women in the card art are negative.
4) It doesn't *really* play 2-8. Four is the sweet spot. Five players drags. Six+ is insanely long, boring, and not recommended. 2-3 forces you to have two characters, which is awful for newbies and anyone looking to relax.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
For anyone who has played more complicated civ-building Euro games like Puerto Rico or dominion, this one isn't going to produce any fireworks. But the mechanics do provide some tense, difficult tactical decision making and lots of dramatic tension, and it's very quick and dead easy to teach. One thing that truly does set it apart the absolutely gorgeous, richly variegated card art, which should make it a pleasure to play for even the most highminded strategy buff.

RATING: 7
BLUFFING. This is such a simple card game but the "role selection" mechanic involves getting into your opponents head and trying to outguess them.  Mostly you are trying to guess which opponents picked which roles, and trying to make sure they can't guess which one you are picking.  Turns can sometimes take a long time while the opponent is trying to figure all this out.  It's a mind game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I played this once where you have different roles you can draft each round and you have information based on what is left to choose from.  There is always one role leftover. Roles are resolved in numeric order

You are trying to acquire money to build buildings.  At the end of the game, you score buildings based on their value and combination of colors and numbers built.  

It is an interesting cross between a social deduction game and a Euro.  When I played the one time there were too many players and it took forever.  Fewer players would go more quickly, however, this is one of the older games around and I think there are newer games which have replaced it.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Fun and brilliant IMO.  A great game to have in your collection and it scales up to 7 players.  Players are competing to build the best cities to score points and choosing the right roles each turn to help them do so.  The fun is in trying to guess what your opponents are going to choose and trying to outthink them but trying to help yourself at the same time.  With more people the role selection tends to drag the game on a bit but this the only drawback.  Great game.

RATING: N/A
This game is ranked high, gets consistently great reviews, can play as quickly as 30 minute game when playing with the 2 player variant, and it can also be picked up by an 8y/o. A definite BUY!

Amazon reviewer offered the following suggestions:

TIPS: For your enjoyment and the preservation of the product, I offer some tips: 

-Put the role cards into plastic card protectors; this will prolong the life of them as they will be shuffled and battered by the players throughout the game 

-Get more gold counters; this isn't an issue most of the time, but with more players and with certain roles a player can stock up quite a bit of gold at times (this is important when using the expansion characters); quality of the gold counters depends on the version, from cardboard to plastic pieces 

-Print or write up a card with the numbers of each role; at times, people will forget who goes next and a card like this is not provided
Help other customers find the most helpful reviews 

Coin Comparison: http://boardgamegeek.com/image/140053/citadels

Alternative games with shorter playing time: 
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1139570/similar-game

RATING: 5
2004 A bit too simplistic for my taste and the random card-draw element is too dominating. And there's the dreaded CCG-feeling. A so-so filler-game. (Citadels)

3/2010 Initial assessment seems too harsh after further play.  It's easy to learn and remember the order and porwers of the different role cards, and which card you select depends on availability and your current needs with regards to possible building cards.  Rating up 3 -> 5.

Bought 15/9/2009, Slim edition with expansion from ScienceFiction Bokhandeln, Malmö

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a game about bluffing and deduction - don't let anyone tell you otherwise. The artwork is absolutely gorgeous, and the game is simple enough to learn that anyone can play. Plays well with up to four, but after that you'll see a big spike in play time. 6-player games overstay their welcome.

I'm a bit burned out on this these days, and rarely play it anymore, but I wouldn't turn it down if someone else requested it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'm very positive about this game after 2 plays, but I can't help but imagine some situations in which my opinion would be drastically altered.  The king-making element was rather overbearing even on my second play, for example, and the non-screwage decisions you have to make seem to be somewhat obvious once you grok the basic mechanics...so in the final analysis you're looking at a game that relies a lot on random elements (getting the right cards) and hoping you don't get screwed over.  Not the sort of game I can imagine playing a lot of, but still pretty fun with the right group in the right frame of mind.

RATING: 7
Fun card game with gold pieces where you secretly pick a role and try to build buildings and hurt your opponents.  The game has a 'screw your opponent' element that some don't love but I think this game is fun and fairly light. Can get a little tedious after a while, but picking different roles and staying ahead gives it enough tension to keep it interesting.

RATING: 9
Beauty and suspense in a small package (at least it's rather small for the german Ohne Furcht und Adel version). The new characters of the english version yet (or the german expansion Die Dunklen Lande, I guess) add some new spice to the game.
Played 20+ times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It is a weird game. The main element of this game is "danger of doing something good for me." If I take a role which can give me much of advantage, it is highly probable that I might be killed or robbed. So it is dangerous to specialize in some role. But many of powers of characters and buildings encourage specilizing. So specializing in some role is encouraged and disencoured in the same time.

Of course the guess can be incorrect. But in this case, an innocent player is hosed and frustrated with right target not being harmed.

Of course possibility of killing being killed, robbing and being robbed is the source of fun, tense, and uniqueness of this game... but still such a mechanic seems awkward. The result of it is a game which is too chaotic to play strategically, too tedious to play lightly, which can give reward to not being picked (luckily) and no reward to careful planning.

If it was half-time short, I would willingly play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Another great FFG Silver Line Game.

Simple mechanics that are easy to teach, colorful art, nice  components, and fun.

The fun that this game provides will vary from group to group. It really depends on how vengeful people want to be with each other by destroying their buildings, stealing their gold, or swapping their cards...as all these mechanics are the ones that generate the interaction within the group. Other than some of those wrinkles (and special cards that can be played), it is a pretty straight-forward game.

Overall though it never really becomes the MOST exciting game that will come to the table. It's good, but not great and does have some flaws...those being: it can be a little quiet around the table for periods of time which is a bummer, there really is a limit to what you can do each turn and how to approach your goal, the cards are made of flimsy paper, and this game definitely plays better with more people.

But it makes a great filler game that people will enjoy. Also I have yet to make use of the included expansion cards that it came with, and I have heard that those add some spice/variety to the game.

Definitely worth owning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A very good game! Perhaps a bit too long when you are five or more.

RATING: N/A
Ohne Furcht und Adel 
Best with 5 players
Recommended with 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 players 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
L'idée du jeu est de construire une cité constituée de 8 quartiers différents. Les quartiers sont classés en cinq catégories : religion, noblesse, commerce et artisanat, soldatesque et enfin prestige.

Chaque joueur interprète un rôle, qui peut changer à chaque tour, et lui confère des pouvoirs ou des revenus spécifiques. On est ainsi tour à tour assassin, architecte, évêque, marchand, ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
1 play:  Hmmm.  I don't hate this game, but I'm not sure yet what the appeal precisely is.  There doesn't seem to be a huge amount of control either.  Early assassin/thief plays will largely be random and you can get stuck by no fault of your own.  Some interesting ideas, particularily how the game seems to be a creative mash of a variety of old ideas (money -> buildings -> points... but set collection helps make more money... but diversity -> more points... special power roles... bonus for being first out).  I wasn't captivated by it, but maybe future games will move my barometer upwards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Citadels has an amazing depth:size ratio. It's small, quick, and easy to learn, but man is there a lot going on in this game -- and its absolutely packed with turn angst. It's also just plain interesting and fun.

The role selection mechanic is brilliantly executed, and there's a lot of variability without veering too far into randomness. Add in a nice metagame that develops over the course of each play, and this is one stellar card game.

The one downside is the length of play with more than about five players; seven was just agonizing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excelent game by Bruno Faidutti. Somehow this author finds the way to make games that age good (everytime you play it, you find new layers, strategics). It has to be played with gamers with the same experience about the game. One begginer with experienced players can make it annoying.

RATING: 9
I was going to rate it "8" but all my friends, including not usual boardgames, really like this one. I trust them too, so here's a "9" for this really enjoyable game.
Rules are simple and gameplay can be really cruel. The 10 "extra" characters allow to have a different match every time (and different flavours and strategies). Always balanced due to the "choose character" at the start of each turn. Nice graphics for the cards, but 
a) essentially, it's a card game and not a boardgame
b) cards are too thin and so can be ruined fast (protective envelopes raccomended)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A very fine game of double-bluff and second guess with quite subtle knock on effects from the various role powers providing multiple routes for success. RATING: 6.43
Rating:

Game quality: Seemed very okay to me. There is some interesting play going on between the roles, but there's a lot of games out that do something similar so even if it stood out at one point, it feels a lot less fresh now. I need another play of this as it felt clunky for us trying to learn this and get strategy down. 6.


Would I buy this again if I was starting over: Unless something changes, this would be an easy pass for me if I was rebuilding from the ground up. 1.

Do I want to play this if asked: Yes, do to wanting to get a better feel of the game and come to an ultimate judgement on it. I don't see it after that though. 5.

Overall: 6.15.

Rating potential: Maybe some additional plays help, but I don't see this moving up a bunch. Again, it feels surpassed already.

Update: A much better second play has me rethinking this. Four plays in and I need to up this. Clearly a better game than some I have ranked higher. I think some people are starting to see some of the aspects to the strategies the game offers. I can see this being a solid game within my game group. Might never be a Top 50 game for me, but it works. Upped to 6.43 until I can get something more official.

RATING: 8
I've played this game 8 or 9 times prior to logging games on the Geek. I've won once ( a 4-player game at KSC 2005) . The game play varies a lot with the number of players. RATING: 8
This is THE gateway drug to eurogames. Anyone can learn it, like Carcassonne, but Citadels stays fresh for much longer because of the tactical role selection. IMO, the perfect number of players is 3. You get two roles per person. Although it is a surprisingly tense 2-player game as well. Large groups slow the game down immensely. The fewer players, the more strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
富饒之城-中文版
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Citadels is a really fun card drafting game.  In it players are attempting to be the first to construct eight buildings in their medieval town.  Buildings have various costs and some give players benefits once constructed.  To help you in your endeavour to build, and to slow others from building, you will draft character cards.  Each character has a special ability.

Citadels can be a bit of a dirty game, as some characters will really put you on the offensive if you draft them.  You can kill, or rob other players, destroy their buildings, or exchange your crappy hand of building cards for another player's better hand.  So, if you don't like the idea of in-your-face tactics then this may not be the game for you.

I, however, recommend this game.  I tend to like most drafting games.  It's fun to see what characters you get to choose from each turn, and try to figure out who may have taken which other card.  Then see how they all affect each player as cards are revealed.  Good fun!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good.
1. FUN for big group. Lots of laughter at the table.^^
2. Nice guessing, bluffing, "racing". I find racing as one of the strategy to win over players who tend to build high gold districts. I race to finish the game, trying to get all colors if possible for bonus.

Bad
1. Waiting for players to choose role. The downtime can become quite significant.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Ordered this after playing Puerto Rico, whose role mechanism I liked but was otherwise unenthused. Had to laugh when I found Citadels predated PR! And it's pretty much everything I'd hoped for: fast thematic role selection with nice components and a near-zero set-up time. Works well with two. I note it is called "Machiavelli" in some other countries - a much better name. It feels more like you're buying up parts of a city through nefarious means as head of an influential family than building your own city. Our friends went and bought a copy the day after introducing it to them; I think they were impressed with my "You. Bitch." when my wife magician-ed away my brilliant dealt hand for a 3-card hand of dross (she then assassinated the magician to stop anyone retrieving "my" cards).
I can't see me ever turning down a game. Quick and gripping.

RATING: 8
Besides the flimsy cards, this game is awesome.  I love the psychological aspect of it.  But it can take a long time with more players.  I still need to try the expansion characters.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Deduction and city building.  Every round each player will select a role from those left available, which give special powers to activate in addition to collecting income and building their city.

Can be a bit nasty for new players as those with experience have a clear advantage.  A good game in the right circumstances.

Biggest complaint is that it tends to outstay its welcome.  Towards the endgame, it can become a bit of a grind where there is a clear leader.  While it is initially fun to try and catch what they are doing and counter it, once their winning position becomes obvious I find the game can drag. 

I also dislike the downtime during the role selection phase - easy to get drawn into analysis paralysis as it is difficult to plan one's move in advance.  I think the designer resolved this issue in his later game Mascarade, which shares common elements with this game but is much more streamlined.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fun deduction elements, though prone to analysis-paralysis. Heavily focused on role selection, resource management and hand management. Tends to overstay its welcome. Being stabbed three turns in a row by the assassin can lead to a very frustrating experience.

RATING: 6
+ March 2010
- Nov 2010
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good: 
This game provides information through limited roles, gold, and buildings to allow you to tactically guess what your opponents will be trying to do. Armed with this information you can attempt to make selections to counter them while benefiting from your role selection. Hands down one of the best "people reading" games I have run across. 

Excellent quality components all around. 

Fantastic artwork. 

Bad: 
If players can't get am accurate read on other player's actions they can be pretty much road blocked, which can be frustrating. 

This game is extremely take-that in nature so only play with even tempered friends. 

I really enjoy this game, but there are a few in my group that really dislike the take-that nature so it doesn't get played as much as I would like. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of my fav's. This game will not be turned down by anyone who has played it. Lots of bluffing ("I should take the architect, but instead I'll take the king... hehehe"), deduction ("If I am the thief, I need to steal from my neighbor who I suspect will be the bishop"), and luck ("I thought for sure the assassin was gonna kill me... whew!"). Every game is different, and those practicing thier poker faces will love this one as they attempt to "read" other's faces without being read themselves. Can't say enough good things about this game! Get it while you can! (Oh, and don't forget to put character cards in sleeves, they wear down fast if you don't).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played 11 times.
Last play May 29, 2009

This is a very fun yet simple game.  I have played it with 2, 3, 4 and 6 players, and while different at each number it was still a fun game.  This game gets extra cudos because it is so versital to the number of people that can play it.  With 2 and 3 players the game is much more stategic and a lot more thought and coordination need to go into choosing your roles.  With 4  players the game is a little more random and has more luck in it.

It has been so long since this made it to the table I had forgeten how much I enjoyed it.

RATING: 5
An interesting and chaotic little cardgame. Can take a while to play, due to the depth of thought required, but good planning is rewarded with some neat combos. There is a lot of player interaction and it can be quite cut-throat.

Unfortunately, this game does tend to take a variable and sometimes long time to play. For this reason, its popularity has declined.

RATING: 8.5
First Impression: Very fun as a 2 player game. Easy to learn, a lot of variable strategy and a seemingly low index of repetition in future games. My girlfriend and I greatly enjoyed our first two games, and found the character selection aspect to be an interesting dynamic that injects a lot of variety into the game play. 

NB: Much of the criticism of the game seems to be that it's slow with a large number of people, and many of these critics (here on BGG) seem to have been judging based on first play through where no one knew the special character traits by heart and had to spend a lot of time reading descriptions, therefor slowing the game significantly. This should dissolve after a few playthroughs, and we finished our second 2 player game in about 25 minutes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Citadels was my first real hook into board gaming proper many, many years ago.  The game was unlike anything I had played up to that point with an blend of personal strategy and player interaction via deduction.  I took several years, however to figure out why the game remained so unique, and it mainly occurs in the way the game presents itself as one thing (a lite city/tableau builder) but then hits you with a core strategy (anticipation/deduction) that just so happens to be one that otherwise might not be palatable to most gamers, but nevertheless is always a hit.  For every instance of my game group turning up their nose at a deduction game, there is an equal number of Citadels games that have been greatly enjoyed.  Can get overly long with many players or an overly social group due to downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Nice and quick deduction, hidden-information and deception card game loosely themed on a fantasy city where the players draft potentate roles to gain resources to build structures in a race to first reach seven buildings and the most points. The roles allow for different ways of shifting the turn order, activating and obtaining certain resources, protecting some buildings, or attacking the opponents outright. Short down times, little randomness nd high degree of player interaction, this is a nice little game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Au début de chaque tour de jeu, chaque participant va choisir d'interpréter pour le tour un personnage doté de capacités particulières. Ainsi l'Assassin va assassiner, le Condottiere attaquer et détruire un quartier, l'Évêque puiser dans les troncs, le Magicien faire des tours avec ses cartes (et celles des autres), etc. Une fois son rôle choisi, le joueur qui interprète le Roi fait jouer les joueurs dans l'ordre de préséance. Chacun pourra soit gagner de l'argent, soit en dépenser pour construire un quartier de sa ville et utiliser son pouvoir spécial. Chaque carte de quartier possède un coût de construction et une couleur (les quartiers marchands en vert, les militaires en rouge, ...). Le joueur qui pose son huitième quartier le premier déclenche la fin de la partie. Les points sont fonctions du coût de construction et il existe des bonus pour les villes qui possèdent tous les types de quartier, pour le premier à avoir posé son huitième quartier, et ceux qui ont réussi à en poser un huitième avant la fin du dernier tour.

RATING: 6.5
Nice little game. Fairly easy to explain. Works good with more people too. Easy to take along too, so makes for a good holiday/bar game.

It's one of those games that I rarely mention when somebody asks me what to play, but I usually still enjoy it when I play it. I like it better with 2 to 4 players than with more, I think the interactivity and tactical options are higher that way.

Rating used to be higher, have played this quite a bit since it came out. And it's usually suggested by someone who doesn't play much, so their turns take way too long. So when I play it I get a bit bored by other players spending too much time on their turn. Which tends to lead to too much tabletalk, so the game takes even longer...

This game is great fun when played in 45 minutes. Last 2 plays lasted 90 and 160. Not much fun that way.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Very interesting core concept. The once around draft of role cards, and then the sequential action phase where each role does its "thing" plus the always available option of building / drawing / taking gold.

Very simple mechanically, but puts forth some interesting questions during play, mainly in terms of risk - reward. Some roles really punish players going for the obvious choice, so you really have to try and read your fellow players.

However, it manages to take a bit too long when not playing with four or less, so stick to that. Also, it has a bit of a run-away issue, you can quickly be out of contention through little fault of your own, simply by being collateral damage to a missed guess by the thief or assassin, perhaps not just once but twice in a row, then you will not be the one winning.  Alleviated some in a three-player game, not so sure with four, but maybe then as well, but more than that ...

Ultimately, I'd rather play something else most of the time, but I found this very interesting, and it certainly has a lot of schadenfreude - which I find fun in games, and this one has it in spades.

A decent / good game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First time through was figuring out stuff, but it garnered much praise and continued interest to play again.  Now it's a requested favorite.  Highly competitive and fascinating two-player game is a very different and highly recommended play experience than with multiple players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
keeper : just a nice mechanic people are put of by inital explination but once its played they love it! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Game in a Nutshell:  A simple city(citadel)-building card game made interactive by a character selection mechanic that allows players to mess with each other.

Played as: 2,4,5,6,7 player

Played with: 2,4,5,7 player Base-game only, 4,6 with parts of the expansion.

Pros:  The character selection really does wonders in filling out in a simple way what is otherwise an extremely basic game.  The hidden nature of it makes for some good times trying to read what others might select in order to steal their gold, abilities, or just plan foil their plans. Seems that new players can pick up on the mechanics after a few rounds and really enjoy it by the end of the game. Nice small form factor and a good price. With the inclusion of the expansion, there’s enough in one box to vary things up when it feels like it might be growing stale.

Cons:  Down-time can be a problem.  This is especially true with just a couple individuals who are either slow or easily distracted.  The other thing that can bring the game down is if you happen to, by accident or not, become the game’s whipping boy.  Usually the players who enjoy the game the least are the ones who get stolen from or assassinated the most.  Veterans of the game could probably take it with a grain of salt, but if it’s their first play... well, don’t expect them to want to play again immediately.  Finally, the character selection rules for two players, out of the box, can be serviceable, but probably not worth it if you have any other half decent options.

Other:  One thing this game lacks is something to keep players actively involved when it isn’t their turn. Usually that’s a deal killer for a game that supports this many players but for some reason it doesn’t bother me as much here. Maybe that’s because I’ve enjoyed the people I’ve played with and the light conversation in between. Or maybe it’s the mind-game aspect that leaves things open for some good old-fashioned, get in your head, trash-talking?  I’ve just started playing around with the expansion after 10 or so plays without.  The witch (replacing the assassin) has been the best change, due to evening things out for both the role player and victim, and one I doubt I’ll change back going forward.  

Best Use:  The game is good at 4-5 players, but so are a bunch of others.  Not as many games are good with 6-7, so that’s likely when I’ll bring this out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

RATING: 5.5
Quite a nice game, if and only if the expansion is added. I play this game only with 3 players, and perhaps will with 4; any more and this simple ditty devolves into an endless mess of I-think-that-you-think nonsense (2 hrs not uncommon), where random factors decide whether you get your money, your turn, or basically your resources for the game.
Also, I play without the Assasin, Thief, and Soldier - the first two inject either randomness, or have predictable targets; the latter only lengthens the game beyond its welcome. Instead some of the Dark City characters should be used, making the expansion essential.

RATING: 4
A casual, slightly cut-throat game that could be forgiven if the city-building mechanics weren't so dull, and the overall pace of the game weren't so tediously slow.  Although aimed at large numbers of players, this suffers significantly from only one player doing anything at a time, while being luck-based enough to remove any serious strategic interest.  There are several other games I would always prefer to play (e.g. Coup).

RATING: 9
The key to Citadels seems to be that those characters which deal damage deal damaged to other characters, rather than directly to other players.

I greatly appreciate Citadels particularly in contrast to card drafting games such as Hero Realms, having drifted solemnly through many a game of the latter where players have chosen to inflict all their damage on the most outspoken player (which is never me, incidentally).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Great when playing two players - really fast (usually < 15 minutes) and alot of bluffing and reverse psychology (the end game is particularly fun). 

The standard rules for three players are poor since they give too much power to the assassin (he has 100% chance of hitting someone if you take him in the first round in three player). http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/44757 has a proposal to resolve this. 

Recommended for 2 player - try before you buy for 3  (particularly for 5  since the game can drag on).

For 4 or more players, I'd go with https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/129622/love-letter or https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/139030/mascarade instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Like this game less and less the more i play it.

RATING: 7
Very scalable card-based game.  Plays slowly with more players (6-7) as each person has only one turn (plus ability to screw over one other person).  Game has interesting balance mechanics for 2/3 people, making it a slightly different type of play (quite a bit faster, for example).  After repeated plays, the best feature is trying to out-guess what others are choosing!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not a lot to the game which is basically a primarily a tactical guessing game with a strong potential for screwage.  There is some deduction and room for some skillful use of the roles though with timing being critical.  When the game moves at a good clip, I enjoy Citadels, but it is also a game that I can begin to disklike if the pace of the game starts to bog down...

Don't do this to your game group, keep the pace of the game fast and light (limit to 4-5p) and fun can be had by all.  Maybe).

Decent artwork, and I particularly like the 2010 FFG Silverline edition of Citadels with the plastic gold coins, wood King marker, compact size and reasonable price.

Overall, a decent filler game, so long as player number are kept reasonable and players don't overanalyze what should be a fast moving and light game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Kolla
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very mixed feelings on this. On the one hand, I love the psychological aspect of guessing the roles other people choose and basing your own choice on both what you need and what you suspect others will do to you.

If other players have you in their sights, take an unexpected role so they can't target you. If they have a role in their sights, don't take it! But you need one of those? Well go ahead, because surely the others know you would never be so foolish as to take the obvious choice, right?

On the other hand, it plays so slow. All action is deadlocked on the currently drafting player, so any AP is intensely felt. If played with a group you are happy to shoot the breeze with during the draft (think "sewing circle") then it will be fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2012-03-24

BREAK IN
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Takes a few turns to get going for new players.  With experienced players is where this game shines as you really start trying to figure out what roles a player will take (new players are random in their selections).  If the game goes quickly then I love this game (about one hour).  If people select roles too long then it drags.  5 people is about perfect for the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A game I’ve owned for years but only ever played a couple times. The theme of Citadels is slightly reminiscent of Dominion, as players attempt to earn cash to purchase buildings of various point values for their town, but the gameplay is very different. Players play buildings into their city from their hand by paying the amount of cash indicated, usually between 1-6 gold. They may draw new building cards from the deck on their turn, or collect more gold from the bank. Some buildings give added benefits, such as letting you earn even more gold on your turn. But the real hook of the game is the character cards. Each round, the players shuffle the 8 character cards, discard one face down, and then take turns examining the remaining cards and selecting a character to play as for that round. (A game usually last around 10 rounds or so.) Each character grants that player a special power. Some powers are straightforward; the King always goes first and collects 1 extra gold for each yellow building in his city, (each building card is designated one of five different colors,) while others are malicious; the Assassin chooses another character to kill, causing them to lose their turn. The trick is that players choose their character from the remaining character cards that are handed to them from the right, always starting with the current King, (if another player chooses the King, she will pick first on the next round,) so they never know for sure who the other players are until the round begins, and even less so if they are seated several seats from the King. Really getting inside your opponents heads, trying to guess who they’d choose, and how to either attack them or defend yourself from them, based on just GUESSES, is the real meat of the game. As you can imagine, also knowing well what each character’s abilities are and how they tend to interact with each other gives you a leg up in this game. If you are all basically new to the game, it is still a fair play, but the high advantage given to experienced players is what has soured me to this game in the past.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.65
My first Faidutti game. [2005.12.15]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
