=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Draft and play district and character cards to improve your city for most points.

Plays: More than a dozen?
Type: VP race = a game where you race to collect victory points (fastest/most).
Complexity: Light.
# of players: 4-5.
Playing time: 15 mins per player.
Player interaction: Competition for unlimited resources – districts. Conflict and targeting – some character cards hurt other players directly and some target one specific player.
Randomness: Low – card draw.

Replayability: Not so high, once in a while is enough.
Fun: Building the city is just a VP race and not so fun. On the other hand, character drafting involves targeted take-that cards, which are devious fun.
Memorability: This creates some stories. You’ll remember being repeatedly assassinated, f.ex. And probably remind the assassin about it all game day.

Thematic integration: Decent.
Components: Good.

Who will like this: Gamers that want another strategy game. This is often second best.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I like this light, quick game for parties or small get togethers.  It scales well for a wide range of players and easy enough to explain/learn that new players can grasp some sound strategies within a few rounds of play.

If a person plays a random role every time, then interacting with that player is much more difficult as several of the mechanics require other players to guess which role they will choose.  It protects the player a bit from having gold stolen or being assassinated, however it also forces them from making sub-optimal picks thereby costing them gold and/or other resources.  I've found that when a player does this, they probably won't win and they will make the less fun for the other players overall.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

I tried this game years ago and not got very far. Admittedly it was with a group that were more interested in socialising than gaming (and there's nothing wrong with that) where no-one had read the rules and no-one really wanted to take charge of explaining and running the game and it all petered out as interest waned. As such, I was a bit wary when my regular lunch-time gaming partner suggested that we try it; he'd recently picked it up with a gift certificate and was keen to give it a crack.

Anyway, memories of it all being a bit crap (I remember being on the wrong end of the assassin's dagger most turns) were put aside and we played a two-player game of Citadels.

I was pleasantly surprised by how the two player game worked. Quite an elegant design and role choosing mechanism where bluffs and counter-bluffs are vital to fox your opponent and get your Citadel built.

We just used the basic set of cards, but with a few more games under our belts we'll try the advanced/expansion cards and see how it works for us.

Overall, I enjoyed the game a lot more than I expected (perhaps proving my memory isn't what it used to be) and look forward to trying this one again soon and regularly. The lesson that it may be wise to give a game that didn’t impress at first another chance has not been lost on me*.



* Except for RoboRally and Power Grid, I have no desire to ever try either of those two games again.

RATING: 4
I've only ever played this 2-player. (UPDATE: I've now, unfortunately, played it with more than two.) I've heard it's about getting inside somebody's head. Except... it isn't, not really. It only seems that way. Because if both you and your opponent are second-guessing each other ad infinitum on which of two cards the other just selected (since when you get passed the role cards, you can easily keep track of which two are missing), it really comes down to chance in terms of role selection. So for me, the bluffing aspect really falls flat. And without it, the rest of the game isn't too interesting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A chaotic but fun game of guessing and second guessing other player's drafting selections. Probably not a game to be taken too seriously and players shouldn't spend too long agonising over their role choices as this will kill the pace of the drafting mechanism and hence the whole game. A good game for large groups or a family. It really is a chaotic 
game and not for those gamers who like to plan their moves. Reasonably good gateway game due to the simple rules but AP newbie analysis paralysis and the resulting downtime may kill it for some.

Update: Finding that although this game has a clever mechanism its problem is that although it is capable of accommodating large groups it drags on FAR too long when played by a large (ie >5) group. Most games I've played with have been with 6+ players and they all ran for 90+ min, with most of it being downtime. For a more strategic game with intervening player actions this would be OK but for what is really a medium-weight filler the downtime blows out to make a dull experience. Also, an early poor start (eg being assassinated, bewitched, getting stuck with a weak role is very difficult, etc) is difficult to recover from, quickly creating a runaway leader and making the game seem to last even longer for those in such situations. I now dread playing it with a group size of >5. Rating 7.5 with 6 or less, 5 with more than 6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Loved by many, Citadels uses a role system , whereby every player takes a role with its own benefit and passes the remainder on. Building different structures is the key and various points are scored for owning multiple colours etc. I think much of its popularity boils down to the role mechanism and the fact it can accommodate a large number. I like it but am not infatuated.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game feels a bit outdated by now, maybe? Well, it's my own fault playing it for the first time only now in 2015. 

It's not a bad game and I'm sure I could have at least some fun with it, but it feels too long & has down-time issues with 5-7 players and with fewer players the role powers don't work so well. The roles also seem to be the only interesting thing in the game, the buildings are just boring. There also seemed to be some runaway problems, since the roles are hidden. Some roles feel more important than others, which made at least the game I played a bit monotonic. 

I've heard the expansion balances the roles out a bit and adds some more flavour to the buildings, but it probably isn't enough.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very interesting game and exciting mechanic. But I have discouraged of the fact, that players builds their cities on their own. There is much interaction during Choose Characters step and during use power of SOME (but not all) characters, and lack interaction during [rather lasting] players' turns. Should be plaied with right company (players that do not such drag their feet).
P.S. Replyability is very high. Rules is simple. There is no much text on cards, so I can play it with players who don't understand English.

RATING: 6
I enjoy the mechanics of the role selection and trying to psych out the other players, but trying to juggle both that and keeping a steady pace of building going never seems to work well for me, so I don't enjoy this one as much as some other games.

Having read cfarrell's comments on it in his "overrated games" list, I think part of this is what he says about the game pulling in two different directions: the strategic, where you want to build up a strong position in order to win, and the tactical, where various roles make doing so next to impossible.

RATING: 7
Very fun game.  Very cutthroat, and quite tense.  The role choosing is a great mechanic and often leads to circular thinking (think the chalice with poison scene in The Princess Bride and you know what I mean), which is deliciously mind warping...  If I choose the thief he'll choose the assassin, but then he might kill the thief, so if I take the assassin I should kill the king, but what then if the thief takes my money...  Great stuff!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I can see why people like this game, but I really feel like it's obsolete at this point. The hidden role selection is done better in both Libertalia and Mission Red Planet, and the building of structures using resources in a tableau-like way has been done in countless other games. That being said, aside from the assassin, this is perhaps Faidutti's least chaotic design. Because of that, I do think this is one of his better games. It's just a little too bare bones for me at this point. If there were more roles and more of the buildings had special abilities associated with them, this would get a much higher rating from me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Initial rating: 9. Just awesome cards (9 because i don't like all the medieval stuff), i've immediately put them into sleeves. Artwork is awesome, colors are bright, backs of cards are also OK. Plastic "gold" is also awesome.

Rating after 2 PvP plays with my GF: 9.
Even though games were close, PvP card draft is what i like a lot. We scored 1:1 and i enjoyed playing most of the characters:

1) Assasin: Had cool assasination of Bishop whilst my GF had 3 blue districts
2) Thief: When i declared that King will be robbed, all the money was spent with Magician, so no luck for me:)
3) Magician: I used this card only once when running low on cards, swapped 2 for 5 cards. My GF also exchanged cards with deck, which i found very interesting technique to find cool districts
4) King: Two games I was a player with a crown (mostly) with no gold districts - so I didn't choose King.
My GF had 3 blue and 2 gold districts, and last two cards I passed to her were Bishop and King. I murdered Bishop, and she scored 2 gold. Nicely done.
5) Bishop: he is awesome if you have blue districts or you are about to play last round - so warlord won't be able to kill your district. That's how i won first game.
6) Merchant is best from colorful characters. Green districts happened to me all the time so having 3 gold and probably more from districts was awesome. Best move in first game was to get Merchant and Architector - 2 initial gold + 3 gold from Merchan't action + 3 gold from districts payed off - with Architect i've built 3 more districts with 10 gold. Uber round.
7) Architector is an awesome card to play. Not just you build 3 districts (more than enough if you aren't going to build a lot of cheap ones), but also draw 2 cards. Awesome that you don't only have Magician and primary action to draw cards.
8) Warlord: didn't pick any time. My GF tried once, but i had bishop.

Didn't touch any Dark City expansion cards yet.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Brilliant game, one of my favorites. It's so simple yet deep and the bluffing on the character selection is amazing.

The only down side about this games is the cards wear very quickly, we only played it 3-4 times and there was marks on the cards (we are very careful and never had problems with other games). If a character card gets marked it can really spoil the game so would recommend to sleeve the cards.

RATING: 9
"Un Muy Buen Juego"
 La verdad es que ciudadelas es uno de Esos, que sin duda merecen el puesto de pertenecer a culquier ludoteca: Un precio justo, unas mecanicas excelentemente bien implementadas y que sin duda funcionan a la perfeccion entre ellas, unos compontes de buena calidad (en el caso de la tercera edicion en España, por que la ultima  de 2016 deja muchisimo que desear) y la diversion en grupos de 4 a 8 jugadores esta garantizada gracias a los "roles ocultos" que sin duda es lo mas divertido.
 Es tan sencillo que directamente "no tiene fallos", facil de aprender y dificil de dominar.
Sus aspectos menos destacables, en mi opinion, es que es un juego que a 2 y 3 jugadores se queda corto y pierde parte de la gracia, esta pensado casi para un ,minimo de cuatro aunque ba muy bien tambien a dos y tres. El arte es muy bonito, aunque a mi personalmente no me gusta demasiado (parece como si estubiera hecho de diferentes piezas no relacionadas entre si) y por ultimo, como ya dije, la ultima edicion en España, es desastrosa tanto en calidad de componentes como en el hecho de que no hayan inluido la expansion.
En resumen: 100% recomendado (salvo la ultima edicion, que al menos que querais tener algo caro que quemar en la chimenea no os la recomiendo)
Un saludo a todos

RATING: 6.5
This is an interesting and quite ingeniously devised city/VP building card game with nice art (and controversial nudity - zoinks!), fast playing turns, cunning tactics and devious treachery, and low-ish overall game time where you’re constantly guessing at your opponent’s moves to maximise your own.  Actually really enjoyed this as a sort of filler game, though I could see how it could go long.  Worth picking up for less than £20, but not sure it would get much play in our collection as it's just not meaty enough.  Another top bloke James Fallows taught us the game, and soundly kicked our arses too – thanks for that James if you’re reading!  You’re going to teach us Magic Realm next time whether you like it or not…  :)

RATING: 6
Citadels is a clever game, and I like the interaction of the roles. I have played most of my games with only 3 players, and when you get to see the pile of roles twice each turn, it really adds to the brain hurting.  You are able to make more intelligent decisions, but it also weakens the thief and warlord.  With more players, the game is still quite fun.

I have 2 main problems with Citadels.  The first is that the game really depends upon the people you play it with.  People who will get offended or upset by what happens in the game should not play, because they will ruin it for everyone.  This means that Citadels isn't always the easiest game to get to table, despite being playable by a wide range of players.  The other complaint is that luck can play a big role, as the quality of the building cards you draw can have a large effect.  But this is a pretty minor complaint, and the game is still enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Simply put, this is a painful gaming experience. I did NOTHING for three turns in a row, and each turn is probably about 5 minutes long. Any game that can allow a player to be sitting around doing nothing for 15 minutes while your opponents advance automatically loses a lot of points, in my book. It's just not fun to cross your fingers, hoping that someone doesn't assassinate you this turn, or steal your money, or do some other god-awful thing to you that sets you back beyond any help. There aren't that many interesting decisions to make, either, beyond choosing your role (which I find frustrating anyway). Do I take money or take cards? That's it. And I also notice that you run low on both a few turns into the game, and you're never really able to generate a full hand of cards again, making your decisions even less exciting. I'm sorry, but it will take a lot to make me play this game again.

RATING: 7
I love Citadels. It keeps me on the edge of my seat. There are so many mind games that take place during the game that I love. "I wonder if she took the thief or the assassin?" "I hope they think I chose the architect instead of the noble". And so on. The art is also incredible, especially on the manor and the park. I LOVE those cards. But this game also has some flaws in my opinion. In the two and three player game, especially the 3 player game, the assassin and thief are broken. They seem to be the strongest characters so they always get chosen, which is annoying. And if you are playing with many people, you end up waiting a really long time for everyone to choose their character. I think this game is best with 2,4, or 5 players. The 2 player variation is super strategic and fun. Anyways, this a solid game that I can get new gamers to enjoy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The fun, interesting dynamic in this game is choosing roles: assasin, thief, magician, king, priest, merchant, builder, and soldier. The trick is that you do not know who chose what role, as it is a secret choice from the remaining cards of roles. These characters have special abilities and you interact by doing something against another character (e.g. assasin announces they will kill the merchant) so you cannot specifically target another player, only a role that was chosen. There is a lot of double guessing in that aspect. Victory is obtained by building to 8 buildings anc counting VPs. However, there is lot of luck with hands being switched, the soldier burning down other people's buildings, the assasin not killing the right person, etc. so it should not be played strategically, since one could get assasinated multiple times or robbed, taking away the fun factor. English version of the game introduces the witch, and takes away only one action from the chosen character, which seems more balancing than someone getting assasinated and losing their whole turn. On the plus side, this game works with 7 people. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Goes a bit long with a big group but still good.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
[b] Citadels[/b] by [person=125][/person]

2-8 players

A race to build a city. Medieval fantasy setting. Best with 2-4 players. Becomes more chaotic and slow with more players added.

Apr 2, 2014 note: recently played 2-player game. Played very similar to the 3-player. Very enjoyable!

A very interactive tactical game, with lots of second guessing what your opponents shall do next, mostly which character roles shall be chosen on a given round. Each role offers up a different ability which aides in building your city, or destroying your opponent's.

Rules are simple.

Note:
Purchase card sleeves for the character cards, which tend to wear down quickly (due to constant character card shuffling), making it easy to spot and differentiate the original character cards from the expansion's character cards, which might not be used as frequently. It's very important that players cannot spot the variance, since the character roles are secretly chosen, and not revealed till played. 

This is one game that truly needs the sleeves. 20 would be needed (expansion characters included), so one pack of sleeves should suffice. I use MayDay Premium USA Chimera Game Sleeves (57.5mm X 89mm, pack of 50).

However, if the original cards are already worn down, and the new expansion character cards are not... you should purchase sleeves, which aren't totally transparent. They should have a black backing.

Check out the game designer´s interesting game blog, it is both in French and English: http://faidutti.com/blog/

Interesting article about the game designer:
http://www.mechanics-and-meeples.com/2006/05/22/bruno-faidutti-professor-of-chaos/
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Then there are the games where I feel totally clueless and get knifed every turn by the assassin.

RATING: 4
Mechanically and even theme wise (though some of the theme is a little abstracted ... how exactly do you "play" as so many different people, what does that mean?) this is a pretty tight game.  Simple, light, no noticeable flaws (though I hear high player counts can be labourious). For many an ideal filler and gateway.  I just could not stomach the assassin, warlord, and thief roles.  Probably from watching too much Mr. Rogers as a kid (I don't actually think it possible to have watched too much Mr. Rogers, that guy was awesome).  Violence and vice doesn't always bother me in games, but in this case it did.  It all seemed so ... personal.

RATING: 2
12/30/2014

This game is balanced around the fact that the Assassin exists. Otherwise, the Merchant and Architect can run off with the game, because they circumnavigate the limited resources Citadels plays with. However, the Assassin is a "lose a turn" mechanic that can often revolve around pure guesswork. "Lose a turn" mechanics are not acceptable design, and so the design of this game is balanced on such a poor foundation.

RATING: 4
Pick a personality from hand of cards you have been passed, pass the remainder to the next player in line, then wait for your turn. When your turn arrives, do 2 things and then wait for everyone else's turns to end. Repeat.

Not sure why everyone loves this game so much. It feels long and there is too much waiting. Plus, if the Assassin or the Thief target you, you [effectively] miss your turn. Missed turn mechanics suck!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of my first euro-type games.  I love it, however new players find it hard to distinguish which character to grab when and why.

A role selection game that gives you benefits depending on what role you choose.  Your ultimate goal is to build a city of various colors and buildings to grant you end game bonuses, but the heart of the game is in the role selection.

If you are able to read your opponents and determine what roles they are going for, you have a clear advantage and might come out on top in Citadels.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
A pure role selection game, it can feel a bit like something is missing now that other games have taken the mechanic further and/or blended into a bigger game.  There is a ton of screwage as the assassin can cost you a turn etc...  I need to try the expansion characters.  One thing that annoys me about the production of this game is the characters have a lot of text, so much so that it cant all fit on the cards.  Fine, but why is the only place with complete text in the rule book?  Player handouts with the full text should be a MUST so as not to slow the game to a crawl when certain interactions come up.  Also, if you are playing with a larger group use the shorter game variant as this game can go too long for what it is.

RATING: 6
A superb game that is part deduction, part bluff, and part building. Highly interactive, as the actions of some characters can affect others, and (mostly) beautifully illustrated. A game that seems to improve with each play. I will say that 4-6 players are the limit for my taste, as less make it more of a race game and more tend to turn the chaos factor up to Gehena (or "11").

I absolutely adore this theme, and to me every game feels more like a fantasy story than a board game.

RATING: 3
Ugh... any game where you can lose turns or progress due to another player's arbitrary decision (thanks to the Assassin and Thief roles) loses major points in my book.  It's possible to lose multiple turns in a row if you're particularly unlucky.  One annoying opponent claimed to me that you have to use "psychology" to win, so I guess the game is *supposed* to be a fractured mess of second-guessing and analysis paralysis.  And really, what else is more fun than watching opponents scratch their heads trying to decide what roles to pick?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Attractive game based on players choosing different roles to carry out actions while searching for the most valuable combination of buildings, and quite possibly the game who took this mechanism (hitherto not used that often) back to the masses, ending up in Puerto Rico, Caylus and so on. While for many players it depends too much on who starts the round the game for two to four players is nice, tactical and quite malicious.

RATING: 7.5
Bel gioco, anche se non molto profondo. Valutando comunque che si tratta di un gioco di carte (ad un prezzo oltretutto molto basso) devo dire che è un buon acquisto. Le regole sono semplici e si adatta a qualunque tipo di giocatore, le spiegazioni durano relativamente poco. Buona giocabilità anche in 2 usando le regole speciali. La riedizione comprende anche l'espansione che lo rende più longevo. I personaggi originali secondo me però sono i migliori, ma il mio consiglio è di sostituire nel corso delle partite i personaggi che vengono scelti più spesso. L'ultima edizione non ha le monete di cartone e ha una scatola molto piccola, le carte invece rimangono un po' delicate. Consigliato!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Played
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
There's something rather beautiful about Citadels. I don't know whether it's the bluff and backstabby elements; the strategic but not overpowering resource juggling; the simple economy; or having a King who will read out the character list as if he's introducing pro-wrestlers (thanks, Stu!), but there's no better time to be had for a table of 5-7 people. Easily explained to beginners (who will become cut-throat powermongers after the first half-dozen rounds) and perfectly enjoyable by seasoned gamers who know the cards and can speed a game through. Best of all with a dedicated group of Citadels-nuts who can indulge in devious groupthink.

Faidutti has produced some first-class games, and a couple of absolute stinkers, but this is a work of genius.

Cheap         :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Quality
Abstract      :star::star::star::star::nostar: Themed
Light         :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: Heavy
Shallow Curve :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Steep Curve
Elementary    :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Complex
Tactics       :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Strategy

UPDATE: Shafi and Eric loved this game as a 3-player game. However, 2-4 player games are much different from 5-8 player games; the effectiveness of the Assassin and the Thief is different, and the effectiveness of the Architect seems to be increased greatly throughout more of the game in a 2-4 player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent game I am always willing to play. It may not seem like a really deep strategic experience at the first glance, but the brilliant thing about it is that the tactical part does not come from complicated mechanisms embedded into the game, but from player interaction. You have to guess what other people want and it can turn into some nice mind games and can reveal the way how other people think, when you discuss who picked which character and why (which is my favourite part of the game). It has also nice pace, but sometimes can be a little slow if people can't make up their mind in character picking phase. Also, I always thought that this game is only interesting in higher number of players, but recently my wife and I have been playing this game in 2 and we enjoyed quite a lot!

Also, the issues that people sometimes have with this game are easily solvable, luck of the draw could be mitigated by using the magician and a little longer than necessary playtime by simply agreeing on lowering the limit of buildings to seven.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game.  Role selection boiled down to its essence.

One of my favorite games of all time!

RATING: 4.5
Interesting decisions but there is a lot of down time with a large number of players as you go through the sequence 1-9 every turn. Can be chaotic, but I quite like the second guessing element, except that you don't know who you're targeting. One player might have her chances  completely hosed by getting hit several turns in a row. 

It's a shame it takes an hour-plus to play, if it were 20-30 minutes I would like it a lot more. Call me ADD, but my beef is that in that hour, you'll only get to play at most 8 cards (if you're lucky).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Dark city expansion is definitely worthwhile as well, it came together with my copy of the original so I've actually never played without the expansion.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
One of my favorite role-picking games. Doesn't hit the table often enough, mostly because I own ye old Deutche edition (Ohne Furcht & Adel) and nobody likes memorizing cards or grubbing through a xerox of Rio Grande's translated rules. A friend owns the English-language edition, complete with the secondary role set, and it's one of our favorite 7-player games.

That said, it's hard to feel like you're getting any better at this game. I've never recovered from a poor draw, and the ultimate outcome always feels very luck-based to me. This is typically a showstopper, but the whole "I know what you picked but I can only make educated guesses about everyone else" stuff is really compelling.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
BENJAMIN

Expansions:
Dark City
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a nice power selection game. To get the right timeframe we play to 7 cards, only allow destroying a building on the last turn if it directly improves the soldier's position in the game and keep it to 5 players max. This keeps the game ticking along at a nice speed and allows us to get through the bad part faster (the slow character selections) and to the fun part faster - the character revelations, especially the killer and the thief's targets.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great game that can scale up to 8 players.  A must have, IMHO.  I would rate higher, but I'm not as big as a fan with 4 (or less if using optional rules) players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The first game we bought when we decided to give our son an alternative to Junior Monopoly. It worked - say no more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nice role/character choosing card game where to main aim is to gain gold with a view to build buildings in your city. Best aspect of this game involves how the roles actually target each other, many of the roles ask you to name a character to affect rather than say the person on your left. This gets you thinking and guessing who grabbed what role and stops people from picking on say dad every round :-) or the leader per say. It's pretty easy to learn/play and the price with expansion now included is very reasonable. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow, what a fantastic discovery!  Had a great time playing five-player with friends.  Social as well as mind-bending.  I will always suggest this in future sessions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Truly a perfect and fun game. Unique card game to build a city in medieval times. Bluffing. Variable turn order and powers. Conflict. Great artwork and components with the FF edition which includes the the Dark City expansion. Everything about the gameplay that I enjoy about this game, some people absolutely hate. Every gamer needs to experience Citadels with a group of 5 or more. Besides, it plays much shorter than a 90 minutes game, especially if you play the 7 buildings variant.

I'd rather play this, than Coup, or Resistance.

Can play up to 8 players with the expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Tableau building along the lines of San Juan with simpler buildings, but with actual money. Each turn, each player selects a role in secret. Half of the roles are nasty and destructive, but since you target a role rather than a player, the effects are unpredictable. 

So: Tons of screwage, with tons of second-guessing. two of my least favorite mechanics. However, it's a well-designed game (as I figured it would be), and I didn't hate it quite as much as I thought I might. But I still really don't want to play it again.

Weight 2.1 seems about right. I would probably give it a 2.2.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My easy to take along game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of my favourit cardgames next to BANG! cool character select system and awsome design. The way players atempt to guess the opponents' choices is what makes this game shine, and since all players select character cards from the same deck... you can guess, thing is that one is always left out, so the secon player has only a 50% chance guessing which character the 1st chose... you can see where this is heading after the 3rd player is chosing, and then the 4th, and 5th... etc. Fantastic little card game with a great fun intrigue and "back stabbing". The illustrations are fantastic.

RATING: 8
A good game with interesting interaction and game play.  The theme might not be strong enough for some, since the game is relatively abstract.  Throw in the potential for some strong swings in the game due to the "luck of the draw," and there will be some that don't get much enjoyment out of this game.

However, the strategy and mechanics work quite well for me and most in my gaming group.  Play can get a bit long sometimes, so there's a preference for other games, but this one frequently comes out on game day.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
12/30/11 - Citadels is an interesting game with hidden roles to benefit you in your goal to build 8 districts. The artwork on the cards are beautiful and I don't mind the chaos the game causes. It also should be said that this is not a friendly game. You will be stealing and halting players choices.

My major complaint is the game length. Most people think of it as a filler and if it is a filler it should play in less than an hour. This game falls into the same area of games like Bonhanza and Farm Cards. They are fun but have a tendency to drag mid-game. Citadels also is a game prone to cause AP in players as the mull over which role to take.

I initial enjoyment has dwindled and I only like to play this occasionally. I am lowering my initial rating of 7 to a 6 because it describes how I feel about the game.

RATING: 6
Good card game that can accomodate lots of people, though it can slow down at large player numbers.  Role mechanic forces players to constantly guess which player has which role.  Random factor is pretty large, but the game is fun nonetheless.  Being assassinated is not fun, especially if you're losing anyway, but since the assassin doesn't know who he's targeting, it does happen.  Many of the tokens that came with my printing of the game are completely unnecessary.

(5+ plays)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
Citadels: a game where card drafting, identity deduction and special player powers all blend together to create a great social game. The objective is to build districts and earn points, but the core of the game is to "read" your opponents and balance between optimal/safe play. Play the merchant to quickly get much gold, but risk getting assassinated? Which character is that person who's stockpiling gold? Solid party game, great replayability.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
TRY Aug/04: Light & good fun!  Great game of trying to out-smart your opponents, and full of second-guessing with the hidden roles.  I love it!

OWN Nov/04: Can be a tad too long, if role-choosing is not done reasonably quickly!  But I've only really encountered that occasionally.  Very nice game.  I have some homemade player-aids (shrunken card photocopies with colour-matching for roles that it matters for).

Added to BSW Jan/05.  Implementation could be better, especially for the 2 gold vs. 2 cards/keep one.  The addition of English text was a blessing.

Aug/06: Tried with 8 of the expansion roles.  Still fun, but a different twist with no stealing or building destruction.

RATING: 8
This is quite a fun game: nice artwork, and difficult decision making.  The choice of which person to take is a fine balancing act between taking the "best" for you (but, at the same time, most obvious for the thief/assassin) or a character that makes you less of a target but also provides fewer benefits for you.  So far, we have only played with 4 or 5, and after an initial struggle to get the special rules straight, we have really enjoyed it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have played this game only with 6-8 people and with that much players the downtime is terrible, and not much else to think about while waiting for your turn (or chance to choose character) than about who will choose what role, while others try to counterthink that guessing. So in the end it feels rather random. Being assasinated and building destroyed in one turn, robbed from money and cards on the next turn while you are well behind in points is rather frustrating. I like games where you can screw other players, but if it is totally random, it is not so cool. Willing to try out a 2-4 player game.

update - if game goes in a good tempo as couple of last plays have been, it´s a quite ok game. rating 4 -> 6.


Update 2014-05: First play with 4 players - game works well and does not take long time. Rating 6->7

Would play it with 7-8 players again, but only if no AP players are present. It´s a light game afterall.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another true classic of the gaming world.  Citadels was the first successful game in the genre of secret role selection games. Each round a hand of characters is passed around. On your turn you choose one and pass them on.  After everyone has chosen, characters activate in a determined order, using abilities to ultimately gain cards and victory points.  This game has the added benefit of playing up to 8 - though it adds quite a lot of time to the game.  There is a new edition out this year (2016) with updated artwork.  If you don't have this in your collection, it is worth the investment
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Good duel as well as big group game which is not something that can be said of many games, includes secret roles with abilities to earn cards and money in turn to buy property types to earn VP

RATING: 7
Now that I've played with 4 players, I have to revise my comments.  I think this game is decent, and could be great with the right group, but its uses are pretty limited for my gaming life.  It has a weird niche between "easy-to-learn" and "passive-aggressive enough to fail with a family-gaming group".  The two-player variant is ok, but there are much better 2-player games out there.  I think it would be great as a medium-light filler game with a serious gaming group.  I also think it would shine best with 4+ players.  But since the bread and butter of my gaming is 2-3 players or family gaming, I'm content to play it at a friend's house, I don't think I need to own it anymore.

RATING: 6

Quite interesting game, allowing wide range of amount of players (2-8) what makes it very flexible. While the randomness plays the main role, helping yourself win requires good guessing what the opposing players are going to do.

The biggest disadvantage of the game becomes visible when playing with larger numbers of players, like 8. Each players actions takes some time and it's quite easy to get bored while waiting for your turn.

What is surprising the duel play, which uses different rules like allowing players to control two character is very playable and much more dynamic. Also the randomness is decreased in this variant.

RATING: 2
This game probably (maybe) deserves a 4, but based on BBG rating wiki and the fact that "I plan never to play this again" -- game gets a 2.  So boring, please make it stop.  I am inclined to want to like a game and have a good time, but something about this game makes we want to never play a game again.  I wish I was just being dramatic and joking, but I hated every second of playing this game.  Not enough depth and what decisions you do have seem random and boring.  I love random, but this game is the epitome of when random is not fun.  I also love games like this where you have to read your opponents (see: Battlestar Galactica), but even when I successfully guessed my opponents moves and blocked them -- I didn't really care.  Thinking about it now, maybe the theme (or lack of an interesting one) is what really hurts this game on top of finding the passing the cards mechanic slow and tedious.  I am not an AP prone player, but this game makes you feel like you need to be one... so screw you game!  Like this review, I can only think of one thing when picturing playing this game again -- please make it stop.

RATING: 6.5
What I enjoy about this game is the fact it's a great role-guessing puzzle game. There is, however, a trick to teaching the game. When introducing the game to a new player, introduce each role two to three at a time, with the Thief and Assassin being last, and it's a smoother transition to the more nuanced aspects of the game. It plays quick, has plenty of brain burning moments, and has many opportunities for table talk. It's probably one of the highest rated game here that has a genuinely significant bluffing aspect to it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

Play with the Thief and Assassin and people get really upset, but play with the Tax Collector and the Witch and it seems too nice.  Add to the fact that it plays best with 7 and yet 7 takes the longest, and, well, I'm not that nuts about it.

I've found the secret to not hating this game: not caring.  But that, in itself, is part of the problem.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

Can sometimes suffer from kingmaking in the mid-to-lategame, if roles are badly used. But still an elegant game, best with 6+ (if people play briskly). 

A chatty gaming group helps to alleviate the slow turns as other people pick their roles; this is a double-edged sword, though, because without dialogue it can seem like a very slow game.

The challenge and depth of the game (as well as making correct reads on your opponents) is variable to the skill of the people with which you are playing.

RATING: 8
Fun with the right people, but repeated assassination/theft can embitter folks who take things too seriously.  

Note that the English version of the Smithy card has a typo that makes it too powerful.  House rules say it should read "pay three gold to draw two cards" (as it does in German), not "pay two gold to draw three cards."

Card sleeves strongly recommended at least for the character cards.  The edges will become worn.

NOTE: Want-in-Trade is in reference to the Russian version only.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Solid game. I would of enjoyed it more if I would of never played San Juan before which shares similar mechanics. Contrarily to SJ, Citadels has players intervening against each other (which can really set you back in the game when you get robbed and assassinated a couple of times in a row) but the various characters and actions available seem less interesting than the actions available in San Juan. Both games have their share of luck of the draw, but they are manageable. I'm glad I bought it for 20$, that's what I feel this game is worth. A nice change of theme and a little deduction play when we want some variety.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Such a simple game, with so much neat interaction. The different characters, their selection mechanic, and the fact that you can be any of them makes this a very satisfying and fulfilling experience. For such a small price, you get a game that is sure to keep a good size team (up to eight players) going at each other influencing the noble to be able to gather enough power to construct the buildings in their section of the city. Very good social game, and as opposed to other games that pit people against each other, the character selection here makes it hard for "grudge" matches to occur. It is everybody against everybody, so in the end, no one is particularly targeted. I would think someone on a budget or just figuring out if board gaming is for them, this is a great inexpensive way to start.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
City-building card game with secret role selection & plenty of opportunity to be nasty to each other. Can be great fun with the right group.

For 2-7 players (or 2-8 with Dark City expansion, included with latest FFG edition). Mid-length playing time. Plays quite differently with 2-3 players.

WARNING: Can take several plays to grasp how the roles work for new players. May be long down-times with lots of players if everyone takes a long time choosing roles (improves with familiarity).

WARNING: NEEDED CARD SLEEVES (lots of shuffling of character cards)

RATING: 8
At first this game appeared far too simple to please my tastes, but the more I played the more it grew on me. I discovered a rewarding system that provokes constant thought into trying to determine what your opponents are thinking and how to react. Each draw phase is filled with tension and many choices. My problem with most card games is the enormous luck factor usually associated with them, but I do not feel this way with Citadels. Many people complain that the same person can have the King throughout game, though this is a losing strategy.

RATING: 7
A hit with every group. Non-gamers love this as much as gamers. A classic. A lot of guessing, anticipating and reacting to other players. Not a game I'll ever get really excited about, but on the other hand it's one I'm always willing to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Originally played Ohne Furcht und Adel with 5 and 6 players, so language accessibility and quick game pace wasn't there for me. 3 years later and playing this version with 4 was an improvement, but still suffers from the downtime feeling due to most of your evaluation being enforced on your turn rather than during the turn of others. You really don't have much to consider except the district values of your opponents. So this really is a social/lunchtime game which allows casual talk and eating to pass for entertainment, which isn't too bad a thing. I love the game play which is simple and smooth. In some ways I prefer this method of role selection (rather than the way it is used in Puerto Rico) as not only is there deduction and bluffing, but with 4 players causing 3 characters to be put aside, evaluation of what's available in each round is less repetitive. Now have played with 3 which is no better, but with 2 players this game truly shines, with less downtime. The assassin is less of an issue, and the discarding of characters introduces bluff and double bluff. But my brain needs two things to take this game over the 7 rating: a scoring track to take the strain off counting individual coins (why not numerals)and a memory/deduction aid to cope with recording and chaotic resetting of character selection (I much prefer the permenant role selection in Bang, then you can focus on other things).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

- foreseeing players chooses gives too small advantage
- no strategy, no tactics, no economy

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
-

This is a party game with good player interaction. It is not a strategy game, just requires some educated guessing, minor deductions, and minimal tactical play. It can be too long for a party game and you definitely need to have some player aids (the list of characters and their special functions.) The game should probably be played with 5 or 6 players. With more it will be too long, with less it is not very good.

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Fairly simple card game, but there are a variety of strategies available. Since most of the mechanics rely on guessing who chose what card, there's a lot of potential for bluffing.

Game would be better if there were more role cards at once, though. I know the expansion gives you more role cards, but they're designed to be replacements. If you shuffled the role deck and then drew 8 and those are what people had to choose per round, I think that would be a bit more interesting.

Also, I wish there were more district cards that had special functions, and that the ones with special functions weren't always purple. I'm thinking of San Juan - having all/most buildings do something special would make this game MUCH more interesting.

RATING: 6
The first tabletop game I played in a board games cafe. It became my first geek purchase on this list. What I didn't like is the Assassin role. The Witch in the expansion makes life less difficult for the victim.

For Dark City: New districts with abilities definitely increased the rating for me. What I didn't like was that the rules state that I can only place a few new purple districts to the base deck and if I want to add more I would have to replace with those already in the base deck.

So I went ahead and shuffled all the new purple districts inside and had great fun but it also made me realised why that rule was in place. Because there will be too many purple districts and I'm not getting gold for building most of them when I have a role that gets gold for building a district with the same color as my role(e.g. Merchant/Bishop/King/Warlord)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game can be a lot of fun under the right circumstances.  For me, those circumstances include the following:

1) Not a large group.  5 players is probably pushing it.  There's just too much down time during role selection with a lot of players, and the game can really drag.

2) Play with the right players.  The game can be very unpredictable, and it's likely that some players will get hit with the assassin and thief a lot more than others.  Don't play with somebody who is going to freak out if they get assassinated while in last place.

3) Don't play too often.  I don't enjoy this one nearly as much if I have played it recently.  I think with this game the frustration level builds up to a certain threshold and then the fun quickly diminishes.

In the right setting I really enjoy this game.  There is so much second-guessing with the role selection, which lends the game a certain degree of subtlety.  It's generally a bad idea to take the role which would give you the greatest benefits.  Instead, there's an art to choosing one that is non-obvious and yet still beneficial.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I consider Citadels a good second-level gateway game. I think it is best played with 4-6 players. It takes at least a few rounds at least (or a couple of games at worst) to get the hang of the gameplay.

In Citadels, you aim to be the first player to build 8 districts. To do so, in each round, you choose a certain character such as King, Magician, Thief etc. Each character comes with associated special powers and is useful at different stages / situations in the game. There is an element of luck, but knowing your fellow players and working out their strategy and tailoring yours appropriately plays a significant part in how well you do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This game introduced me to the "role selection" mechanic and I loved it. The rest of the game is pretty simple and straightforward. This makes the game easy to explain while keeping it challenging enough even for experienced gamers.

The main downside of the game is that it doesn't play well for 6-8 players despite what the box says. Games tend to be super long and slow paced which can bore out a lot of people. There are usually better options for 6-8 player games imo.

RATING: 7
Great little game about building cities choosing a hidden role at each turn.
It blends a unique gameplay with a terrific artwork.
The easy rules leave room for strategy, tactics, luck and even psychology.
Unlike others, I enjoy the fact that games tend to end very close because expert players focus on blocking and attacking each other, neutralizing their expertise advantage, so newbies, kids or poorer players may have their chances.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This one is a true classic. There are a lot of strategies and counterstrategies to be played. In my opinion, the Assassin's a bit too good in the 2 or 3 player game, where you can pick him and then get another chance to see what your opponent didn't pick before deciding who to target. With four or more players, Assasin is fine and people need to learn to live with it and play the mindgames that make Citadels so good. This game is small but deep, and great from a monetary-value perspective.

EDIT: After further plays, this game really doesn't work with 2 players. It kinda works with 3, but I'm still not impressed. 4 or more is fantastic though.

Tentative rating: 7.5/10. More plays needed at higher player counts. Also consider Masquerade or Libertalia for similar games.

RATING: 8
I love the bluff and psychology of the role selection mechanic.  The endgame seems to sometimes just be a hope that no one screws you over while you try to finish your districts rather than any great strategic decisions.  The downtime is kind of a bummer, man, but not too bad if you have a lively group.
 
 
This is easily the most played game I own outside of Tichu. It's easy to pick up, and I play with a lot of people who enjoy fantasy themes, so it hits the table a lot. I enjoy it even more lately, it's just fun.

RATING: 8
Nice amount of bothering-other-players combined with trying to get ahead. I think it works better as a two-player variant we made up, in which each player takes the place of two normal-game players, player 1-and-3 and player 2-and-4. The assassin and thief seem like strategically poor choices in multi-player games, especially the assassin (*maybe* costing *one* other player 'one' at the cost of definitely costing yourself 'a half'), but a valid choice with only two players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I prefer this to a bunch of hidden role games because there are lots of ways to mitigate the inherent variance. Each role is, at the very least, pickable in some situation, even if there are some that are really good overall. The Architect has been on the wrong end of the Assassin's blade probably more times than any of the other roles combined.

The biggest problem is that the game tends to drag excessively with more than about 4 people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
As good as it gets when it comes to card game design which pushed the boundaries of card games. The core is the role selection and a winning condition which makes the endgame rather frenzy and tactical (who will get there first). Rounded up by a nice light fantasy theme, which is not too silly or high fantasy to put any games from the extreme spectrums off.

EDIT: I found that my sweet spot for this game is three players (just like 7 Wonders). More than four makes this less enjoyable for me

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Yet another gem purchased solely on BGG recommendations.  A game you don't need to be ashamed of when you push it on your casual (party) gamer friends.  Rules can be explained in less than five minutes, and after a round of play most players "get it".  It's deceptively simple, and new strategies are constantly emerging as you play.  The theme is very fitting and gameplay is intuitive.  Loads of player interaction (it can get a bit nasty with all the backstabbing possible, so don't play with sensitive types).  The dullest time in the game is waiting for other players to pick their characters; use this time to plan your strategy for the upcomming turn.  Other than that, there's barely a dull moment in the game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game. Also easy to explain and good to catch new players. It gets a little bit too hard when you play it often with the same group of people, but still is great and has a high replay-ability.

Plus ont est mieux c'est

RATING: 7
We don't play this game enough. I see where a lot of people rate this very low, saying it doesn't work and takes way too long. I also see these people usually have played with 7 or 8 people.

We have always played with 4 or 5 people. This means that some of those potentially problematic roles may not be in play every round. The "assassinate or steal from the Merchant or Architect" doesn't work because it's likely one of those cards isn't available in the round. Which lifts the danger of picking those roles a good degree.

RATING: 7
Based on 1 play. I wouldn't say Citadels is UNbalanced, but the mechanics do not have a buffer to prevent IMbalanced, frustrating, unfair play. Namely, the 1st player was King for 5 straight rounds, through choosing it and it being the 1 buried role. This inability to change start player leads to inequitable and inferior play. While I can accept this design flaw, I do note it and how it decreases the quality of the game.
Would like to play again to get a different session to base opinions on.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
i really enjoy playing this game with two or three players*. im not sure how balanced some of the character powers are, but you have to be willing to switch gears in this game and sometimes not make the best play, in order to throw off the players who select the thief and assasin. this game is very tactical in nature, but that's what keeps me intrested in a good card game-tough tactical descisions. i really like the bluffing aspects in the two player game. i never play until 8 buildings, no matter the number of players. 7 is a fine number of buildings to play to as far as i can tell. 

*arguably, the 3 player game needs a few tweaks to work well. played with the rules out of the box, the player who is the king has too much of a strategic advantage over the other players. i find that removing the assasin in favor of the witch and adding one of the expansion characters--the navigator, tax collector, or alchemist--as a ninth card dulls the starting advantage well enough. i play with my cards in sleeves, so it is easy to alter the number of the card by placing a sticker on the front of the card with the new number.

RATING: 7
It's good to be the king, unless you're playing Citadels. I don't mind being assassinated, it's the tediousness of trying to build your city one card (or two if you're really lucky) at a time and then having some lucky sod destroy a card or steal all your money that gets me annoyed. Even with 2 players I found the game slightly dull. The characters are interesting and I like the second guessing, but the slow play annoys me. 

Update: Using the optional rule of one less building card to quicken the game up has worked really well. Completely different to the snore fest of previous games.

RATING: 5
I could imagine enjoying this more if I knew what I was looking for in the card deck.  I had a hard time remembering what all of the action cards did and I didn't know what I was looking for in terms of cards to play in my tableau.  My rating would probably improve if I were to play this game more. Even so, I've got other card games that I'd rather play, so Citadels is not a game that I need (or want) to buy.

Also, it makes me feel like a jerk!  Either I'm terrible at the game or I am great at the game and I know just who to target to get the maximum amount of their stuff.  It makes me sad.  I don't play games to feel sad.  That's why I'm not a huge fan of Citadels.

Yet I can see that it is a good game for someone who really enjoys a lot of take that! in their games.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When I first played Citadels I was completely blown away by how good it was. It instantly became my favorite deduction game and I truly loved the role selection mechanic. After playing a few games my rating dropped down because I found the game to drag on for too long. As soon as someone was close to building their 8th district everyone would go after them making the game take longer. It got to the point where I would select the warlord late in games so no one would be able to destroy districts. I will never play this game with more than 4 again, just takes way too long in between turns. I will also only play if the house rule of needing 7 (not 8) districts to end the game is in play. Would like to try it with 2 people.

Update: I finally got to play this as a two player game.  I think being able to discard one of the roles after you pick your own is brilliant and adds another layer to this game. In my opinion playing with 2 is the only way to go with this one.

RATING: 8
This is a game I push to play as often as I can, and have only managed to play twice.  The first time I won handedly, and the second time, despite being the constant target of assassinations and thievery, I still came in second.  I really enjoy the thought process of guessing who took what, or even better, what people are going to think you are going to take, and acting accordingly.

As an update, I've managed to play this a few more times, and still love it.  Even if I lose horribly, I still take great pleasure out of figuring out what everyone will take.  It's hard to beat that feeling when you predict how an entire round will go and swing the entire game as a result of having it figured out.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An interesting role choosing game.  There is some ability to try and get in people's heads, but there is also a lot of collateral damage along the way.  That is perhaps the major strike against the game: being assassinated or stolen from too often can put you out of the running, but it might happen with you as only be an innocent bystander hit by bad luck or incompetence.  The game can support a large number of players and is fairly straight-forward. I think I'd rather play Adel Verpflichtet which feels a bit less vicious, but still fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.455
Really fun game.  Can teach it in 5 minutes and the new players can really enjoy the game.  Good interaction and anticipation in this game.

Every time I've introduced this game to a new group they've either requested an immediate replay, or asked where they could buy a copy of the game, or both!

I can't think of anything negative to say about this game!  (edit:  I had one semi-negative experience where I played with a big group all of who were new to the game....it took WAY too long.  But that was an anomaly). 

The mechanic that everyone looks at the available cards, chooses one and passes the others has the potential to take a long time (especially when newbies aren't familiar with the cards).  If players read every card, every time they get passed to them, it will be slow.

Highly recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Description: Secret role selection, drafting, medieval fantasy city building, bluffing, set collection, tableau building card game.
Weight: Medium to light.
Number of players: 2 to 8 players. Best with 5 or 4.

Impression: Very interesting tableau building card game by Bruno Faidutti, in which players are choosing secretly a role from 8 (or 9) different roles numbered from 1 to 9 and passing the rest forward. After all roles are selected first player is calling their numbers starting from the lowest, at which point the player with that number reveals his selected card and performs corresponding actions. The goal is to build a city by playing city district cards in 5 different colors in your tableau by paying gold (usually). The first player to 8 districts triggers the end of the game after which the highest score wins. For every character you can chose, and all of them are fun, there is an alternative character in the expansion to keep the game fresh. 

Likes: Different roles with variable player powers. Bluffing. Purple districts with special powers.

Dislikes: Too long for a light game (with more players). Not good with fewer players. Large downtime. Possibility of players losing their turn against their best effort. King making and player induced imbalance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Feel that citadels is best with 4-5 player. Looses its speed and deduction at higher player counts

Decent party game. Great gateway game to introduce newcomers to gaming.

RATING: 7
This soon became one of my favourite games when I first played it way back in 2011 - and while I now prefer heavier games, I still think Citadels is excellent as an occasional game when you're looking for something light but not a mindless filler. While I hear that it can go on far too long with 7 or 8 players, we rarely play with more than 5, and it's about the right length with 3,4 or 5. In my opinion, it ranks alongside 7 Wonders as a quickish game for more or less any number. And 7 Wonders doesn't have mind games and "bluffing" like this. (I still prefer 7W, but Citadels, despite being very different, fills a similar niche.) Table talk is a must with Citadels (provided of course it is not overdone to the extent of giving away information to players that they shouldn't have).

Couderches
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
For me Citadels has all the right ingredients but suffers greatly from inherent flaws that make it a "I'll play (without great excitement) but never suggest" gaming option as it's a game with potential that rarely transforms into an enjoyable gaming session for all involved.

Most notably, with 5 and more participants, you will often see a player at the bottom of the table with no option to remedy the situation early enough to have a fighting chance. He will often then play kingmaking throughout by sniping whoever he happens to be fairly sure has selected a role, whether that player is in a good position or not.

... thinking about it just now, this game is depressively broken, yet too cleverly fine-tuned to be easily 'fixed', despite the dozens of house rules that can be found on these forums. I can't think of any other game that can claim to be more than a prototype yet feels like one.

Played with 2
Played with 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game is at the top of my list to play for good reason. There are so many strategies that it boggles the mind. Should you try and out build your opponents, steal their cards, take their money, or just assassinate them. You never know who has which role and the roles change each turn.

People with great intuition for what the other person will do seem to always win or at least have a great shot at winning.
Most games are close and I keep the game moving so it does not drag on. I have yet to play this game and not enjoy it.

RATING: 3
Played with 4 players. Didn't like it all. Game felt long and unexciting. Maybe we played with a poor strategy, but there seems a big flaw in the game: The king of the previous round will choose his character first. The other players can do nothing of stopping him to be the starting player again. Even if one player picks the murderer and murders the king, he will be the starting player in the next round again.

Note, that in the 4 player game the murderer was not chosen very often (in fact, only once at game end) because his character is one of the less powerful ones.

Boring!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my all-time favourite games. Exellent with anywhere from 2 to 8 players, and it's easy to teach. I really like it as a 2 player game in particular, but the dynamics with a larger group can be equally entertaining.

My only small critism is that in a 3 player game, if you're paying attention, you can always name a character chosen by an opponent in a given round (when using the Assassin and Thief abilities). Because you see the character deck twice, whichever two cards are missing from the first time you saw the deck are necessarily the ones your opponents picked. You won't know which opponent chose what, but that doesn't matter that much; you'll be setting someone back for certain.

To correct this problem, in a 3 player game I suggest adding in the Artist (from the Dark City expansion) to the character deck. Then, before the starting player chooses his or her second character in a round, randomly discard one of the remaining characters face down. This means that the Assassin and Thief have a chance of naming the wrong character.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

One of the best card-board-pocketsized-party game ever ! Regular game (not filler) packed to small box.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Oh, Citadels! This game got me into the hobby initially and it has earned a special place in my heart. Something in Citadels always creates an enjoyable mood, both relaxed and tense at the same time (save for occasions when somebody just doesn't accept the game). Antisipation of other players choices and desire to see if you'll be able to execute your plan for the turn mixes with unobtrusive friendly talk, which usually occurs due to short turns with long time between them, and it all results in a very pleasant atmosphere. It's not for everyone's liking, but when you have the right group, this is one of the best games to play.

RATING: 4
--Dec2003-- Don't really mind the random factor that some have complained about.  Not too bad with 2, either.  Fun, and not particularly serious:  appropriate, given the author!
--Oct2011-- After a few years of not playing, my view has changed.  Today, it seems unfortunately capricious to the degree that I'd usually prefer to play something else.  I enjoy the game for a half hour, after which the continued knocking down the leader begins to manifest as tedium.
--Nov2014-- With the advent of [thing=170340]あやつり殺人事件[/thing] (which takes the character selection mechanism of Citadels for something shorter and admittedly sillier) I find myself even less inclined to play.

RATING: 7.5
A card game about building your own citadels by hiring different helper each round. Those helpers have cut-edge special power which is more dominating than assisting (like the assasinator, who can stop you from an entire round!). The key is to survive from the assasination and to play large (expensive) cards. Once you succeed in playing the University, the game is yours. This game has down time, so prepare for an in-game dose ^_^

RATING: 5
Gift
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game and Bang are the two best card games I own.  This game is a ton of fun, even though there is a bit of chance involved.  One game my poor friend got thieved or bewitched every round but once.  The poor guy just couldn't pick something that nobody wanted to not tamper with, so he finished the game with only a few districts.

My $20 copy came with the expansion that included doubles of the main card numbers for a completely flexible game.  And I think it plays 8 people instead of 7.  Including this expansion in the box set makes this game a must buy IMHO - the game has a lot of bang for your buck.

Recommend Adjustments: When I play, I always swap out the 1. Assasin card for the Witch,  and the 8. Warlord card for the Diplomat.  I find that these two expansion cards aren't so mean spirited as the originals, so players targeted by these two cards aren't hurt so badly.  This helps keep it fun for everyone.  Again, this is a great game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I've only played the German version (Ohne Furcht und Adel) without the expansion cards, and only with two players. 

Of the two-player games which I have played with my girlfriend, this is probably the best. It's not complicated; it's the first game in which she has gone beyond understanding the rules and actually started thinking about how to win. In particular, I like the game of bluff and double bluff as you try to convince your opponent that you have taken a different character to the one that who have actually taken. I also like the fact that in the two-player game you can choose two characters each turn, making different combinations of skills possible. Overall, good fun.

EDIT: That said, the whole 50/50 guess with the Assassin is beginning to get a bit tiresome. I'm dropping my rating from a 7 to a 6.

Gave away when I left Germany.

RATING: 7
An enjoyable game of city building. The 'hook' of choosing new roles each round really makes this game, as it provides the player interaction. I appreciate that you can tell how well you are doing as you go along (unlike, say, Ticket to Ride) but there's still a little suspense as to who will win, based on the 'first completion' and 'one of each type' bonuses. Highly successful with non-gamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My favorite role-selection game. Easy enough to play with non-gamers as well (most of the time).

One drawback is that it sometimes ends up in a "stuck" situation where it drags on before someone finally triggers the endgame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like this game for two big reasons:

1) It can be taught to almost any non-gamer and grab their enthusiasm. (In the past half year, I've 'inspired' at least two non-gamers into buying their own copy).

2) It's a relatively small box and relatively short playing time, so it can be taken with me on many occasions.

The bluffing aspect of this game is what makes it so great. Bluffing about the role you're going to pick for your turn, bluffing about the 'quality' of the building cards you hold in your hand.
It works quit well as a two-player game too. My girlfriend loves to play this with me and kicks my ass all the time.

RATING: 10
After many years and many plays, Citadels has shown itself to be a special game. It remains Faidutti's masterpiece, a great piece of design that feels more and more like it's been forgotten. It's a shame too, because some of what's done here is astonishing. The eight roles all feel so well considered. They pull at each other perfectly, and the game is such that all of them are picked at any given time.

The only downside is that it can sometimes run a little long. But in my experience this is more a function of people playing poorly than the game itself.

There are way better board games that fit this 8 Player range than this. I have not played this with 3-7 Players but I would suspect this: I would try with 4, maybe 5, and feel 6-7 players will bog it down way too much again. All in all, I do not pull this game out too often.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Citadels is a role-based card game where players are racing to be the most prosperous city by building districts into your own city and possibly sabotaging the efforts of your rivals.  There are 8 different roles in the game, each offering a different power including, causing another role to lose its turn, stealing money from another role, swap hands with another player, get first pick of roles, protection, earn extra gold, build 2 districts in one turn, and destroy a rival's district.  Each turn the King shuffles the roles, discards 1-3 roles at random (one face down), then chooses from the remainder; each player then chooses a role from the remaining roles.  Each player acts in the order of their role which are numbered 1-8, with the lowest number going first.  In addition to acting on their special powers players must decide to either collect 2 gold or draw cards on their turn, then they have the option to spend their gold to build a new district.  The game ends when a player has built their 8th district at which time the value of each district is calculated and the player with the most points wins.

Citadels is a lighter strategy game and once all the players know what each role does the game plays fast.  The hardest choice players have is choosing which role they want from those available.  The roles are varied enough in power that no one role is superior to another in the long run.  Player interaction is limited to affecting another role (not player), with the notable exception of the ability to pay gold to destroy rival's district.  The distinction between stealing from a role and a player keeps the game from having a "take that" attitude, as you don't know who picked which roles until it is that role's turn to act.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Initially exciting, but has lost a bit of its appeal to me (after about a dozen games).

Some of the characters feel a bit too much like no-brainer choices if you get to pick first i.e. assassin (can't get killed/robbed, might take someone else out, get to act first).

Feels like it should be a light snappy game, but always seems to take a bit too long for comfort.

Need to play more and try the expansion cards before forming a full opinion.

Might be better with a larger group - with 4 people I feel like the king doesn't get picked (or even not in the deck) as often as he should be, meaning that the picking order gets static quite quickly.

RATING: 8
Citadels is a "hidden role" with "role slection" game for the slightly-less-than-casual gamer. It involves a lot of second-guessing and trying to read other players, but actually doesn't offer much in the way of game talk. It is not a difficult game to learn, although leeway must be given for the first play. It is a city building exercise, though three roles, the assassin, thief and magician add player interaction by killing, stealing gold or stealing cards from other players in that order. This is a game that I play with non-gaming friends alongside Resistance, Telestrations and Dixit. I would definitely recommend this game if you don't have a similar game with hidden role selection like Libertalia.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

UPDATE Jun-27-2010:

RATING: 10
This game is one of the first that I owned and has hit our table numerous times. 
Apart from the game itself there are 2 main advantages which give it a TEN. 1st it can be played from 2 to 8 people giving an extreme flexibility. 2nd it can grab ALL kind of different people, from the strategic player to the newcomer and satisfy them as one of the most interesting games that they have played.
It is a mix of strategic play, psychological understanding of your opponents and screwing them at the same time and I have to admit that for me it is very difficult to win but the FUN compensates every play. Keep in mind that IMO it's also a WOMEN'S game and they almost always win:) The screw factor is their game. Beware of them...

RATING: N/A
Played a solo walkthrough of a 4-player session to learn the game. Stopped after building five districts (instead of eight). It looks like it could take awhile to get through a proper game of this. I can usually tell what I'll think of a game after a walkthrough, but this one left me uncertain. It's more than a 6 and less than a 10, but I'm not sure where it'll end up rating. It might be fun with the right group, I'm just not sure I know anyone who belongs to that group. Also, while I definitely like the butterscotch coins, the card quality of this FFG version is - as everyone else seems to mention - truly abysmal. The character cards are showing signs of wear after only half a session...Inconceivable!?!

RATING: 8.5
This game has roles (and special abilities) associated with turn order, and  every round you draft which role you want to play.  Some roles are more likely to effect other specific roles directly, and some roles won't even make it into the drafting pool.

Very cool that this game can play up to 7 players, and it's not too hard to explain.
