RATING: 7
Too much downtime and the potential to have long gaps between actions if you get killed too frequently.  I'll play it again, but it won't be my suggestion.  Not to mention that the decisions don't seem to make that big of an impact.  I finished with 15 points and was pretty close to players who had played much better than I had.

I have amended my rating due to how quick it plays in the free online version on Citadelles.net.  Against the AI's, it allows the game to just flow much better without all of the downtime.  A solid little game online that gets a 7 online as opposed to a 5/6 live.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This works better that it has a right to: It's very simple to pick up and play as theme makes rules intuitive. The interaction level is quite high. The roles make the game dramatic - Assassin more or less makes the game (thief and magician mop up the rest of villainy): the stakes are high as both negative and positive cards have strong aspects. 

Now, who you shouldn't play this with. As the bluff and doublethink are in the forefront, the game is actually better with seasoned gamers, though not necessarily seasoned in the game, but being mature, able to take on conflict and not to delve into some personal agendas or pure randomness. Also: while not necessary, the game is better with the right atmosphere that rides this drama I described - better with people who know each other and are loud. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Should be played with no less than 4 players. Beer-proof.

RATING: 6
Played 1 4P game. Of all the hidden role selection games I have played, this has the most 'take that' moments. It takes quite a bit of time to play because of the constant building up and destruction going on.

The role drafting mechanism is good, but also rather clunky in how it is executed. When playing with big groups, it takes a while for players to select their roles (as they have to pay attention to the possible roles taken, and the ones remaining) and it isn't very fun calling out numbers and waiting for players to respond.

RATING: 7
[4 plays] This has some depth, is very portable, plays quickly, and the role selection mechanic is nifty. There is some psychology here and some tactical considerations. But this can easily be treated as a light social filler game and enjoyed on a level similar to Bang!

I wasn't overwhelmed the first time we played this, but a lot of it has now clicked for me. I think I really like it now and look forward to more. 5 players seems like a very good number for this game. 3 players was also interesting.

Most recent play Nov '15 me, Garrett, and our kids.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
#91 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

Citadels was one of the first modern games that I learned, and I still think it's a great game. Players select their own role from the available characters- each of whom have a special ability. Everyone is trying to get the most points by accumulating gold and playing city cards into their tableau. Some of the character roles mess with other players, such as the Assassin (kills someone for the round) and the Thief (steals a characters money), so there is a lot of bluffing and double think that goes into choosing which character you take each round. Maybe the Merchant's power would really benefit you, but it might be too obvious that you'd select him, making yourself a target, which could mean you'd get no turn at all. Some of the cards also have powers that effect the gameplay. Games are usually fairly quick, though the ability of one character to destroy cards can extend the playing time. But this one has never overstepped its welcome with me. 

Acquired: College

Small Card

RATING: 4
Citadels can be played by 2-7 players, but with 5 or more, our games have bogged down horribly. After playing some fun 3 and 4 person games, I actually turned some newbies OFF to European games by trying to play a six person game of Citadels.

And the game gets really predictable with 2 players. So, I'd play it with 3 or 4 if requested. Those games were a hoot. It can be a lot of fun, but I still don't like the downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Wonderful game: one of the few that works great with larger groups.  A unique round structure: everyone secretly chooses the roles of Assassin, King, Bishop, etc, each blessed with a special ability.  The round is then played out not in the order of players, but in the order of roles, with the Assassin going first, the Thief going second, and so forth until all the players have moved.  Being predictable and choosing the role best for your situation can be deadly, as the Thief and Assassin target roles, not players.  To speed up play in larger groups, we recommend that new players think about the role they want as soon as they're done, as there can be a lot of downtime waiting for people to read about and select roles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Great "leveling" game to borrow from poker strategy, simple to learn.

RATING: 2
[2010-09-06]
Nagyon jól eltalált játék. Körönként más-más szerepekbe bújva feladat a legtöbb pontot érő birodalom leghamarabbi kiépítése. Változatos, izgalmas játék. A szerepválasztáskor adódhatnak hosszú gondolkodási idők.

[2017-02-16]
Egy játék van bekönyvelve, de nekem gyanús, hogy játszottam én már ezzel többször is. Arra is rosszul emlékeztem, hogy szapultam volna a játékot, de most ennek tényleg eljött az ideje. Egyrészt bármikor véletlenül megölhetnek és kirabolhatnak a játékban. Az ellenfél se tudatosan teszi legtöbbször még az adott szerep választását sem. Ha ez megtörténik veled nagy valószínűséggel nem tudsz nyerni a játékban. Simán megtörténhet akár, hogy megölnek és még a lapjaid is elveszik, ezek után tulajdonképpen már csak végigasszisztálod az egész játékot. A kezdeti épületek véletlenszerű kiosztása is nagy szerencsefaktor. A királycsinálás a hadúrral szintén a játék része. Aki ebben a játékban nyer az biztosan tudja, hogy nem a jó stratégiája, taktikája miatt nyer, hanem a szerencséje okán. A játék partijátéknak túl hosszú sok személlyel, óriási a holtidő. Kevés játékossal meg kevésbé lehet jó. Nagyon nehéz bármi jót találnom ebben a játékban. Nem szívesen játszanék többet vele. 6->2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6

Cons: the game I think has a tendency to allow someone to perpetuate being the lead player - but this is offset by the character abilities and if you "hog" one character you can suffer as you limit your playing scope. I find the warlord & magician is a bit odd as its the only ability characters that allow for 'player' targeting rather than 'character' targeting which is the way on which all the other characters such as the assassin and theif work so it can feel a bit personal at times - though its a nice mechanic to stop a leading player from winning.

Pros: this is a ripper of a game! In all, its interesting and easy but complicated enough to allow for fun player to player interaction and for 'secret strategies' which I always liked in a game. Pretty art work and some of the district cards have fantastic juicy abilities. We had great fun playing this with 4 players. The theme is nicely intergrated too.

RATING: 7
This is a clever card game that plays more like a board game.  One reason that I love this game is that it works so well with a wide range of players.  I have played 2-player and 7-players and just about everything in-between.  They are all good.  (Although 7-players can have too much down time.)

I heartily recommend this game.  It's small, so it easily fits in the bag, and it gives you a depth of options from 2 to 8 players.

I own a copy of the original Ohne Furcht und Adel, but I recently picked up a copy of the Citadels.  The Citadels version has 10 more characters, which can be used depending on your whims.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Seems like a solid game, and I could appreciate the deduction and strategy here. Unfortunately I think it's just "too long for what it is." Can't see ever really wanting to play this over other 90 minute time slot games. Too few players seems like it wouldn't work, but too many takes too long. I played with 4 players and that was probably actually ideal.

I think most games with good players will end up with perceived winner getting railed on until someone squeaks by, which makes the late game pretty tedious. 

In my one play I actually lucked out by the "King" being absent so many times in a row while I held the Crown that I was able to straight up dominate my opponents without them being able to pound me into submission (and probably kingmake someone else). But I got lucky.

Most of the cards (buildings) are boring. Half of the roles are boring. 

(4 Design + 1 Enjoyment)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A very good game. It's easy to learn and if you like player interaction and role-selection - this is a must try.

The core of the game is the character selection phase, where each player secretly chooses a character with different abilities. it's all about guessing which character the other players choose and then choosing the character that benefits you the most. With the wrong character you can loose you entire turn or all your gold and with the right one, you can either receive bonuses or screw your opponents.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
After playing online at http://www.amarriner.com I have gained a new appreciation for this game. It's always fascinating to speculate about who is going to do what, and immensely satisfying when your own guile pays off. Yes, it can be frustrating to be knocked out of the running because of a couple of random acts of violence or thievery; but that's life, isn't it?

RATING: 6
I really like this game with 2-3 players and dislike it with 5 or more. Every additional player further slows down the game. The special rules for 2-3 players make the game more dynamic and strategic since you can make nice combos when selecting 2 characters each turn instead of 1.

The extra characters are a nice plus since you can play a different selection of characters each game, by replacing a few of the original ones for the new ones.

It's usually recommended for big groups but I do the opposite and would never choose Citadels when I have a big group at the table, too slow and boring, play it with 2 or 3 people, 4 MAX!.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Just fantastic if played with the right group (people who can see this game as a fun one, not a serious "i have to win this" game) and with people who won't take it personally when they get assassinated or burgled. Fantastic artwork too - which I didn't know about, but was really surprised by. This is an easy game to teach, as you just tell what stuff does and in a few rounds people generally figure it out. Of course, the way the roles all work together is brilliant, as has been stated many times before. The only caveat I have is that I don't like this game with too many players - even though some people think that's a strength of this game. With more than 5 the game can take too long for what it is, in my opinion. And, I love this game as well with just two players - very snappy and fun. There is luck in the card draws, as this is a card game, but again, if you go in without being too serious there is a ton of fun to be had here. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good role selection game, requiring you to outwit your opponents, while still keeping an eye on the prize.

RATING: 7
Light chaotic fun in a pretty package.  I can see where this might get a tad formulaic with repeated plays.  Good, clean implementation of ideas.  I imagine the expansion would help keep it fresh for several more plays.  Pluses: easy to teach, opportunity for fun table talk, some challenge.  Minuses: getting stuck as last player for several rounds because the king is building royal buildings and getting asassinated, multiple levels of chaos prevent any meaningful planning.  Relatively easy to utterly destroy the leader.

RATING: 6

Best played with an outgoing group, or with friends; downtime can be an issue with serious gamers. With the right group, in the right mood, it's great fun; with the wrong one, it falls flat. It's a bit like Bang! that way. My enjoyment of both is inversely related to the solemnity of the room.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Players select roles and take turns in order building buildings of various types, some of which modify basic game play. Game ends in round when anyone builds 8th building. Get points for variety of colors, being first to build 8, etc. Most points wins. The key feature is the role selection where players take turns choosing a role, and everyone has imperfect knowledge about which roles were available for everyone to choose from (earlier in turn order know more, and have more choices). Roles do various things, like steal from another character, get a bonus income from specific building types, become starting player, etc.

The game takes ENTIRELY too long with more than 4 or so players. Also, it really stinks when you keep getting hit by the Assassin, and just sit there for much of the game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Mildly entertaining card game with a simple ruleset that plays fairly quick. Supports up to 7 players which is a huge plus.

RATING: 8.5
Fun game, though it can get rather chaotic at times.  Scratches a similar itch to Puerto Rico, but I can't take it nearly as seriously.  Probably a good thing, really!

Edit 11/15/09:  Citadels has certainly eclipsed San Juan in terms of my urge to play, and the two games fit into a similar niche.  Citadels has a screw-you factor decidedly missing from either SJ or PR, but it's light enough it doesn't matter.

Edit 01/08/13:  Revised up to an 8.5, which I suspect will be a constant rating going forward.  Top notch game, and a go-to title when I've got 3-5 players looking for some strategy but not too many rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I only played once with three and had a good time.  I think it would work best with four or more.  I've said this about probably 50 different games, but I would love to try it again!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love the blend of mechanics for this game.  Card drafting, role selection, money management, tableau building, and hidden roles.  They all work really well together.

The biggest complaint I have about the game is the kingmaker aspect.  Every time a player manages a good turn and ends a round with a stockpile of gold or nice special building the whole rest of the table sees blood and they can find themselves not having fun as they're robbed, razed, or forced to skip their turn only to see another player win unmolested with the "slow and steady" approach.

NEVER play this game with less than 4 players, it's awful.  Having the roles go around twice allows the first player to pick the assassin or thief and guarantees he will hit one of his opponents.  I think there needs to be at least some gamble that the assassin and thief completely miss to make the game balanced.  The thief is weakened a little bit unnecessarily too.  If the thief targets one of the roles that goes later in the round, since you play two roles you can use up all your gold with your first turn and give the thief nothing.  There are several other problems with Citadels when played with less than 4 that we've encountered as well, it is just not at all well-designed for that number, but I still think it is a good game for 4+ (although I have yet to play it with 7+ which I think would include the same early-pick assassin/thief issue as with less than 4).

RATING: 8
This used to be my favourite card game before I really got into trick-taking games. Reverse psychology is the central issue in this game, building comes second. I think it's best with five. With less, too few characters are used and with more it drags severely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game would be higher on my ratings if it didn't take so long.  I usually play with a home rule of 9 victory points, because that 10th one seems to take forever to get.  With 4 or 5 players this game can easily drag on for 90 minutes - far too long for a game that's essentially a stack of cards.  If you can manage to endure the length though, this game does role selection very well, and can lead to some tense and competitive decisions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[FFG 03 edition w/o expansion] {Medieval, city building, fantasy; double-guessing, variable-player-powers, role-selection, utility cards; optimal 4p} Citadel is a thematic card game. Each player chooses a character to help him each turn and tries to be the most successful architect in a fantasy land. The artwork is good but the quality of cards is average.  Besides, there are many unnecessary components in the box, which makes the game larger than necessary and expensive! :(

There is a lot of player interaction in Citadels.  The character selection is the core of this game, which provides the fun, decisions and even intrigues.  The game time is just right for 4-5 players (around 30 minutes) but it easily run long for 6-7 players (longer than 45 minutes). 

Citadels is balanced between luck and tactical moves in 4/5p game.  If a player is in short of a particular resource (building, card, gold), he can get characters to help himself.  It also offers several strategies for scoring - have 8 cheap buildings quick, opt for expensive buildings, opt for a collection of buildings, etc.  However, it becomes chaotic and has strong down time in 6-8p game. Thus, I prefer the short version (7 buildings) in a large group.

[Expansion] I won't buy the new expansion because I don't think it has any thing special. USD8 for the extra new 14 purple buildings is somewhat expensive. I would rather FFG can just provide a cheap package of the new 14 cards like Bang! A fistful of cards.

[Update] The new edition has nicer bits: color card-back, king-pawn, smaller box and color rulebook. It's more attractive.

RATING: 8
Crucial to enjoying this game is that you can play it with a group (the larger the better) which gets the roleplaying aspect of this game. Playing it "abstractly" (not building a city, but acquiring victory points; not assassinating an opponent, but forcing a player to skip a turn) is possible, but makes the game much less worth playing. Sadly, the character cards wear out quite fast -- consider using sleeves for them.

Two-player games are awesome as well.

RATING: 7
[u]Key Words:[/u] Medieval - Secret Role Selection - Card Drafting - 2-7 Players - 1h

[u]Summarized Opinion:[/u] 4+ players = too chaotic! Need to try with 2-3 players.

[u]My Rating Explained:[/u] Comment needs update.

[u]Verbose Assessment:[/u]

I've only played this game with 5 or more people, and the game is definitely too chaotic for me with that player count. People don't know what's going on, just do something, and invariably someone gets killed or mugged all the time. It sucks to be that guy.

But the design intrigues me a lot, and I can't help but wonder what it'd be like with 3 or 2. It seems to me that control would be a lot better, and I might enjoy the game more that way.

So I definitely want to try again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Role selection city building card game. At the start of each round players select one of eight roles, each of which provides a special power e.g. the assassin allows you to murder one of your opponents' roles, the king becomes the starting player, the warlord allows you to destroy one of your opponents buildings etc. Once this is done, cards depicting buildings are placed into the players' tableau each costing a certain amount of currency to construct. Once eight building cards have been placed, the game ends. This is a relatively fast paced game and some thought has to go into which role to select and when based on what you are hoping to achieve and what you think your opponents are planning on trying to accomplish. On the negative side you feel somewhat constrained by the limited number of buildings available to you each turn and their isn't a lot of variety offered beyond the role selection which leads to games lacking in strategic depth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
French 2000 edition

RATING: 7
this is a game that starts off slowly so it might benefit from some sort of jump start. Also the building aspect seems rather simplistic compared to the quite interesting role selection aspect; it's like the vict pt system was simply tacked on. What impresses me most is how well the roles work without rule issues, I dont think we had any. So this game would be an 8 for design and mechanics more like a 7 for how much I want to play again. It takes a little long for what it does but its worth the experience at least once.

RATING: 6
8->6
I like this game for 4 or 5 players. It seems to be a very easy game. But it has a second ground. Chosing a character is very interesting. When you choose always the best character for you, someone could block you (for example with the assasin). But when you never choose the best character for you, you won`t play efficently and will not win. So in Citadels you have a psychologic game. 

For 2 or 3 players the game changes its character. You choose 2 persons. The game looses his psychological aspect and becomes a card combo aspect. I don`t like it. It`s not so original and interesting like for 4 and more people.

For more than 5 players the game has a too big downtime.

Edit: Could be frustrating if you`re few rounds in a row the target of the thief or the assassin.

RATING: 7
Citadels is a fun small card game you can play with a surprising level of depth for such a simple card game.  I liked the theme and the building of structures and the idea of the role selection and turn orders.  We had some interesting things happen with the King since a player can effectively get stuck with that role which seemed to expose some flawed mechanics, but all in all the game worked.  If it felt a little more balanced and polished I would bump it up a point or two, I really do like the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simply put I haven't played a game of this I didn't enjoy. Tried it with a number of players, it's mechanics work brilliantly and it has a "You bastard" quality that I (but so few of you) enjoy. The changing turn order works well as does the secret role choosing creating a wonderful mechanic. Generally its an easy game to teach people with some hidden depth making it well worth anyone’s collection. The Dark City expansion keeps it interesting and fresh!

RATING: 6
Game really starts to drag with 6 or 7 players.  Each player has so little control over how the game plays out that the winner seems fairly random.  It is rarely a close game for more than two people.  I also think that the rule that you cannot use the warlord on anyone who has 8 buildings is terrible, but I can see how it creates kingmaking due to open points.  I think the warlord is a bit weak, since spending money to reduce another player's score helps everyone else at the table at your own expense.

RATING: 1
My experience with Citadels is surely described in Dante's Inferno - which I could have read during the downtime.  We played with 8 players and through losing my turn on consecutive turns, I once went 45 minutes without doing anything.  At the end of the game, the "Dodge" Diplomat character got to choose the winner among three suitors.  Absolutely NO catch-up mechanism.  I was out one hour into our three hour game and had to endure.  No incentive to draw good characters, who are either bewitched or theived.  No incentive to build good structures - which are theived or destroyed.  I'm bringing a book to the next gaming session just in case this hits the table.

Am I really ranking this below Candyland?  You can play Candyland in less than 2 hours and the random nature of the game is more apparent.

RATING: 9
This is a great game.  The variablility of of what character controls your (and your opponents) city makes for a delightfully fluctuating game.  Also, the management of city district cards add a thoughful turn to the game - i.e. just &#039;cause you finish first doesn&#039;t mean you win.  My two knocks on the game would be that 1) you need to play with other people that can adapt to the strategy of this game.  2) It is possible for one player to continually get screwed by the assassin or thief characters.  Still, I love to play this one.

RATING: 6.5
There is some really good stuff here, and I can see why people like it, but it feels so light yet with a high player count drags on. But the worst part is the potential to essentially not have a turn for no good reason but mostly bad luck (I admit there is some skill in bluffing here), but that should make for a very bad game. Really not a good idea. Assassin tension is sometimes fun, sometimes annoying. The drafting is really good, the tableau building is simple but works, and the ability to mix up the roles is nice. Unfortunately though, the assassin and thief cards are simultaneously the worst and best parts of this game, as they both make it interesting and kind of nerf it.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Fairly good game. The role selection and city-building combination is fun, with the role-selection providing a good amount of player interaction and the city-building scratching the itch to try out different strategies and combinations for the most effective, efficient cities. The rules vary quite a bit depending on the number of players, which allows it to scale nicely (two players can have a good time with this!); however, the length varies significantly. With two or three players, this is done in 30 minutes or less; with more, you're looking at a much longer game, and because it feels pretty light, it might drag a bit. Also, the repetition in your limited actions--take two gold, take one card--can get stale, so it's really the player inaction that makes it worthwhile.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
There's a reason Bruno Faidutti has acquired a large following of late ... this is it. Update: More than a decade after Citadels rocketed to fame, I find I like it less and less as a big multi-player affair. It's just too long and random that way. Pretty interesting as a two-player game, though, and it hangs on in my collection because of that alone.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Citadels is a card game that uses a role selection mechanic similar to San Juan.  In the game, you are attempting to build up your city one structure at a time and prevent other players from doing the same.  The roles you pick from can decrease your building costs, increase your income, and (one of my favorites) prevent another player from taking his or her turn (the assassin).  This is a fun game, not heavy, but not a light filler either.  If you enjoy it, get the Dark City Expansion as that has replacements that broadens the types of roles you can have in the game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Finally got around to playing this a couple times with larger groups (at least 5 players) and it was a bit of a let down. Seems like it should have been great at those higher player counts but it just wasn't.

The core dilemma of the game is that you want to build valuable buildings but collecting lots of money means you are risking the thief stealing from you. And not only that, by having lots of money you draw attention to yourself, so you have to be extra sneaky in choosing a role.

This in an of itself is great. The problem is when the player count gets high, and therefore the interplay of roles is most interesting (since most roles are out there) you can often just get by on luck. And when you do get caught it really hurts. Almost certainly, a couple players get picked on our of sheer luck, and are totally taken out of the running through no fault of their own. This is one of my least favorite features of a game.

The basic mechanic has nice intrigue, but I view the thief/assassin as pretty fatal to the enjoyment of the game. The best games are the ones where fun is had by all and in this game you have the opposite: a near-guarantee that someone will not have any fun. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
What a great game. One of the most versatile games I know of. It scales really well from 2 to 8 players (no, really, I've tried them all!). Plus it's got some great backstabbing fun. Unique mechanics make for an interesting departure from other board games. My wife says she hates it, but every time it comes out, she's up for a game.

Having the expansion packed-in is really nice. It lends a nice bit of extra flavor to an already great game. The different roles allow for a different style game that plays very fresh. It's on my "must have" list.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Rating increased from 7 to 8.

My wife and I travel a lot for weeks at a time so I love "flexible" games.  This means compact,  scales well to a wide range of players, enjoyable for gamers and non-gamers, and doesn't take much space to play.

Citadels certainly hits a sweet spot for flexibility.

Update: Rating goes down from 8 to 7.  I just don't enjoy it as much anymore. All the above about flexibility is still true and I think this might also be a game every collection should have.  It is just not as fun as it used to be.

Many disagree about how many palyers is the sweet spot, but it certainly does accomodate a wide range of players at least adequately.

It is very compact.

It can easily be played on a card table-sized table.

Enough game for gamers, but non-gamers can easily figure it out and have fun.

Beyond its "travelability" it is just a good game.  It has beautiful components, great replayability and expansions, a fairly wide range of ages can enjoy it and it is also "fun".

If I could keep only one game in my collection this might well be it.  Not because it is my favorite, but because it is so darn easy to get to nearly any table.

Update:  I just never choose to play this.  It takes too long. I need to try this with less buildings required.



Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 5
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 5
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 5
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 4


Overall - 5

RATING: 7.5
I don't see why every Portland gamer I play with dislikes this game.  Random elements in other games can get to me, but I like the guesswork in this game - sure, you could end up being horribly unlucky, but I actually like that better than "screw the leader".  I enjoy this with three players and have played this quite a bit with my family.  We have the FFG Silver Line edition including the Dark City expansion, but mostly play with the base set.

I like playing with three, since you get two characters each turn and can plan for combinations of actions - the same kind of feel I get with two-player Race for the Galaxy.

RATING: 6.5
My first experience with Citadels was terrible. There were too many players and too many had never played before. I was not able to even establish a working strategy before the game ended, which is a foreign feeling for me regardless how obtuse the game might be. After reading some reviews I decided to give the game another shot but as a two player game rather than with a group. This went over very well. My wife and I played together several times She enjoyed the game more than I but primarily because the bluffing/guessing mechanic is something she does well with (I HATE poker and can't stand bluffing games). After a while we both started to tire of the Assassin playing such a central role in the game and so stopped playing. I have the expansion but have yet to try the game with the alternate characters. This is a great game for the right people. I enjoy the occasional play, but I'm not the right people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Easy to learn, hard to win slow deduction game with solid player interaction. 

It plays well with a variety of players (from 2 to 8 with the included exp).
With 4+ players the game is exceptionally tense, and you need to constantly make tough choices and guesses.

The theme is a bit too dark for my taste, and it's really a "my death"-"your life" game. So it's not a family game, new or "bad" players tend to make some pretty random choices spoiling the balance, and players get pissed-off/dissapointed a lot due to the cutthroat gameplay. The major flaw however is downtime, which can increase exponentially the more inexperienced or ap prone players are.

In the end, this game is excellent with players with a lot of nerve and patience, the kind the average player lacks. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Played 2,3,4,5,6 players. Always a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
An OK game, but not more than that.  I used to rate it more highly, but as I've played more games its shortcomings have become more evident to me and I have now traded it away.  One definite negative is that it can be dreadfully frustrating if you spend an entire game getting killed or robbed (which happened to me in my second game) -- especially since these events are (at least at the beginning of the game) fairly random.  My biggest criticism is that it always seems to take a bit longer than it should (or is welcome).  I'll still play this on occasion if it is suggested, but I've moved beyond the point where I want to play a game just because it has one or two clever twists on tried and true mechanics if the game overall doesn't measure up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fun fun fun.  Controlled chaos.  I think the group you play with has alot to do with how much you will enjoy it.  The balance between the characters is incredibly well done.  I can't recommend it for less than 5.  I also recommend playing to 7 districts.  This is our closer on game nights for two reasons.  One it allows everyone who attended game night to play(we normally get 6-8 people), and two:  everyone likes it.  This game is responsible for the success of my game night.  6 with the addition of the queen is the sweet spot for this, in my humble opinion.  The perfect beer and pretzels game.   Really funny to play, when taken too seriously. Creates some classic moments in gaming.  Not the usual fare I fall for, but it does what it does really well and in an enjoyable manner.   With 7+ players you should play to six districts.  This avoids the game "bogging" down to a finite amount of cards at the table.  If the game devolves into this it can drag... but its the best social type game around if this does not occur.

The assassin and trying to avoid it makes the game shine for me.  The game is at its best when you are in the lead, you receive the character deck and the assassin is missing.  You know the assassin is gunning for you and the think/double think emerges for this very important decision.  Similar feeling with the thief, but not nearly as scary.  The tension and decision point at these moments is unlike any other game I have played.  

I have been thinking of end game variant.  I think if the number of district cards in hand becomes sufficiently low the game should end.  The game can drag when the number of district cards in hand become sufficiently small.  Playing to 7 districts normally fixes it, but an alternate end game trigger would address the exact problem that I have experienced.  

A unique game which creates a great social experience for players. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
WOW! If you haven't played this what are you waiting for.  It's a FF Silver line game so it's going to set you back $20 brand new.  Find it used for less.  FANTASTIC game.

UPDATE: After a few years and Mission Red Planet coming out which handles the role selection process better I've moved this down a notch to an 8. Still a cool game. No doubt there. 

UPDATE: Another couple years and this doesn't hit the table much. Got to play it recently and it's still a good game but gotta drop the notch a bit more. Now a 7.

RATING: 5
Somewhat interesting role-selection card game.  Works best with 4 or 5 players.  While it claims to work with 2 to 7 players, I find that there's too much downtime while picking roles and between turns with 6 or 7 players.  Also, the bluffing mechanic doesn't work as well with only 2 or 3 players.  Like Bohnanza, I find the 2-7 claim is a bit overstated.  All that being said, this can be a fun and engaging card game if you have the right mix of people, but it has the tendency to get bogged down and take far too long for what it is.

Received as gift: July 20, 2005

RATING: 3
Someone had once mentioned Citadels to me as a game they thought I wouldn't care for.  Spoiler alert: They were right.

At first blush, the game seems like something that would be fun.  It's a role selection and deduction game about building buildings.  Unfortunately, it's a high conflict game where other people can muck things up by stealing all your gold, assassinating you for the turn or tearing down your building.

When we got to the fourth round and I had already lost two turns to assassination, I knew that I didn't like this game.  The game lasted maybe 7 rounds and I accomplished very little.

The game is pretty, but the gameplay didn't suit me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like many things about it:
- the role selection is fun (there is tactic, (low) strategy, attention and guessing elements on it);
- the gameplay, once everyone knows how the game goes, is somewhat fast, though downtime can be an issue with 6+ players;
- the artwork is gorgeous;
- an all the game fits a small box, even when the cards are sleeved!

I [i]really[/i] don't like the game when playing with more than 5 people. Five is the limit for me, as I have some terrible plays with more, I strongly recommend against it.

My review (in portuguese) is [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/772696/citadels-resenha-em-portugues-review-in-portugue]here[/url].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
First impression is not too good. Few interesting decisions. If players ignore each other it's a very simple solitaire game. Attacking other players is either direct or at worst limited by a guessing game (attack a role rather than a player). Pretty hard to solo play...

In my game the winner was the person who was in second place prior to the leader getting bashed the turn before. Scores were close, seemed like a very arbitrary win.

...If you take out the role-guessing attacks it's hard to perceive any strategy, any interaction, any game at all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A role selection game where you are trying build a city and earn the most victory points in the process.  I love that your choice of role effects when you take your turn.  It sounds straight forward, but has some social aspects that make it a lot of fun.  I prefer it with 4-5 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The included expansion, Dark City, really helps the replayability of Citadels. It adds new buildings, a full suite of replacement characters to randomly substitute in for one or two of the regulars, and a pair of number 9 characters to extend the game to 3-8 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I don't really understand the appeal of this one.  Most of the game is waiting.  First you wait for your turn to pick a character, then you wait for your turn to come up or everyone else's turn to be over.  This would be fine if the other player's turns were engaging enough to keep your interest, but the only time they're interesting is if you're being assassinated, stolen from, or having one of your buildings destroyed.  Choosing the right character at the right time and guessing which characters the other players have chosen is interesting, but that's the only thing this game has going for it.  Everything else is kind of a drag.  It is also way too long for a game this small.

Read my full review here: [url]http://www.partyhatpotato.com/reviews/2017/1/citadels-review.html[/url]

RATING: 6.5
The rating is given based on 2-player variant. I have tried it twice with my Significant Other and on both occasions, I did not enjoy the game play.

The selection of role cards felt a bit restrictive to me at times. I almost felt that I have not much choice but to choose a particular role card especially when I am the first player choosing my first card. I am not sure whether I have missed out something here. 

The effect of the Warlord is even greater in a 2 player game. The reason is one is always the target as compared to multi-player game. It can be quite frustrating that your buildings keep getting destroyed after you have built them. 

After the 2 plays, I concluded that this game may be more suitable for 3 or 4 players instead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Players seek to build a collection of districts worth from one to eight points. Once someone has built eight districts, the game is over after that round ends, and the player with the highest total value wins. However, to facilitate the process (and make the game interesting), players sequentially choose a character from a rapidly dwindling pool of eight each turn. The characters give players special abilities for the turn.

Citadels had a separate expansion, Citadels: The Dark City Expansion, but the new (3rd Edition) Fantasy Flight editions come with the expansion included (the Hans im Glück tin box also included it). With the newer version that includes Dark City, or the Dark City expansion purchased separately, this game can take 2 to 8 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Sometimes this game plays OK (even though it's mostly about guessing and bluffing), at other times the endgame ruines everything. The higher the number of players, the greater the chance that you will lose interest halfway because of the downtime or the inability to end it. It is really easy to become stuck in some sort of status quo by the end of the game when playing with five. Charming game, but not my cup of tea. By the way, I also feel that the game became redundant with the introduction of Mission Red Planet (by the same author) - a better game and very similar with regard to mechanics.
UPDATE: Played it again after 4 years (7 players) and really disliked the choatic nature of the game combined with the long playing time and the limited controlability. Games have really evolved in the last couple of years!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Card game playable up to 7 players which uses a variable-power role-selection mechanism at the beginning of each round. The goal of the game is to build districts and score the highest possible of points from them. Many of the buildings just provide points while others also give a power that alters the game. A little hard to get into on my first play but it proceeded fairly smoothly once I got the hang of it. Can't say I was really taken by this on the first play but I didn't dislike it - I'd give it another try if in the right mood. I also found it too long for what it was.

RATING: N/A
Rating on 1st play with 5. The group I played with seemed to enjoy it, and table talk was fun. It would seem hard to knock a game with that going for it right? Usually I'd say yes. Yet the game itself was just really not fun for me. I'd rather play a better game with the same great group. Here are my gripes: (1) the role-selection process feels tedious and drags. Worse, the decision to be made with this mechanic often feels trivial by the time it gets to you (if you are not within king 2 or so.) I don't mind downtime for a good cause (brain-burning, mmmmmm), but lots of downtime for trifling choices is annoying like muzak in a broken elevator. (2) The assassin, thief and magician insure that long-term planning will be useless, and the special cards are distributed too randomly for how seemingly important they are. 

**I HAVE BEEN INFORMED THAT WE HAD A RULE WRONG AND THE COMMENTS BELOW ARE ACTUALLY A FUNCTION OF OUR INCORRECT PLAY. SO, IGNORE THIS COMMENT AND I'LL UPDATE WHEN I GET A CHANCE TO PLAY AGAIN!

But even if I ignored those knocks on the game, I'd still give it a 2 or 3: In our game, the top three players all were within a few points of each other; I had no chance of winning and yet as the Warlord (my final role on the final turn) I had the power to choose the winner. ***I hate, hate, hate, Kingmaker situations.*** What is the point of playing a game for 2 hours if it ends on a Kingmaker play? No one feels good ending like that: not the Kingmaker, not the winner, and not the should-have-been-winner. Yuck.

RATING: 7
At one point, this was my favorite 90 minutes or less multiplayer  game.  I still like it, but it's been downgraded from something that I wanted to close every game night with to something that I will merely ask for occasionally.  Still one of the best of its type.  Great guesswork.  Beautiful art and just the right amount of screwage.  The flurry of short hidden-role games that have come out recently ([gameid=131357], [gameid=139030], etc.) owe a lot to this venerable title.

If you're looking at buying a copy, make sure you get one of the newer editions, as the money, king counter, linen-finished cards and the included expansion make it a much better value than the old version.

Rated after 5 games (there might be some more in the dark history) and if I remember correctly, I have never won. The game is good (would be better if I would know a good tactic or two) with lot of interaction and being nasty to others.

One game and one year later I dropped the rating to 6. I didn't find the game that nasty or interactive anymore. The game does not feel exciting anymore, it is ok, but I don't have any special need to propose this game.

One game more and I dropped the rating to four. It is just amazing how much downtime there is in this game! You wait and wait to pick your role, then you wait and wait to make your move and then wait again to start to waiting again. Of course you can follow what others do and what they have built and speculate, but still there is more than enough time. With experienced gamers it might be faster, but still the content feels quite light. Not necessarily a bad game, but something that I don't enjoy much.

Bruno Faidutti; build a collection of buildings worth from one to eight points, but players sequentially choose a character with unique abilities from a rapidly dwindling pool of eight each turn; Category: Medieval, Card Game, City Building,  Mechanics: Variable Player Powers, Card Drafting; base game now includes Dark City expansion; Ohne Furcht und Adel

RATING: 8
This game is all about knowing your opponents, and guessing how they think.  If you're not into bluffing and out-thinking, or if you're playing with some new people, this game might not be for you.  The game seems to be better with fewer players (though with three, the mechanisms get ... weird), but 5 players seems to be the sweet spot here.  It's important to play with the right people in two different ways -- those who don't get their feelings easily hurt, and those who can keep the game moving.  If you take too long to pick a card, the downtime can be excruciating.

2 plays: 3 players
3 plays: 4 players
9 plays: 5 players
1 play: 5 players (variant role selection rule)
4 plays: 6 players
1 play: 8 players

Strategy
City constructions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great strategy game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
The players must try to build the most valuable, or the most useful districts. However, the core of the gameplay revolves around role selection. Players secretly choose a character card and pass on the rest - starting with whoever has the crown. Each character has a special ability, and the usefulness of any character depends upon your situation, and that of your opponents. If you are too obvious in your movements, you may meet an untimely death at the hands of an assassin, or a thief may whisk away all of your precious gold.

Once someone has built eight districts, the round continues until all other players have taken their actions, and then the game ends. The player with the most victory points wins. Victory points are determined by the gold value of buildings, but it is also important that players have a varied city, and complete their districts with haste if they are to see any bonus points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Cardgame. Not CCG.

KORTSPEL VUXEN:

Riktigt skoj och enkelt kortspel med flera dimensioner och strategier - men med två spelare var det lite för snabbt och rakt fram och hade ingen "tröghet" som gjorde att det blev spännande. Troligen ett helt annat (och bättre balanserat) spel på fler personer! Man bygger en stad och väljer olika roller baserat på vad man behöver för egenskaper just den rundan.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Citadels is the award winning game by Bruno Faidutti in which players are attempting to complete their city first. Each turn, players choose a secret role from eight choices: bishop, thief, king, etc. Each role has a special ability and allows the player to attempt a different strategy. Players must always beware of the deadly assassin, however, and players must constantly seek to double guess their opponents. Each city is made up of different districts, some of which also provide special abilities to the players. When combined, the game is an interesting bluffing and tactical game. This card game provides a ton of enjoyment and can handle up to seven players!
\13\\13\
Note: Requires The Dark City Expansion included with the game to play with an 8th player.

RATING: 4
Well, 2-p and 3-p are just broken and horrible - let's get that out of the way. You pretty much always pick the assassin, and then kill the king. Boring.

RATING: 6
A fun, very social (or anti-social, if your group loves the assassin) card game that plays fairly quickly once everyone becomes familiar with it. It's a bit simplistic compared to other card games I regularly play, but there is still quite a bit of fun to be had with the right group. It's rarely played around here anymore, but I keep it in the collection because of the tremendous influence it has had on the design of so many other modern games...Games that I do enjoy. 

I'm a geek that way.

RATING: 8
Great fun! Any non-party game that can support 7 well is OK in my book, and this one fits that bill quite nicely. It can be a little chaotic at times, but this isn't meant to be a brain burner. The player interaction leads to a lot of laughs; I could see certain personality types getting really angry about being assassinated and the like, though no game is good for every group, so I don't consider that a fault. It's an enjoyable, light game that is a nice bridge between fillers and deeper games.

I do think this is much better with 4+ than with 2 or 3. It's more strategic with less than 4, but also extremely take-that, and not as good as many other games with a low player count.

RATING: 7
Easter vacation was approaching fast and I needed a lightweight easy game, easily transportable and playable. I checked it out at the hobby store and I decided to buy it since the price was affordable. It turned out to be a diamond in the rough. During our 3 day vacation we practically "melted" the cards from usage and I had to buy plastic sleeves to protect them. In the end I've made many fans for this game who didn't previously have any gaming experience. A nice light weight card game which  can be player by a maximum of 7 players. A typical game lasts about 40-50 mins.

RATING: 7
Only played with two, but it's a perfect combination of simplicity and depth.  Supposedly more players cause considerably more chaos, and I can definitely see how that would come about.  But with two it's a great combination of tactics, reading your opponent, and second guessing.

Make sure to go into this game expecting to get screwed.  If you, or your friends, can't handle that, this game isn't for you.  The assassin in particular is vicious, but he's also the main cog in the strategy (at least in two player games), and thus essential.

---

Update: Now played a few times in big groups.  Frankly, I vastly prefer the two player game.  With seven this game is just way, way too long.  It is also very chaotic.  Shorter, tenser, and more strategic with two.

RATING: 9
I enjoy the mechanic where you choose your character in secret each turn, it gives everyone a chance to try out different powers and causes people to guess each other's strategy.

Also, I like how there are only a couple of ways to attack other players and it is very difficult to "team up against" or "take down" one player.  You are trying to win and not trying to make others lose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The current gaming group seems to like this one.  This isn't a short game for us though - it seems to take two hours (4-5 players) to three hours (7 players).  Then again,  our plays number in the single digits so far,  and we've always had new people.

Gameplay is probably much deeper than it may seem at first - in addition to outguessing meta-game, the action choices are far from trivial - I've been trounced most of the times we've played this game.   Long-term planning is probably much more important than I thought at first - the game really comes down to how efficient you are at converting gold to districts.  Or so I think now.

Yay!  I've finally won a game...and then I promptly came in last place again...but I think I'm getting a better grip at the strategy for this game.

RATING: 8.4
What I love-
2-player game with selecting two roles per round. The second guessing of whether or not the character you are selecting will be assassinated or thieved. The feeling of outsmarting your opponent when you correctly determine what they are doing. Building my citadel. 

What I dislike-
Higher player counts can make the Game drag between turns. Increased random assassinations can feel unlucky at higher player counts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Citadels is notable for its role-selection mechanic which, to me, is the best part of the game. It is fun to see the interactions between the various roles and to strategize based upon which are available and which your opponents may have chosen.

The game itself takes a bit too long with its surprisingly light gameplay and I think the key experience (role selection) would be better serviced with a more engaging game tied to it. As such, I think Citadels is a decent game but one that would probably be easily dethroned by other, similar game designs such as Mission: Red Planet, Libertalia or even Lost Temple for most people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Players seek to build a collection of buildings worth from one to eight points. Once someone's built eight buildings, then the game is over and the player with the highest total value wins. However to facilitate the process (and make the game interesting), players sequentially chose a character from a rapidly dwindling pool of eight each turn. The characters give players special abilities for the turn.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I'm told that I would like this game if I played it with different people. Well, I get to play with different people at festivals and cons, and when I'm at a game festival or con where I can play "big" games all night, why would I play this shallow, vaguely tactical game? You can't "plan" with this game because each turn is completely dependent on the randomness of the cards and - as far as I can tell - the random last minute decisions of your opponents. The main object, it seems to me, is to be vindictive as you can, and try to screw with the guy who screwed you last turn. Not fun.

Een rollenselectiespel dat mij niet echt weet te grijpen.

In dit spel kiest iedere ronde alle spelers een rol van de 8 beschikbaar en die worden dan op volgorde uitgespeeld.

Opzich is het best een leuk bedacht systeem, maar het duurt naar mijn idee te lang voor wat het is. Bovendien is het wat mij betreft iets te vaak voorgekomen dat een speler een paar keer achter elkaar vermoord wordt en daarmee meteen kansloos is voor de overwinning (en daar komt ook de speelduur weer om de hoek kijken).

Toch een 6, want er zitten een paar leuke ideëen in.

RATING: 8.5
Like an interactive version of Race for the Galaxy, where everyone builds their own tableau, but players can mess with each other.  This is a really nice design where each role has unique abilities, and none any more powerful than any other, so there is no single role that is always preferable - it depends on what you need to do.  Sort of a 'tweener - not really a full meaty game, but more than a typical filler.

RATING: 7
[b]This is not a game for people who care about fairness.[/b] But, aside from that, the game is a lot of fun and plays very well with younger kids (my almost-6-year-old loves it!) It's got a lot of second-guessing of other players involved. Lots of laughs, because you can try to screw over another player, but often your attempts misfire and hit an innocent bystander instead of your intended target!

It can sometimes take a little bit too long, especially with lots of players, but that can be fixed by playing to fewer buildings and/or by replacing the assassin with the witch. The assassin is more fun, but having it in the mix does slow things down.

RATING: 8
Good social game, and plays fairly quick once you're familiar with all of the character abilities.

Scales well based on number of players, and is a very different game with two players than it is with five or more.

Be sure to check out the character info in the rulebook - there are a handful of extra abilities that aren't mentioned on the individual cards (we tend to forget about them.)


It's good to be the King.

RATING: 7
I like this game. I am a sucker for building games. I have had some really good games and some poor games of this. I have played it with my 8 year old girls and they had fun, although assasination can be frustrating. I have had good games with several groups of people and my older sons. I have tried it several times with my gaming group and they just do not get into it. They think too much about each move and do not have fun with it. Middle amount of screw the other player can turn some people off. Some reviews complain about the randomness but careful money mangement seems to matter more than which specific cards you get and generally seems to pay off.

Update: For all of it's flaws this is still can be a really good time. I am not lowering my rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game I really played a lot when I first got it. The cards show their battle scars!

As you might have guessed, I liked the game back in the year 2000-ish. But even now, the game still feels great. I like how each character has their own special ability and how easy the game is to teach.

The murderer card does feel overpowered as it has been picked every round if possible. Perhaps that balances out the Merchant, who would otherwise be picked every round consistently.

The game has a good length and player turns don't take too much time, so a big group doesn't seem to increase the play time too much.

I've often heard a "Let's play another round!" when I play to game with people, which to me is a good sign.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
{ P - 5 [6] 7 }

Analysis of a Meaningful Decision in Citadels

A card is burned. The King is looking at Assassin, Thief, Magician, King, Merchant, Architect, and Warlord.

THE KING
"Merchant is clearly the best card here. And I'm playing a Green. Nobody can refuse that money. So should I take Merchant? I dunno - the person who picks Assassin is likely to target the Merchant because he's so powerful. And the next guy knows I either have Bishop or Merchant. But maybe the next guy also knows that I know taking Merchant is extremely dangerous! So he'll figure Merchant was burned because there's no way I'd take something so risky! So I can take Merchant because he'll assassinate Bishop! But wait ... maybe HE KNOWS that I KNOW that he knows Merchant is risky! That means he'll choose to assassinate Merchant after all! ... ... ... In that case, what happens if I take Architect?"

Five minutes later.

THE KING
"Whatever, I'll just take Thief, which in retrospect is one of the most broken roles because you can name not Merchant or Architect and always succeed. Additionally, you force someone else to take Assassin and perform the communal necessity of naming Merchant or Architect."

LAST PLAYER
"Hmm, Merchant or Architect? Merchant is more powerful, but more likely to be assassinated. So I'd better take Architect. But wait! What if the Assassin knows that I know--"

RATING: 7
A bluffing and deduction game with reasonably simple rules. Game play has some depth, arising from the different combinations of roles on hand.

The nature of play is such that downtime increases linearly with the number of players, making it unsuitable for larger number of players. The artwork is not very consistent in style from card to card.

RATING: 8
Citadels is a very cool role selection game, in which roles are selected in secrecy, with some being removed each round at random, leading to a fantastic double-bluffing element and lots of "well I can clearly not drink the wine in front of you" lines of thinking.

The theme is city building in a medieval-like fantasy setting, and it has very good components for a card game. I also love the old Silver Line boxes.

RATING: 10
+: quite easy to learn
+: short (possibly very short), easy to learn (not to master) 
+: none of your wealth is certain (money, buildings, hand of cards) and you cannot protect it all..
+: interactive/conflict-rich: leader-bashing, will you take benefits and maybe lose them or have no benefits and maybe hinder others?
+: predict the choices of other players
+: tense until the end as there's rarely a clear winner who is unstoppable
+: very flexible number of players, but best with 4 or 5
-: quite some randomness in luck with buildings or characters that are left out in the final round (but prediction/deduction is way more important!)
-: kingmaking possible (either let emotions run free, or try to do what is 'best' in a neutral way)

RATING: 4
The goal is to build a city of cards each worth a number of points.  The role you select on your round either effects you (gains you more gold or cards...) or effects another player (Theifs steal from other players... Assassins make other players miss their turn!).  In the end I find this takes too long to play with way too much down time... and I don't really care for the Assassinations (who likes missing their turn in a game that already has too much downtime...). I'd much rather play Mission: Red Planet!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is currently one of my favorite card games.  Its not a CCG, and new gamers have a much easier time picking it up.  

Its also a tense game on a psychological level, especially when you play against people who really know you well.  Choosing the right role can be agonizing and the thrill of picking correctly is exhilarating.

RATING: N/A
Type: Economic
Number of Players: 2-6 (Suggested: 5-6)
Sub-Type: City Building, Card Game, Card Drafting, Bluffing
Game Flow: Excellent (3.5 / 4) 
Gameplay: Average (3 / 6)
Appeals To: Competitive Gamers (6.75)
Less Appeal For:  Casual Gamers (6.25)

Game Length: Short (60 - 90 Minutes)
Game Balance: Moderate to High (Potential for unbalanced play if Warlord is repeatedly used against a Player, Partially Balanced by the Witch/Assassin and Bishop)

Strategy: Moderate (Card Drafting, Deduction, Bluffing)
Luck Factor: Moderate [High w/out Variant] (Balanced Card Drafting, Minimal Effect from Card Draw)
Replay Value: Moderate (Variety amongst Buildings, Card Drafting)

Suggested Variants: 
a) Custom Professions Deck - For a more balanced game, use the Dark City Professions with the exception of the Bishop(5), Merchant(6), Warlord(8) from the original game.

RATING: 8
After 5+ Plays: Lots of luck, but also quite a bit of fun.  You can really get hammered if you get hit with the thief and the magician in one turn, and end up with no gold and no cards!

After 10+ Plays: I still really enjoy this game, and have found it to be particularly good with 3 players, as there is less downtime between turns and little chance of the game outlasting its welcome. Upping rating from 7 to 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Here is a decent game that can ruin friendships. The concept is easy enough to learn and play - pick a role, then either get more money/cards or use said money to build a new building.

The assassin role is exploitable, particularly in games with fewer people, as you can use it in tandem with the king to permanently be the start player, which carries advantages. I prefer to play with some of the alternate roles.

With too many people the game can drag way too long, especially if you have roles in play that can punish the leader (like the Warlord). Also, with more players you tend to lose a bit of control over your game, as the power shifts to whoever has the external effect roles which can target whoever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
Every time I play this game, it is a major disappointment. The last time I played this game, it dragged on for about 3 hours, i.e. as long as a typical heavy euro game. The game is simply too long for what it is. The tedious slow progress is baked into the game because of the character murdering, money stealing, card exchanging, and building destroying. The same mechanisms also give a feeling of lack of control. During our last game, we also saw a player get so far behind by the time the game was half way, that his chances to win were negligible.  Nevertheless, that player had to endure another hour of limping behind the rest, which was of course no fun. There are so many other shorter and far more fun games to play on the market, that this one is simply not worth considering.

RATING: N/A
Got it because it can be played w/ 2 players and has many mechanics I typically enjoy. 

In Citadels, players take on new roles each round to represent characters they hire in order to help them acquire gold and erect buildings. The game ends at the close of a round in which a player erects his/her eighth building. Players then tally their points, and the player with the highest score wins.

2-8 players though. 8!! I imagine that would take a while. I would totally try it sometime though.

RATING: 8
This is another quick and fun card game. The artwork is beautiful and the game play very deep. The 'guessing' mechanic doesn't become old, and having a good poker-face is a key component towards winning.

RATING: 9
I've only played this game as a two- and three-player game, and I think I'd like to keep it that way.  I really enjoy games where you have to get inside the head of your opponent, and, from what I've seen of this game, that works better with a smaller player count.

RATING: N/A
Cada ronda selecciona un rol cuyo beneficio depende de tu ciudad. Comienza la ronda quien tenga al rey (rol Nº1). Si eres muy obvio en tus intenciones podrías ser asesinado. Intenta construir los distritos que otorgan más PV sin ovidar la variedad.
